","The Story...

My name is Sean Sullivan, I am a Northern California based professional photographer and filmmaker.  For more than 25 years I have been capturing imagery from some of the most stunning adventure destinations around the globe and sharing this imagery with the world through books, magazines, and websites.
I took a trip to Southern Belize in December 2015, the video posted above is from that trip.  Due to the short time frame of this campaign, we've chosen to post this as our video
column2: in it we share some of the beautiful scenes that are so unique to this area.  BTW > Those who stick around to the end of the video will be rewarded with 3 minutes of cerebral sunrise tranquility recorded at the waters edge on French Louie Caye.  We include this here because this a big part of what makes this place so special and why it must be protected from those who wish to develop the area without forethought of how their actions effect the big picture here.

column1: The Cause ...
As it seems with all pristine places, this region is under threat from all sides. We are hoping through this project to make a contribution towards the preservation of this sacred sanctuary.

In late 2015, with little fanfare or consultation with locals, the government of Belize signed a deal with Norwegian Cruise lines to allow their ships to dock at Harvest Caye 3 miles south of Placencia.  This region is renown for it pristine nature, Garifuna culture and the longest barrier reef in the Northern Hemisphere.
photo courtesy

At times the cruise ships will bring as many as 4000 people A DAY to the area, and with them comes their garbage, human waste, and undoubtedly destruction to the pristine reef system that this part of the world is so known for.
The Mission ...

At the start of 2016 I was approached by members of a local Belizean conservation group known as the Placencia Fishermans Coop,   We talked about producing a series of short cultural narrative videos based around the local people and their environment.  From footage shot over the course of 2 weeks April 14-28, we will create a series of video pieces
column2: each centered around a different aspect of Belizean experience. These shorts will in turn be shown to all disembarking cruise ship guests as they arrive in Placencia.  The hope is that these images will inspire people to recognize the importance of being mindful towards both the land and the people.

column1: Working together with the From the Heart Foundation, Our primary goal through this project is to educate and inform this impending tidal wave of humanity in regards to the pristine nature of the area as well as the unique Garifuna Culture that is synonymous with this part of the world.
We could use your help...
All proceeds from this campaign will go towards the costs involved with this project. This includes food, lodging, transfers, guide services

Short Summary
Hi,

I’m Jake. I have been exploring, practicing, learning and living the practices of Re-wilding and Natural Movement for the last 6 years of my life. Over those years I have been learning what it means to be truly alive, how to live in connection with my nature as a human animal and how to thrive in the modern world. There have been some underlying themes in my journey that have always brought me back to the idea of place-based, community-centric culture that honours humans as a natural and integral part of the ecosystem in which we live. I have discovered that we are a part of nature, and we require a symbiotic relationship with nature in order to thrive.

In my travels and exploration of these concepts, a strong vision and idea of what I want to create has come to me and inspires me in all that I do today. But I know that in order to turn this vision into a reality I will need help, I will need a community.

I envisage the re-aligning of our lives with the ancestral practice and lifestyle of place-based culture, where we live as an integral part within a greater ecosystem. The creation of such a community is a long process, but all great journeys start with one step. My one step is the creation of retreats that enable facilitators to share ancestral living skills such as hunting, gathering, natural movement, building, food processing, tanning, crafting, wrestling and so on in an immersive environment designed to empower participants with not only the skills they need to survive in life but also the community that will enable them to thrive. The main theme of these retreats will be re-wilding, natural movement and community, celebrating what it means to be fully alive as a wild, strong, free group of humans. This project is very much a community-based operation, I’m sure as you’re reading this you can think of thousands more ideas for what these retreats could look like and that is the point. I want to involve you in this process, this is not about an individual, it’s about a collective, moving towards a better way of life. I want you to help me, if you are reading this then you are in a unique position, you are aware that life can be fuller, richer, brighter and more vibrant, you seek a similar vision, and we both know that vision is turned to reality through collaboration.
I want you to reach out, share your ideas, connect and join me on this journey.

If you support this project here on Indiegogo, you will be contributing to the creation of the retreats and positively impacting participants lives and the natural community with which we will integrate.
<h3>What We Need &amp
<ul>

• We will need a decent amount of funding to get this off the ground, perks at the moment include early bird tickets to the first two retreats (Autumn and Spring 2021) and will soon include other options as we expand such as t-shirts and online courses.

• If we do not reach our goal, funds will still be used to fund a smaller project that will still be focused on bringing together the aforementioned elements and creating a transformative experience while still being profitable.
<h3>Risks &amp

Inevitably there will be challenge in getting this project off the ground. I feel blessed to have immense experience working and helping to create similar events around Australia. I feel confident in my ability to lead this project through to success and have many connections who are ready to help me make this happen.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially, there are many ways in which you can help:

- Volunteer - help me set-up the event and the infrastructure required. If you have any experience with event organisation and set-up, promotion or any other skills you think might come in handy then please get in touch with me via Instagram (@move_wild) or email - jake@movewildcollective.com

- Facilitate - I am looking for people to help facilitate, whether that is background work in terms of mentoring and holding the community or at the forefront, teaching skills. If you are interested in facilitating at this retreat, please get in touch with me - Instagram (@move_wild) or email - jake@movewildcollective.com

- Promote - I will need many people who can help promote this event to get it out to more people. At the low-level if you could share this work that would be much appreciated in getting it out there. If you have skills in marketing, videography and promotion I would love to connect in order to get this retreat out to more people. Get in touch with me on Instagram (@move_wild) or via email - jake@movewildcollective.com
- Invite - Know anyone who would be interested in these retreats? Share this page with them! :)

Do you love the ocean?  So do I....

In early 2016, I went on a vacation that somehow turned into a mission. I went to a beautiful Caribbean Island and was devastated by the amount of trash I found on the beaches and in the ocean.

 

I started to make art out of the beach trash - to try to make something positive out of something quite horrific. During the day, I would beach comb the plastic-covered beaches and find 'treasures' that emerged into art - mostly mobile and totems made out of children's toys.

In the evenings, I would scour web pages learning about trash in our oceans.  I learned that what I was seeing was happening to the ocean and beaches everywhere in the world. I learned that:
• We dump 16 billion pounds of trash in the ocean each year.
• By 2050, there will be more pounds of trash in the ocean than pounds of fish.
• Plastic is killing a million seabirds and 100,000 sea animals every year.
• This plastic never goes away - it just breaks down into smaller and smaller pieces.
• Fish think these pieces of plastic are food and they're eating them - and then we're eating the fish.
• The plastic we are eating is very toxic and is linked to cancers, heart disease and birth defects.

Who knew? Even though I had worked on environmental issues for 25 years, I didn't - and I'm sure many of you reading this didn't either.

Splash Trash Tour

It changed my life. No matter how I tried, I couldn't let it go. I knew I had to do something more.

So I created the Splash Trash Tour to promote dialogue and action around trash in our oceans and what we can do to make a difference.

The Tour includes an arts-based interactive Pop-Up Show, presentations to local groups, activities with schools and teachers and work with the media.

We have been invited to tour six locations along the Florida Gulf Coast in early 2017. Great locations including the Apalachicola Estuarine Research Reserve in Eastpoint, Padgett Park in Walton County, Brooker Creek Preserve in Tarpon Springs, Robinson Preserve in Bradenton, St. Joseph Bay Preserve in Port St. Joe and the Key West Eco-Discover Center.

The Tour activities and messages will touch the lives and hearts of at least 30,000 people. At least 1,500 people will make a public commitment to adopt a new habit that reduces trash in our oceans. More than 500 school children will be involved in Tour activities. At least 30 media articles and reports will spread the word about trash in our ocean even wider.  

Help the Splash Trash Tour Reach 10,000 people.

I am totally self-financing this Tour.

Crazy, right? That's why I need your help!

In this first Indiegogo campaign, I'm asking you to help me reach 10,000 people.

Each dollar you donate will help me reach one more person. 

It might be a child who grows up to be a marine biologist, a teacher who will share the Tour messages with her classroom, a young father who wants to help his children understand the world around them or a journalist who will spread the word among her viewers.
column2:
>Any level of donation will make a difference!

Other Ways You Can Help the Splash Trash Tour
column3: >PLEASE - ask at least one other person to support the Tour!  Share this with your family and friends and encourage them to donate as well. (At the top of this page, click on the Facebook  or email icons to the right of the ""Back It"" button.)
column4: >Like and follow the Splash Trash Tour on Facebook, Instagram and YouTube.
column5: >Invite your friends and family who live near the Tour locations to visit the Pop Up Show and participate in the Tour activities.
column6: >If you live in one of the Tour locations, connect me to local media and networks to help spread the word or volunteer to help out at the Pop-Up Show.
column7: >Schedule the Tour in your community.
column8: >Schedule the splash trash art in your gallery space.
column9: >Feel free to contact me with other ideas!  Or at:  splashtrashtour@gmail.com
column10: >Together we can make a difference!
column12:
>www.splashtrashtour.com

Growing a Global Community of Nature-Protectors  

I’m Naamal De Silva, Founder of Mayla. My earliest memories are of finding comfort and excitement in exploring the vibrant tropical garden of my home in Sri Lanka. By the time I was 8, I was an apartment-dweller in DC, but stories by people like Jane Goodall made me decide to protect nature when I grew up. 

That goal stayed with me through graduate work at Yale and 9 years at Conservation International. I worked with inspiring people around the world and traveled to stunning places. But, what I gradually lost during this race against extinction was my optimism about the future of nature. I decided to switch to local environmental education. 

But, I was still inundated with stories of species extinction, deforestation, coral reef bleaching, political corruption, and corporate irresponsibility. I spoke with many, many people who felt the same way. So, I decided to create a platform to share the successes of people who protect nature. I would use their stories to connect people to nature and to each other. 

Welcome to Mayla: Matchmaking for Nature. 

We are a mission-driven digital media company: we will build community online through creating, aggregating, and sharing uplifting stories about people around the world who protect nature. 

But we are more than digital media. We will use technology to translate stories to action. For example, you read a story on Mayla about a James, a Samoan cleaning up the plastic pollution that threatens his nation’s reefs. Through our platform, you could donate to directly his organization, but you could also sign up to clean litter traps on the Anacostia River, or find a local grocery store that banned bottled water. In this way, Mayla is global and local. 

No other organization does exactly what we intend to. There are many organizations that cover aspects of Mayla’s mission, and we see them as future partners. 

We aim to grow a diverse global community of nature-protectors who create hope, find joy and work together to solve wicked environmental problems.

We launched our website on Earth Day and have been rapidly growing community and gathering story ideas through our Facebook group, attending events, and engaging our networks. Over the next few months, we will research the needs of potential customers and develop a range of proof-of-concept stories. As we gain traction, we will seek sponsors and investors. Within 18 months we will have advertisers on board and plan to expand rapidly.

To grow, we need your help! Please support our crowdfunding campaign, join our Facebook group, and share your stories and ideas. 

Who We Are 

Collectively, our team has founded seven organizations, both nonprofit and for-profit. We have expertise in filmmaking, fundraising, strategy, marketing, arts entrepreneurship, photography, and graphic design. 

Naamal De Silva, Founder. Eco-Equity Challenge Coordinator at George Washington University, co-president of DC Environmental Education Consortium, and a doctoral candidate in education . Previously, she was director of conservation priority setting and outreach at Conservation International. Naamal was born in Sri Lanka and moved to DC when she was six.

Robin Moore. Communications director for Global Wildlife Conservation, senior fellow of the International League of Conservation Photographers, an independent photographer represented by National Geographic, and co-founder of Frame of Mind. Robin grew up in Scotland and has lived in DC for many years
column2:
he provides support on partnerships and storytelling.

Vaughn Perry. Equitable development manager at the 11th Street Bridge Park, co-founder of Happy Ours, an educator, preacher, and coach. Vaughn is a DC native and provides support on community outreach and strategy.

Bill Finnegan. Co-founder of the Tamarack Media Cooperative, provides support on environmental media.

May Curry, an independent graphic designer and co-founder of Spark Design, advises Mayla on creative partnerships and graphic design.


William Crosse, a deputy director at the Rainforest Alliance, provides us with stunning photographs and advises us on measuring impact.
 
Anne Corbett, co-founder of Building Creative and Cultural DC, advises Mayla on entrepreneurship and business plan development.


Karen Ancillai advises Mayla on strategy and fundraising.

What We Need

Mayla is a startup: each team member of our founding team has a day job (or several). We need to get the word out, expand our community, create more stories, and build a lean team by hiring freelance storytellers and interns. With $70,000, we can cover the costs of getting started. If fully funded, we can cover:

column1: • 3 short documentaries that focus on people who protect nature. For example, team member Bill Finnegan is currently fundraising for a documentary on solar power that is tentatively called ""Power to the People,""
• 365 portraits. Each portrait consists of a photograph and short interview celebrating a nature-protector.
• Limited costs associated with setting up our organization, expanding the Mayla community and building the partnerships that will lead to future stories.

We definitely do not need the full $70,000 to get started - we will still be able to tell stories and any amount we raise will help. However, with the full amount of funding, we will grow faster, be less driven by donor needs, and create more impactful stories such as short documentaries.

What You Get
• Donors at all levels will be featured on our website as founding supporters.

• We are offering art and opportunities to connect to nature and other nature protectors. For example, we are offering gorgeous signed prints of the first photographs featured on our website, taken by our team members Billy Crosse and Robin Moore.

Our Community and Our Movement

By contributing to our campaign, you join the founding team as we launch our organization. You will join a community and a movement. We will collectively replace messages of despair with ones of hope and possibility. We will showcase innovative ideas, creative solutions, and meaningful actions. We will develop or adapt technology that enables Mayla  members to act in their own communities and support partner organizations. Together, we will solve wicked environmental problems and create joy through growing community and exploring nearby nature.

Risks &
column2:
Challenges

The biggest risk to the success of Mayla is that we do not attract a large number of people. Our success depends on growing a large global community online, and on developing the technology and the partnerships that would enable Mayla members to act locally. Fortunately, the existing networks of our team members collectively encompasses many nations and professions within both the arts and the sciences. We will also continually seek input and partnerships. 

How You Can Help

We need your help to move from idea to action. Please support for Indiegogo campaign. If you cannot support us financially, you can still join our community and help to spread the word. Join our Facebook group and follow us on Twitter. Share our campaign through social media. Thank you so much for your help! We are really excited to get started!

","Growing a Global Community of Nature-Protectors  I’m Naamal De Silva, Founder of Mayla. My earliest memories are of finding comfort and excitement in exploring the vibrant tropical garden of my home in Sri Lanka. By the time I was 8, I was an apartment-dweller in DC, but stories by people like Jane Goodall made me decide to protect nature when I grew up. That goal stayed with me through graduate work at Yale and 9 years at Conservation International. I worked with inspiring people around the world and traveled to stunning places. But, what I gradually lost during this race against extinction was my optimism about the future of nature. I decided to switch to local environmental education. But, I was still inundated with stories of species extinction, deforestation, coral reef bleaching, political corruption, and corporate irresponsibility. I spoke with many, many people who felt the same way. So, I decided to create a platform to share the successes of people who protect nature. I would use their stories to connect people to nature and to each other. Welcome to Mayla: Matchmaking for Nature. We are a mission-driven digital media company: we will build community online through creating, aggregating, and sharing uplifting stories about people around the world who protect nature. But we are more than digital media. We will use technology to translate stories to action. For example, you read a story on Mayla about a James, a Samoan cleaning up the plastic pollution that threatens his nation’s reefs. Through our platform, you could donate to directly his organization, but you could also sign up to clean litter traps on the Anacostia River, or find a local grocery store that banned bottled water. In this way, Mayla is global and local. No other organization does exactly what we intend to. There are many organizations that cover aspects of Mayla’s mission, and we see them as future partners. We aim to grow a diverse global community of nature-protectors who create hope, find joy and work together to solve wicked environmental problems.We launched our website on Earth Day and have been rapidly growing community and gathering story ideas through our Facebook group, attending events, and engaging our networks. Over the next few months, we will research the needs of potential customers and develop a range of proof-of-concept stories. As we gain traction, we will seek sponsors and investors. Within 18 months we will have advertisers on board and plan to expand rapidly.To grow, we need your help! Please support our crowdfunding campaign, join our Facebook group, and share your stories and ideas. Who We Are Collectively, our team has founded seven organizations, both nonprofit and for-profit. We have expertise in filmmaking, fundraising, strategy, marketing, arts entrepreneurship, photography, and graphic design. Naamal De Silva, Founder. Eco-Equity Challenge Coordinator at George Washington University, co-president of DC Environmental Education Consortium, and a doctoral candidate in education . Previously, she was director of conservation priority setting and outreach at Conservation International. Naamal was born in Sri Lanka and moved to DC when she was six.Robin Moore. Communications director for Global Wildlife Conservation, senior fellow of the International League of Conservation Photographers, an independent photographer represented by National Geographic, and co-founder of Frame of Mind. Robin grew up in Scotland and has lived in DC for many years

INDIAN DAIRY INDUSTRY AN OVERVIEW

India, producing 150 Million Metric Tonnes (MT) of milk annually which is equivalent to 18.5% of the world’s milk production, is the largest milk producer in the world, eclipsing the United States, Russia, Germany and France. But these figures belie that fact that there are huge problems in the Indian dairy industry. The fact that the average milk yield per cow per lactation in Europe, United States and Israel is about 6500kg, 11000kg, and 12000 kg respectively and in India it is only less than 900 kg, is a clear indication that the industry is not efficient and needs fixing.

Some might argue that in the western countries, the cows are more productive because of the more conducive cold weather prevalent there, but then you would be hard put to explain how the Israeli farmers, where the climate is even more arid and extreme than it is in India, with the desert temperatures soaring above 55oC in summer and below 5oC in winter, have a higher yield per cow per lactation.

The productivity of the farm animals in the Gulf countries, like in the UAE and in Saudi Arabia, where modern dairy management practices, proper housing, feed management, and higher-quality germplasm are standard, is also on par with the European countries. However, in India, because of the low animal productivity, not only is the costs of milk production, processing and marketing very high, the hygiene standards are low resulting in milk quality that is poor or sometimes even injurious to health.

There are four main aspects to Dairy farming:
• Animal Management,
• Milk Production,
• Milk Processing, and
<li value=""NaN"">Marketing &amp

In most developed countries, the same business entity oversees all four areas. In India, however, big and small key players of the dairy industry only undertake milk processing and marketing, leaving animal management and milk production to small-scale, unorganized farmers who view cattle rearing only as a supplementary activity. Put simply, Indian farmers do not view dairying as an independent profession. This leads to sub-par conditions, a lack of innovation, and low profits. These farmers are oblivious to the latest dairy management practices, which have revolutionized the dairy industry in other countries.

International standards dictate that milk must be chilled to below 4oC within 20 minutes of extraction from the cow’s udder as a safeguard against bacteria, ensuring and keeping the bacterial count to below 100,000 CFU/ml so that the milk is fit for human consumption. This unfortunately is not the case in India, where farmers milk the cows under unsanitary conditions and then transport it un-chilled to collection centres sometimes more than 12 hours later! The milk then gets delivered to processing facilities between 12 and 24 hours after collection. When the milk reaches the processing facilities, the bacteria count is more than 8 to 9 billion CFU/ml. Unscrupulous middlemen who use dangerous adulterants to dilute the milk are just one more hazard within the milk supply chain.

It is no accident that despite being the world’s largest producer, India contributes less than 0.1% to the world’s dairy market despite producing 150 million MT of milk. It is also worth noting that 45% of India’s agricultural produce, including dairy milk, goes to waste because of improper handling and a lack of cold chain storage facilities. Considering the fact that nearly 25% of the world’s malnourished population (and more than 50% of the world’s malnourished children, 3,000 of them dying each day) reside in India, this situation is unacceptable.

The Unnati Solution

At Unnati Manz Biotec Dairy Farm Pvt Ltd, we believe we have a solution: our state-of-the-art Integrated Biotech Dairy Farm Project at Jewali(District of Osmanabad) Maharashtra, India. The company’s philosophy is straightforward: higher-quality products and multi-directional integration directed at leading the modernisation of the Indian dairy industry at large. Already, we have partnered with dairy industry leaders from around the world, and these leaders have lauded our project for its vision, careful implementation, and potential benefits to our industry.

The main components of the farm project are:

          1. Cattle Farm

          2. Dairy production and processing Plant

          3. Biogas and Power Generation Plant

          4. Feed Processing Plant

Additional complementary components and possible JV tie-ups include:
• Fisheries
• Spirulina Farm
• Mushroom farm

• This is an integrated Indian dairy farm that undertakes the crucial functions of animal rearing, milk production, milk processing, and milk product marketing. This is a radical shift from most other Indian dairy farms, which only procure and process milk from other farms.

column1: • 100% fresh, biological Milk (NOT recombined or re-constituted milk made from powder)

OUR UNIQUE SELLING PROPOSITION- EMPOWERING THE COMMUNITY
<li>

Six Sigma Company:  We are committed to growing this enterprise into a world-class institution, holding up principles, values, discipline, efficiency, professionalism, products, output, work-culture, and a work environment commensurate with such an organisation.
<li>

Composite nature of the Project: This farm will feature the latest state-of-the-art, biotech, and composite integration in an industrial dairy farm project, something that is completely unique in India.  Our objective is to enhance the cattle breed, productivity, and raw milk quality to meet international standards. We will also keep our price affordable, carry out complementary activities to add value to our product, and reduce costs through synergy.
<li>

Multi-Directional Integration - a Unique Unnati Concept: With a multi-directional integration unique to Unnati, ours is truly an industrial dairy venture, the only one of its kind in India and possibly in the world.
<li>

Green Project / Zero Discharge Enterprise: We aim to be an environmentally friendly Zero Defects Project and a Zero-Discharge enterprise, converting all waste and discharge efficiently. We want our impact on the environment to be positive, and we will also procure agro-waste and crop residues (that would otherwise be openly incinerated), feeding into our bio-gas project and making our venture green.
<li>

Carbon Credit Eligible Project: We are registering as a CDM project through UNFCCC (United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change) and seeking approval from their CDM Executive Board. We will average 5 metric tonnes of (CO2e) credits generated per cow per year.
<li>

Priority Sector Project / Bio-technology, Agro Project: This is a bio-technology, agro-sector Project, and we are located at Jewali in Osmanabad district of Marathwada region, which is a D+ Industrial Zone, and thus eligible for the State government’s funds and incentives.
<li>

Rural Employment / Training: This project gives back to society by generating approximately 200 direct and 500 indirect employment opportunities in the rural sector.  We will offer training to aspiring entrepreneurs / employees seeking a career in dairy farming as well, improving many lives along the way.
<li>

Cow Hostel Scheme: We will invite other farmers to participate in our corporate venture through a tri-partite agreement between the member farmer, the funding bank, and Unnati, guaranteeing high fixed returns and perpetual dividends to the farmers.
<li>

Fodder Cultivation Programme: We are largely out-sourcing our feed and fodder requirement to local farmers, assuring improved yields and higher revenues. We will include nearly 500 farmers and their 2000 acres of cropland under Contract Farming through our Tri-partite Agreement with the project funding bank.
<li>
Wide Societal benefits:  We intend to champion socio-economic causes such as:
• organic farming
• soil conservation,
• micro-irrigation management
• contract farming
• rain-water harvesting and
• bio-fertilizer application
<li>
Holistic Approach to Dairy Farming: Our “Holistic Approach” to the dairy business distinguishes us from any other project in India. We will let no detail fall by the wayside
PROJECT OUTLAY &
• Total Project Outlay of this First Project is: USD 20 million
• Project Outlay So far : USD 8.5 million
• Short-term immediate funds requirement to go to market
• To fund purchase of 1000 cows :  USD 2 million
Why we need your support

This is not a Greenfield project:  This is a proven, tested and highly successful model in the world’s worst Geo-climatic conditions, in the deserts of Saudi Arabia. Doing it in India, with the most conducive conditions for dairy development where abundant green fodder and water is available and where the dairy market is growing at 16% CAGR  whilst the milk production is only growing at an annual rate of 4 % CAGR  will exacerbate the already acute mismatch between the demand and supply of milk creating more social problems.

Minimal construction / implementation risk: The project is already under  construction and nearing completion and poised to enter the market  with its high quality products with 200 cows already on site . World-class free-stall animal housings are completed and ready to house 1200 cows. All state of the art plant &
column2: machinery and equipment from China and Europe have been installed, tested and commissioned. All that is needed are more cows to make this project economically viable to enable it to sustain its massive social impact of feeding thousands of malnourished children.

column1: Replication potential: There is tremendous replication potential for such projects all over India as we could easily replicate such satellite dairy farms within every 50-100 km just around the area itself and even overseas impacting the rural folks of the major developing economies of Asia.
By-product Revenues:  All of the farm waste (manure &
column2: fodder residue) will be converted into value added products viz. biogas, bio-fuel (CNG) &amp
column3: bio-fertilizer and power generation proving the eco friendliness of the project and its ability to significantly impact the community at the same time.

column1: Dairy Management &
column2: Consultancy potential: Within India, there is tremendous potential to educate, train and uplift the rural communities within the vicinity of such integrated farms  through the setting up of a dairy consultancy which in turn would spread the knowledge of dairying and improving lives

column1: Local Demand: There is tremendous demand for milk within and around Unnati’s farm area itself with the catchment area of some 3 million people who consume about 500,000 liters of milk per day. Our farm, at peak capacity can only supply 50,000 liters per day which is barely 10% of the total volume of consumption of Solapur, the nearest town. Milk and Yogurt demand cannot be fully satiated by our farm and hence we have a high degree of confidence in implementing our expansion plan and impacting millions.
“Agri-Project Management Co and Dairy Consultants” organization. We want to bring Indian dairy farming into the 21st century.

Our Corporate Social Responsibility Initiative:  We have made it a primary goal of ours to donate a certain percentage of milk produced on each farm to orphanages and elderly homes local the farm. We are committed to donating at least 5000litres/ day in the beginning, which would provide 20,000 Children 200ml /day, satiating the daily nutritional protein needs of each child.

Priority Sector Project / Bio-technology, Agro Project: This is a bio-technology, agro-sector Project, and we are located at Jewali in Osmanabad district of Marathwada region, which is a D+ Industrial Zone, and thus eligible for the State government’s funds and incentives.

Rural Employment / Training: This project gives back to society by generating approximately 200 direct and 500 indirect employment opportunities in the rural sector.  We will offer training to aspiring entrepreneurs / employees seeking a career in dairy farming as well, improving many lives along the way.

Cow Hostel Scheme: We will invite other farmers to participate in our corporate venture through a tri-partite agreement between the member farmer, the funding bank, and Unnati, guaranteeing high fixed returns and perpetual dividends to the farmers.

Fodder Cultivation Programme: We are largely out-sourcing our feed and fodder requirement to local farmers, assuring improved yields and higher revenues. We will include nearly 500 farmers and their 2000 acres of cropland under Contract Farming through our Tri-partite Agreement with the project funding bank.
Wide Societal benefits:  We intend to champion socio-economic causes such as:
organic farming
soil conservation,
micro-irrigation management
contract farming
rain-water harvesting and
bio-fertilizer application
Holistic Approach to Dairy Farming: Our “Holistic Approach” to the dairy business distinguishes us from any other project in India. We will let no detail fall by the wayside
PROJECT OUTLAY & SCOPE
Total Project Outlay of this First Project is: USD 20 million
Project Outlay So far : USD 8.5 million
Short-term immediate funds requirement to go to market
To fund purchase of 1000 cows :  USD 2 million
Why we need your support

This is not a Greenfield project:  This is a proven, tested and highly successful model in the world’s worst Geo-climatic conditions, in the deserts of Saudi Arabia. Doing it in India, with the most conducive conditions for dairy development where abundant green fodder and water is available and where the dairy market is growing at 16% CAGR  whilst the milk production is only growing at an annual rate of 4 % CAGR  will exacerbate the already acute mismatch between the demand and supply of milk creating more social problems.

Minimal construction / implementation risk: The project is already under  construction and nearing completion and poised to enter the market  with its high quality products with 200 cows already on site . World-class free-stall animal housings are completed and ready to house 1200 cows. All state of the art plant & machinery and equipment from China and Europe have been installed, tested and commissioned. All that is needed are more cows to make this project economically viable to enable it to sustain its massive social impact of feeding thousands of malnourished children.

Replication potential: There is tremendous replication potential for such projects all over India as we could easily replicate such satellite dairy farms within every 50-100 km just around the area itself and even overseas impacting the rural folks of the major developing economies of Asia.

By-product Revenues:  All of the farm waste (manure & fodder residue) will be converted into value added products viz. biogas, bio-fuel (CNG) & bio-fertilizer and power generation proving the eco friendliness of the project and its ability to significantly impact the community at the same time.

Dairy Management & Consultancy potential: Within India, there is tremendous potential to educate, train and uplift the rural communities within the vicinity of such integrated farms  through the setting up of a dairy consultancy which in turn would spread the knowledge of dairying and improving lives

Local Demand: There is tremendous demand for milk within and around Unnati’s farm area itself with the catchment area of some 3 million people who consume about 500,000 liters of milk per day. Our farm, at peak capacity can only supply 50,000 liters per day which is barely 10% of the total volume of consumption of Solapur, the nearest town. Milk and Yogurt demand cannot be fully satiated by our farm and hence we have a high degree of confidence in implementing our expansion plan and impacting millions.
“Agri-Project Management Co and Dairy Consultants” organization. We want to bring Indian dairy farming into the 21st century.

Our Corporate Social Responsibility Initiative:  We have made it a primary goal of ours to donate a certain percentage of milk produced on each farm to orphanages and elderly homes local the farm. We are committed to donating at least 5000litres/ day in the beginning, which would provide 20,000 Children 200ml /day, satiating the daily nutritional protein needs of each child.",5.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Novelty Bizcentre, Singapore",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/biotec-dairy-farm--2/pica
0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a="""">
Check
out this inspiring Indigenous alliance initiative - bringing together
Indigenous leaders from the North and from the South. We need the
support of everybody and make sure that our brothers and sisters from
the Amazon and North America grow this driving force we all need in the

face of this climate chaos. We will all go to Paris for attending the last Climate Summit in December and ensure that the Indigenous delegations rise as those voices for change they are supposed to be.

""As
the industrial corporations push further and further their destructive
projects, destroy more and more Mother Earth, the people are now rising up.
From outside, it seems to be tragic
column2: but from inside, a spiritual giant has

column1: awakened. It is the reunion of the people that were already linked together. It
is a reunion beyond borders. It is a reunion around the world."" - Phil
Lane Jr.
The
Takeoff Project aims to explore the solutions
available to the many impacts of industry’s expansion of “extreme” crude oil on
global and regional ecology and on the welfare of Indigenous communities.
These funds will finance the trips of 4 indigenous environmental leaders from North
America to South America, facilitating the creation of bonds and alliances with
the local Indigenous communities.
ABOUT
US
We
are French and German filmmakers/community organizers
with backgrounds in sociology, media and health. We took-off in April 2014 from
Europe on a 1 and 1/2 year trip that will take us to 5 countries: USA, Canada, Ecuador, Peru
&amp
We
reached a point in our lives where we felt that we could no longer keep our
eyes closed as if our future, and that of our children was not on the line. We
began to see the world more clearly, becoming more aware of the injustices that
are going on in the world. During our awakening, we witnessed an incredible
movement building and being led by indigenous people and wanted to support
their efforts. When you are aware, you have a responsibility to act.
We
made it our mission to let the world know about the commitment and work of all
the inspirational worriors that stand against extractive industries. We want to
show their positive approach of building strong bonds all over the world in
order to reach their goal to ""leave the oil in the ground"".
For
many years we watched many environmental disasters as a result of extractive
industries. When we heard about the Tar Sands we knew it was time to act. We
quit our jobs, took our ten years savings and began our journey to North

America.

Canada’s
tar sands operations are a global environmental disaster with more
than 140,000 km² total exploitable reserves — an area larger than England. Tar
sands is the biggest energy project in the world, currently producing 1.9
million barrels of oil a day.  The impact of the Alberta tar sands on
local First Nations communities is devastating, but this massive extractive
industry is a concern for communities all over North America and the entire
globe.

ABOUT THE PROJECT

We
committed to create a documentary film, “The Condor and The Eagle,” that
weaves together the  story of 4 individuals (2 from the U.S. &amp
Canada - 3 women and 1 man) who in their way take a stand against corporate
pollution, organizing communities where they live. Each person is involved in
the fights against the tar sands (Northern Gateway pipeline, KXL pipeline,
Houston refineries, oil tankers.) In 2015, they will travel to South America's
Amazon Rain Forest to meet Indigenous communities impacted by similar
extractive industries.
“The
Condor and The Eagle” is not the goal but the means to bring about change and <b>convince
people of the urgency to act NOW! Therefore our project is a call to
action: to facilitate alliances and raise awareness on an international
level. It encourages people to join forces and work together (like our
key-people do) towards stopping the tar sands development.
Until now, we have managed to fund the first 10 months of
our journey in Canada and the U.S. following our four key-people where they
live &amp
column2: their efforts to build bridges between local communities. In the

column1: coming 10 months, we will fund and organize their trips to South America, facilitating
the creation of bonds and alliances with the local Indigenous communities. Our
project acknowledges the importance of women leadership and its
importance in this setting of an emerging climate movement to protect our
Mother Earth.  Thus, 3 of our 4 key-people are Indigenous women.
The folowing issues will be addressed:
<ul>
<li>The rise of the environmental
movement
<li>Continued Indian genocide caused
by the modern industrial projects
• Climate Change
• Intercultural Awareness
• Women’s Leadership
• Rights of Nature
• Community Organizing Strategies
The key-people will achieve the following in South America:
<ul>
<li>Partnerships with youth
organizations in Ecuador/Peru organized by the youth and for the youth
<li>Bonds and alliances while working
on the creation of a women treaty between Indigenous women from the North
and the South
<li>Awareness on Yasuni National Park
sellout to petrochemical extractive industries

THE 4 KEY PLAYERS

CASEY CAMP-HORINEK: 66 years old - Stands against the KXL pipeline connecting the Alberta tar sands to Houtson, Texas - crossing her territory.
also              been at the forefront of grassroots communities' efforts to educate and empower both Native and non-Native

community members on environmental and civil rights issues.

TA'KAIYA BLANEY: 13 years old singer, songwriter - Stands against the pipelines projects (Northern Gateway and Kinder Morgan) aiming to transport the tar sands from Alberta to the pacific coast.
column3:
/>

She is also in the process of creating her own organization

column1: aiming to establish a marine sanctuary, promoting an
educational approach for the youth — ""Igniting youth to restore
and protect the Salish sea through the training, leadership
and mentorship of first nations youth cultural ambassadors”.
MELINA LABOUCAN-MASSIMO: 33 years old - From tar sands region, CA - Stands again tar sands expansion projects.
column5:
/>


Beside her environmental work, Melina got involved into denouncing

column1: Canadian government's apathy towards the massive number of missing and
murdered Indigenous women. “Violence against Mother Earth is violence

against women, the two are inextricably linked” says Melina. Photograph by Ayşe Gürsöz

BRYAN PARRAS: 37 years old - Xicanos from Houston,TX - Stands against the refineries that aim to refine the tar sands if the KXL is permitted.
Bryan is deeply involved with organizing
marginalized communities to confront environmental racism
in the sacrifice zones of Houston and the greater Gulf
Coast region. He is currently raising awareness around the
potential harms and environmental effects of the KXL tar

sands pipeline.


THE CAMPAIGN
We
are reaching out to you today because we need your
support in order to achieve our end-goals of the coming 10 months. This is a
big scale project with a total cost of more than $200,000. The $35,000 of this
crowdfunding campaign will help us finance the travel expenses of our 4 key-people
and 4 of their collaborators to South America as well as our own organizational
costs (preparatory work, scouting, first contacts.)
We
are promoting a constructive and positive vision for both the film’s creation
and its final distribution, emphasizing the achievements and actions of
key-people who are bringing about positive and tangible changes.
Don't
underestimate the magnitude of what YOU can help achieve.
Your support will greatly help connect the film's key players in the
environmental movement throughout the American continent and beyond.
YOU
will help amazing and powerful Indigenous women/leaders raise awareness,
organize events, panels and community discussions in collaboration with local
actors. The success of our project lays in our understanding that “The Condor
and The Eagle” is not the goal but the means to bring about change and convince
people of the urgency to act NOW! This movement-in-the-making, climate
change action depends upon making those vital cross-border connections. Its success
also depends on the support from people like YOU.
THE IMPACT
We
aim to use the film as a way to blow the whistle and alert the public to the
urgent issues emphasized in our film. Once the film is finished, we will continue our
travels (North America, South America &amp
column2: Europe) using the film as an

column1: educational tool. We want to reach as many people as possible and collaborate with
environmental and local grassroots organizations, we will organize an awareness
campaign on the moratorium of tar sands development and extractive industries
in the Amazon.
As
we are confronted with the largest energy project on the planet that threatens
to push us into climate chaos, it is more than necessary to gather those
amazing stories of resistance and cultural preservation.
Other
Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially to this project, you can still make a
difference and help out! Let's get the word out and let people know about the
importance of our project and convince them that, in turn, they should spread
the word as well. Let's activate our networks and make sure that in the coming two
months, a maximum of people will get acquainted with our work and the work of
the 4 ""key people."" Let's make some noise!
Use the Indigogo share tool and share our campaign with your
friends and visit www.thetakeoff.org where we will post photographs and
videos during the trip.
Together, we will be stronger!
Sophie &amp

column6: >COLORADO THROWS AWAY OVER 450 MILLION GLASS BOTTLES EVERY SINGLE YEAR…..

column1: WAIT, WHAT? COLORADO RECYCLES, WHAT GIVES?
Definition of Recycling: to undergo reuse or renewal
column2:
be subject to or suitable of further use, activity, etc.:


Glass is the perfect recyclable material, it is INFINITELY recyclable without any loss in quality. What does that mean? It means, I can take an old glass bottle, crush it down, melt it, and make a new bottle, as many times as I want! And, this new bottle is just as good as the first bottle! 

So, wait, why is glass ending up in the landfill?! 


Other than just throwing glass directly in the trash . . . and obviously the landfill . . . we put the rest of our recyclables into a bin with the ""chasing arrows"" called single-stream recycling.

column1: That bin gets picked up by trucks and brought to a Material Recycling Facility (MRF)
<div>
<div>
That MRF then separates the recyclables into different materials (i.e.: paper, plastic, aluminum, and finally glass).
HERE’S THE PROBLEM :

When a recycling truck picks up that single stream bin, it compacts its load, which shatters the glass and smashes it into all the other materials.  When the glass gets separated out from our single-stream recycling, it looks like this:
This glass is being used as…landfill cover . . . WAIT WHAT???, that means its’ still going to the landfill along with all the glass that is thrown into the trash!
THE SOLUTION: CLASSY GLASS STATIONS!
It’s simple!
We put these stations at convenient locations you shop at . . .
<div>
and while you're out shopping, drop off your glass in our stations . . .
and we pick up the glass and take it to our facility where we turn it into a purified sand called ""cullet"". . .
<div>
which this purified sand is then used to make new bottles!
And to top it all off we will be donating $1 from every filled classy glass station to local Colorado non-profits!!!
100% GLASS RECYCLING AT ITS FINEST
Be a part of THE SOLUTION and make a pledge today to help us get classy Glass Stations throughout Colorado!
THE FUN PARTS! PERKS!!!

Project S.I.A.D.

Hello Everyone, my name is David M. Champion, Vice President of Stormweapon Defense Systems, LLC. It is my honor and pleasure to present to you several facts pertaining to our proposed Anti-Hurricane Weapon System. This second Indiegogo campaign we are bringing to you is intended to raise the necessary funds to take the project to the next level. We sincerely hope that you will consider assisting us in our pursuit to save human life and our precious environment from the ravages of these future killer-hurricanes.
We have estimated the expenses that are necessary to advance our project to the next level, and in a brief break-down they are as follows:
<ul>
• Customized Super Computer, built in house by myself and my team.
• New Operations Center, portable and self-sufficient.

• Travel and Consultations, meetings with the DOD, selected drone manufacturers, and other Defense Contractors in the USA. Other agencies include NASA, NOAA, The National Hurricane Center, and a host of other weather-related  tracking agencies necessary for our project.

• Travel to foreign countries like Japan, who has already shown interest in protecting its citizens and families from the death and destruction caused by the killer-typhoons in that region of the world.
• Wrap up first phase consultations with our five-person selected scientific team.

We must immediately proceed with the major project funding which allows us to begin construction on Project S.I.A.D.. Of course we have had many obstacles in the past 12 years of this project, mainly financial, but we have supported it with every dollar we could muster and now we need your help to get it constructed and operating!
Our goals are to never again lose another innocent life from these killer storms, or lose our homes and jobs because they were eradicated within hours. We never again want to witness the terrible destruction to our Homeland, our beautiful coast lines, or to our infrastructure by the inland flooding caused by these environmental destroyers! Imagine, no more grief from the loss of a family, a friend, or a pet...
We desperately need your contributions and are offering gifts of appreciation
column2:
our Perks that are listed here in our campaign!
If it is difficult for you to contribute anything to our project, we would surely appreciate it if you would share us with all of your friends and family, to help spread the word that a Texas company can 'knock the legs' out from under a killer storm in the early making, before it grows into a killer! We may potentially not have to worry about killer hurricanes or killer typhoons ever again! We will keep everyone up to date as to our project advancement! Thank you from the bottom of our hearts! From all of us at Stormweapon Defense Systems, LLC, till our next communication, God bless all and take care.

Sincerely:
David M. Champion, Vice President

New Operations Center, portable and self-sufficient.

Travel and Consultations, meetings with the DOD, selected drone manufacturers, and other Defense Contractors in the USA. Other agencies include NASA, NOAA, The National Hurricane Center, and a host of other weather-related  tracking agencies necessary for our project.

Travel to foreign countries like Japan, who has already shown interest in protecting its citizens and families from the death and destruction caused by the killer-typhoons in that region of the world.
Wrap up first phase consultations with our five-person selected scientific team.

We must immediately proceed with the major project funding which allows us to begin construction on Project S.I.A.D.. Of course we have had many obstacles in the past 12 years of this project, mainly financial, but we have supported it with every dollar we could muster and now we need your help to get it constructed and operating! Our goals are to never again lose another innocent life from these killer storms, or lose our homes and jobs because they were eradicated within hours. We never again want to witness the terrible destruction to our Homeland, our beautiful coast lines, or to our infrastructure by the inland flooding caused by these environmental destroyers! Imagine, no more grief from the loss of a family, a friend, or a pet...We desperately need your contributions and are offering gifts of appreciation
column2: our Perks that are listed here in our campaign!If it is difficult for you to contribute anything to our project, we would surely appreciate it if you would share us with all of your friends and family, to help spread the word that a Texas company can 'knock the legs' out from under a killer storm in the early making, before it grows into a killer! We may potentially not have to worry about killer hurricanes or killer typhoons ever again! We will keep everyone up to date as to our project advancement! Thank you from the bottom of our hearts! From all of us at Stormweapon Defense Systems, LLC, till our next communication, God bless all and take care.Sincerely:David M. Champion, Vice President",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

Short Summary

column8: Wildlife Fund's scholarships give the Maasai Steppe's best and brightest children the chance to receive a private secondary school education.
column17: >In this sweeping, rural landscape, most families cannot afford to educate their children beyond Tanzania's free educational limits (up to grade 6).  APW gives rural Tanzanians who are living side-by-side with wild predators (such as the highly-threatened African Lion) the chance to benefit from wildlife presence.
column25: >These children earn their scholarships through significant participation in our conservation education after-school programs and environmental summer camps. They have demonstrated a commitment to their community and to the natural world. They want to become the future environmental leaders of Tanzania - and you can help make it happen!

column1: <h3>What We Need &amp
column2:
What You Get
  • We've already raised $8,000 for our scholars.

column1: • One scholarship = $1,000/year.
• 25 scholars = $25,000. We have $17,000 left to raise!

If you donate, you'll have the chance to send a letter directly to our scholars and/or to receive a thank-you note in return from our conservation team. Check out all the fun perks at various giving levels!

Throughout the year, you can also opt to receive regular updates on our scholars' activities.

The Impact

In Tanzania, school is free only through grade six. Without financial support, even the brightest, hardest working children cannot go to secondary school.
Those children who have successfully progressed through APW's primary school youth programs can apply for one of APW's Noloholo Scholarships.
We select scholars based on performance in our youth programs, national and environmental science exams, and interviews with an unbiased committee.

These Scholars receive 6 years of full-ride scholarship (grades 7-12), plus additional mentor and mentee opportunities and free tutoring. Scholars must receive passing grades every year in order to maintain their funding.
APW just graduated its first class of scholars!
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

We have been working on the Maasai Steppe in Tanzania for ten years. Our scholars develop a strong sense of civic responsibility and we have a strong rapport with them. Of course, they can always choose to leave the Steppe - even in this case we believe they will become environmentally-minded leaders in all walks of society.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

Share our work!
If you'd like to fund a different APW program (including our wildlife conservation programs) please go to: http://www.afrpw.org/donate to learn more.

column6: >Delivering good by delivering good food...

column1: Rolling Oasis
delivers organic produce by bicycle to your door in a socially responsible,
environmentally sustainable, economically viable and healthful way.

Environmental Impact

Every Hub saves each client 1 trip to the grocery store. Oh, by the way

that is 17,160 trips per year per Hub. The carbon reduction impact…huge!     

Social Impact

Every Hub provides income opportunity for 5 community
members with an equity mandate that 3 of 5 of these routes be represented by
communities of color. This opportunity, which takes only 10-12 hours per week,
is an equivalent wage to 43 hours at minimum wage.

Economic Impact

Every Hub generates $343,200 in revenue each year! More
than half of this goes directly back to the community being served by the

business! 

Health Impact
Significantly increases the likelihood of the community eating more fresh
produce resulting in better health outcomes.
Help Us Deliver Good!
Every Hub is
partnered with a local community-based non-profit
We do this so that we can continue the
social impact to the community and support for the route owners. It’s easy to
start something, it’s another thing to continue bringing good for the long run.
Every Hub has the
goal of 30% of customers paying with SNAP/Food Stamps
We are applying to become one of the first Oregon
Food Bank mobile distribution partners. Every one of our SNAP/Food Stamp qualified customers
would additionally receive one bag of additional groceries.
column9:
/>


So... are you a non-profit or a business?

The answer to this is simply YES... We are a non-proift that recognizes that often time market systems are where change needs to happen.  Vocoform the parent organization is devoted to using market systems to give opportunity to communities otherwise excluded.


Can't I already get food delivered?

We're not the only company that delivers organics to your home.  From similar curated-delivery services like a CSA to á la carte options like Instacart, it's an exciting time to be experimenting in innovating grocery service.


Is This Just so Portlandia?

column1: Bikes and organic food — is this just another gentrifying novelty business for white hipsters?

Far from it. This model was actually developed as part of conversations Vocoform had with communities in Chicago, IL and Richmond VA. Equity is foundational to the good we are delivering. We want affordable access to healthful food to be a reality for all in Portland and beyond.
<ol>
• Through our partnership with Vocoform, for example, at least half of all Produce Pedalers in each Hub will come from underresourced communities.
• Keeping prices on par with Fred Meyer lets folks eat healthfully without breaking the bank.
• We'll soon be accepting SNAP/EBT payments.
• A breakthrough partnership with the Oregon Food Bank will soon allow us to deliver dry goods for free to all SNAP/EBT-paying customers.
Which neighborhoods do you plan on expanding to next?
We've been operating in Lents for a year, and are actively exploring debuting service in the following Portland neighborhoods.

Short Summary

Hello my name is Ben Micek. I represent a Colorado  nonprofit specializing  in community based ecological restoration, sustainable food production, and community empowerment through classes, workshops, and demonstration sites. Our project, the Turtle Island Ecology Center is a grassland and Bison restoration project, and Organic Permaculture farm in the High Plains of Northern  Colorado.

 In 2012, I had the wonderful opportunity to study Ecological Restoration and Conservation Biology in Southern Chile and instantly fell in love with the ancient Alerce forests, the turquoise  waters, and the local culture. That is why I keep going back!
column5: >But this time when I return I am ready to get to work, and with a lot of help from my friends, we aim to reforest a 50 acre piece of land at the base of the extinct Hornopíren volcano that borders the mighty Rio Negro (black river) and create an Ecovillage.
column9:
>We plan to plant a forest with seedlings of the ancient Alerce tree, and other threatened species, and simultaneously develop an Ecovillage, Hostel, and Education Center. Known as the ""Redwoods of South America"", the Alerce trees rival the Redwood in stature and are the second oldest known living tree on Earth (3600 years), and are also one of the most threatened. They were nearly wiped out in the Hornopiren area in the past 100 years due to excessive logging and their  numbers are still dwindling. A similar fate to that of their cousins, the Redwoods.

Now an ambitious project like this must need some serious manpower, and that's why the human community is so important to the project. We hope to raise a portion of the funding through our friends, family, and the wider crowd-funding community, and we are dependent on the ideas and physical labor of our local community, the Ecovillage.
column13:
>Nestled between the newly planted Alerce seedlings will be a small and bustling community adorned with tree houses, cabins, gardens, ponds, and community areas with an eclectic and diverse family of people living simply, growing an abundance of fresh food, and treading lightly on the earth.

Mother Earth needs our help and there is lots of work to do. However, many hands make light work. And that is where the community  comes into play, the human community!


What We Need &
column14:
What You Get

Our goal is to acquire enough funds to purchase a 51 acre piece of land outside of the small fishing village of Hornopiren, Chile. The property is tucked between Hornopiren National Park and the coastal fjords of the Pacific Ocean.

The property costs roughly $73,000 including attorney fees. The land includes nearly 200 meters of the Rio Negro, with world class fly fishing and kayaking. The great news is that we have raised a good chunk of the funds and are hoping to raise the remaining $ 20,000 through crowd-funding. Any additional funds raised will  be put towards much needed basic infrastructure such as compost toilets, aquaponics, greenhouses, lodging, and gardens:)

What we can give in return is access to and lodging in one of the world's most beautiful and scenic places. Come relax in a beautiful and charming house that is a century old and still as good as new. Or camp out in an enchanted forest under the stars. Listen to the sounds of the many year round streams on the property and drink the pure, cool water right from the stream. Walk down to the river through the bamboo, moss, and fern lined paths. Hornopiren National Park borders the property, where you can see one of the last remaining ancient groves of Alerce trees, with many trees older than Jesus. 

Hike 3 days down the Rio Puelo to El Bolson Argentina, a beautiful bohemian mountain town that hippies flocked to in the 70's, with it's vibrant mix of ex-pats, breweries, hiking trails, and organic farms. Explore the coastal fjords of Southern Chile. Kayak from the property out to the Gulf of Ancud and explore the Comau Fjord where you can see dolphins, blue whales, orcas, humpback whales, fin back whales, sperm whales, and penguins. Visit nearby islands and Pumalin Park, the world's largest  privately owned nature preserve, and soak in one of the many natural hot springs. Fly fish for giant salmon and trout in the Rio Negro and nearby Rio Blanco or the many glacial lakes, or try your hand at deep sea fishing In the Pacific.

All investors can come and visit, with access to community kayaks, fishing gear, and community facilities, and watch the community grow! However there are wonderful perks listed for different levels of donations.


The Impact

Our vision is a full time community of people sharing a common goal of restoring the landscape in which we live, while crating a safe, healthy, supportive, and abundant community. The Ecovillage can be a  hub for travelers, designers, artists, musicians, teachers, farmers, the indigenous, elders, and people of all ages.

The property is in prime location to make a positive impact. Hornopiren is known as the Northern gate to Patagonia, as it is where the Southern Highway ends and ferries head south to where the road starts again towards Patagonia. Our Eco Hostel will attract Chilean and International travelers on their way into Patagonia. Ecotourism opportunities abound. With kayaking the fjords, Rio Negro, and Rio Blanco, horseback riding, guided hiking into Pumalin and Hornopiren Parks, guided flyfishing and flyfishing lodge, deep sea fishing, hostel, campgrounds, and tours to the hot springs we will provide income for the community. Nearby fishing lodges in the area charge upwards to $7,000 USD per week for guided fishing with lodging.

We aim to educate the local community, travelers, interns, and volunteers  in sustainable agriculture, permaculture, indigenous wisdom and traditional ecological knowledge, ecological design, forest ecology, ecological restoration, appropriate technologies, and most importantly we will create a space were we can honor Mother Earth and be a lasting example of positive change.

Risks &
column15:
Challenges

This has been a long time in the making since I first visited Chile, and the help I have received along the way has been unbelievable and very appreciated. Through my connections made while studying in Conservacion Patagonica, I had the privilege of receiving assistance from the founder of Pumalin Park in finding a property in the desired area, as well as finding qualified legal assistance in Chile to make the purchase. With this assistance  our risks and concerns have been greatly reduced. The title of the property has been cleared by our attorney in Chile and as of now we are ready to proceed with the purchase.

Chile is a country with a booming economy, high quality of life, abundance of natural resources, and WATER. I feel like the biggest challenge has been raising the funds. Once we have the property, we have access to tree seedlings, vegetable seed, fruit trees, berry bushes, beehives, farm animals, and local knowledge, through the connections I have made in my previous travels. We are set up for success and just need your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with someone who may be interested in supporting our project. Many hands make light work! If you are interested in sustainable agriculture, aquaponics, permaculture, or ecological restoration, please come volunteer and see what it takes to envision, design, and create a community from the ground up.
