Short Summary

My name is Josphat Wahome Kariuki, Founder and Director of Equater Fuelwood Energy Saving(EFWES). EFWES is a social enterprise energy service provider which was started in January 1998. EFWES is unique in its kind in this region(Mt.Kenya and its environs), providing reliable products and sound services based on the philosophy of professional integrity, innovative and advocacy for sustainable use of natural resources. The services are offered through efficient, acceptable, adaptable and business oriented approaches. The social enterprise targets the rural poor who are negatively impacted by natural resources degradation through the promotion of appropriate and sustainable technologies in the rural areas and in the informal settlement.
EFWES as a social enterprise has a wealth of experience in renewable energy solutions like:
<ul>
• Development of biogas technologies
• Design,Production, fabrication and installation of efficient clean cook stoves for households and institutions
• Solar lighting and heating systems
• Trainings, consultancy and awareness creation to the community
• Training of the skills to school leavers who don’t make it to higher level of learning and have nowhere else to go.
• Creation of jobs to the less fortunate and people living with disabilities
• Key advisor the community and other stakeholders in matters concerned with environmental and energy conservation through alternative technologies and energy audits.
What We Need &

By contributing towards the establishment and completion of this center, be sure you will create a full- time-job to a young person/woman/person living with disability who will come to be equipped with skills for self sustainability as well as improved livelihood to the community.

EFWES is seeking Short term funds to finish up most of the pending structures which are required as outlined below: Training hall(4500usd), administration office (2500usd), 20000lts water tanks(3000usd), drying storage house for clay products( 3500usd), purchase of solar panels(3240usd- panel sold per watt and we buy at 1usd.80ctsx1800watts ), a truck for ferrying materials like clay soil, sand, wood,(15000usd), A wind turbine(4500usd), Solar water heater and fittings(2200usd), solar batteries and other accompanying accessories(5500usd),solar fencing for security(4000usd), green house full kit-green house, solar pump and drip irrigation (7500usd), construction of a medium biogas plant( 4500usd), biogas equipments and appliances for demo(5000usd), Kitchen(1500usd), 2washroom blocks(1800usd), warehouse for displaying finished products( 2100usd) 3 staff houses( 7000usd). Hostels-20rooms with WIFI connection (10000usd). CCTV cameras (600usd) Labor costs and overheads (12000usd).  Total budget:  99940usd.
Funds distributed towards this center will go directly to finish up construction of the required structures and equipments for learning with both local and international students.

The community will also be in a position to come and be trained on the technologies that are beneficial to their farms and houses.  

The Impact
<h3><span style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif
column7: >A revolving fund will be created to give newly trained artisans/youth loans to start their own business based on the skills they learned at the resource center. As the new entrepreneurs pay back the loans, the money will be redistributed to new trainees so that the process can continue. Furthermore, the center will act as a market link between the new entrepreneurs and the center as products will be marketed through demos and displays at the center during field days that will be organized after every quarter of the year. With the linkages created so far by EFWES, market is guaranteed for the new entrepreneurs who will benefit from our training courses.

column1: <h3><span style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif
column7: >The center hopes to be sustainable after the initial funding as it will be making products of clean cook stoves and bricks for sale, get business contracts to do biogas to households after paying a visit to the site to see how a biogas does household chores like cooking, lighting, heating water, run a chuff-cutter machine for cutting straw for cows, solar lighting and heating. All these are businesses opportunities that will be available once the communities visit the center during and when we call for field days at the same venue. We strongly believe that the impact created in this center will trigger other resource centers in other counties to be started on the concept.

column1: <h3><span style=""font-size: 16px
column4:
>Be part of this noble campaign and contribute generously and improve the live of our young people and community as a whole as we establish this center fully.

Risks &

column1:
Through collaboration with relevant government officers like security police detail, we anticipate very minimal cases of insecurity as the government has initiated measures to curb with incidents of insecurity. The center is located within a radius of 500mts from a police post. The government has also put an emphasis on ‘nyumba kumi’ initiative (ten houses initiative) where residents have to know themselves and their neighbors.  

The land is currently challenged by poor infrastructure from the tarmac road but the government has assured it will be attended to as it’s budgeted in the coming financial year from June2016.

Other Ways You Can Help
column4: >Please email us at equaterfuelstove@yahoo.com to receive updates on news and the progress of our project. Thank you for your contribution!

","Short Summary

My name is Josphat Wahome Kariuki, Founder and Director of Equater Fuelwood Energy Saving(EFWES). EFWES is a social enterprise energy service provider which was started in January 1998. EFWES is unique in its kind in this region(Mt.Kenya and its environs), providing reliable products and sound services based on the philosophy of professional integrity, innovative and advocacy for sustainable use of natural resources. The services are offered through efficient, acceptable, adaptable and business oriented approaches. The social enterprise targets the rural poor who are negatively impacted by natural resources degradation through the promotion of appropriate and sustainable technologies in the rural areas and in the informal settlement.
EFWES as a social enterprise has a wealth of experience in renewable energy solutions like:
Development of biogas technologies
Design,Production, fabrication and installation of efficient clean cook stoves for households and institutions
Solar lighting and heating systems
Trainings, consultancy and awareness creation to the community
Training of the skills to school leavers who don’t make it to higher level of learning and have nowhere else to go.
Creation of jobs to the less fortunate and people living with disabilities
Key advisor the community and other stakeholders in matters concerned with environmental and energy conservation through alternative technologies and energy audits.
What We Need & What You Get

By contributing towards the establishment and completion of this center, be sure you will create a full- time-job to a young person/woman/person living with disability who will come to be equipped with skills for self sustainability as well as improved livelihood to the community.

EFWES is seeking Short term funds to finish up most of the pending structures which are required as outlined below: Training hall(4500usd), administration office (2500usd), 20000lts water tanks(3000usd), drying storage house for clay products( 3500usd), purchase of solar panels(3240usd- panel sold per watt and we buy at 1usd.80ctsx1800watts ), a truck for ferrying materials like clay soil, sand, wood,(15000usd), A wind turbine(4500usd), Solar water heater and fittings(2200usd), solar batteries and other accompanying accessories(5500usd),solar fencing for security(4000usd), green house full kit-green house, solar pump and drip irrigation (7500usd), construction of a medium biogas plant( 4500usd), biogas equipments and appliances for demo(5000usd), Kitchen(1500usd), 2washroom blocks(1800usd), warehouse for displaying finished products( 2100usd) 3 staff houses( 7000usd). Hostels-20rooms with WIFI connection (10000usd). CCTV cameras (600usd) Labor costs and overheads (12000usd).  Total budget:  99940usd.
Funds distributed towards this center will go directly to finish up construction of the required structures and equipments for learning with both local and international students.
The community will also be in a position to come and be trained on the technologies that are beneficial to their farms and houses.     The Impact

A revolving fund will be created to give newly trained artisans/youth loans to start their own business based on the skills they learned at the resource center. As the new entrepreneurs pay back the loans, the money will be redistributed to new trainees so that the process can continue. Furthermore, the center will act as a market link between the new entrepreneurs and the center as products will be marketed through demos and displays at the center during field days that will be organized after every quarter of the year. With the linkages created so far by EFWES, market is guaranteed for the new entrepreneurs who will benefit from our training courses.

The center hopes to be sustainable after the initial funding as it will be making products of clean cook stoves and bricks for sale, get business contracts to do biogas to households after paying a visit to the site to see how a biogas does household chores like cooking, lighting, heating water, run a chuff-cutter machine for cutting straw for cows, solar lighting and heating. All these are businesses opportunities that will be available once the communities visit the center during and when we call for field days at the same venue. We strongly believe that the impact created in this center will trigger other resource centers in other counties to be started on the concept.
Be part of this noble campaign and contribute generously and improve the live of our young people and community as a whole as we establish this center fully.   Risks & Challenges

Through collaboration with relevant government officers like security police detail, we anticipate very minimal cases of insecurity as the government has initiated measures to curb with incidents of insecurity. The center is located within a radius of 500mts from a police post. The government has also put an emphasis on ‘nyumba kumi’ initiative (ten houses initiative) where residents have to know themselves and their neighbors.  The land is currently challenged by poor infrastructure from the tarmac road but the government has assured it will be attended to as it’s budgeted in the coming financial year from June2016.   Other Ways You Can Help Please email us at equaterfuelstove@yahoo.com to receive updates on news and the progress of our project. Thank you for your contribution!

Locoal Charcoal

Hi my name is Petey!  I was born and raised in Austin, now living in paradise on the lower Colorado River.  Watching this city grow has made me aware of all the organic waste going to our landfills, so I have been diverting it to create premium products.  My growth has allowed me to work closely with the City of Austin and University of Texas to demonstrate how we can make Austin the first carbon neutral city in North America.
<ul>

• I started this mission after an evening under a 180 year Native Pecan Tree.  After asking her what her favorite band was, she replied the ""Almond"" Brothers and our relationship was established.  I give her special thanks for the origin, and for most of the inspiration, I added the perspiration.

• I have personally built a fleet of homemade retorts by diverting oil drums from the landfill, and have been producing daily for 8 months.  These retorts are unable to keep up with the demand and I need a commercial retort.  With a retort mounted on a trailer I can take it to waste locations and further reduce the carbon footprint coming from the development of Austin.

• This campaign is designed to be a value driven crowd sourcing where you believe enough in me and my products to pre-purchase, to then be fulfilled at a later date.  I will be working with a fulfillment company that will ship charcoal to fans across the nation.
• There is too much organic waste going into the landfills, and I need your help to finance a commercial retort to offset as much as I can.  This cannot be accomplished without your help.

• My lump is a premium hardwood charcoal that lights faster and burns hotter and cleaner for a premium grilling experience.  You don't need any chemicals to start it, and it burns at a much higher temperature to better sear your meats to maintain the moisture.

• My biochar is a premium hardwood charcoal that has numerous gardening benefits including moisture and nutrient retention and a habitat for beneficial bacteria.  One gram of biochar has the surface area of a tennis court, and helps plants grow bigger and healthier.
I need a larger retort to produce more charcoal.
• A commercial retort mounted on a trailer costs $20,000.  This retort would be able to produce hundreds of pounds of charcoal daily and divert over 2 tons of waste per week.
Rewards: (all will receive the shout out)
<ul>
•  1 pound of carbon stored in your name and donated to the non-profit Urban Patchwork to use in elementary school gardens. - $2
• 3 pounds of carbon stored in your name and donated to the non-profit Urban Patchwork to use in elementary school gardens. - $5
• Bag of lump charcoal and Locoal sticker - $10 + shipping
• Custom Locoal reusable tote bag, bag of Lump and sticker - $25 +shipping
• Tshirt and bag of lump and sticker - $50 +shipping

• Tour of the grounds with stories of failures and success.  Petey the Tour guide will share his property and show off Melissa, the native Pecan Tree where it all began.  Will include appetizers over Locoal, paired beverages and desserts - $200/pp
• Commercial Retort to your property and loaded up with a full batch of materials, (4) Locoal shirts, and a cubic yard of biochar delivered to you or donated to Urban Patchwork - $1000
The Impact
<ul>

• I have already offset thousands of pounds of organic waste from the landfill, and have developed relationships to provide a solution for dozens of dumpsters of organic materials to be diverted each week.
• Each bag of Lump charcoal diverts 4 pounds of waste from the landfill.
• Each Cubic yard of biochar diverts nearly a half ton of organic waste from the landfill.
• Biochar stores carbon in the soil for decades.   In addition to the benefits to the plants and water ways, carbon in a physical form will not be released into the air as a greenhouse gas.
• The Locoal mission:  Waste diversion, methane elimination and carbon sequestering while producing premium products.
<h3>Risks &amp

I was laid off last fall and I have put my blood, heart, sweat and savings into this business.  Developing a brand, filing a trademark, networking sales and waste channels all while crafting a premium product has reinforced my beliefs, but I need your help to make my dreams come true.
<ul>

• For the past 8 months I have been waking up with the drive of diverting waste.  Starting my morning chopping wood, eliminating greenhouse gases and producing charcoal, each ax swing inches closer to my goals of waste reduction and education of alternate waste solutions.  I believe in my charcoal so much I have been brushing my teeth with it.
• I have sold over 100 units without any negative feedback and great grilling results.  However, scaling to more markets will require larger production.
• A commercial retort can process 2 cubic yards of waste per day and create hundreds of units of lump charcoal, or equivalent of dozens of cubic feet of biochar.
• Locoal products will be sold across Central Texas and provide a superior solution for grilling, gardening and greening our communities.
• Locoal will plant 100 trees yearly to strive to be carbon negative.
Other Ways You Can Help
<ul>
• Do you grill, do you garden, do you want to save the world?  Know anyone that does?  Please tell them about my mission and how they can help.
• Please share across all your social media platforms. I will be adding videos explaining the process and products, quotes and inspiration from the trees, and fun tidbits and images from my day.

This is a huge opportunity to pre-purchase a premium product to help me see my dream through.  I'm not only the owner of Locoal Charcoal, I use my products for keeping my fridge fresh, grilling, cleaning water, growing better plants, drawing, and brushing my teeth.

","Locoal Charcoal

Hi my name is Petey!  I was born and raised in Austin, now living in paradise on the lower Colorado River.  Watching this city grow has made me aware of all the organic waste going to our landfills, so I have been diverting it to create premium products.  My growth has allowed me to work closely with the City of Austin and University of Texas to demonstrate how we can make Austin the first carbon neutral city in North America.

I started this mission after an evening under a 180 year Native Pecan Tree.  After asking her what her favorite band was, she replied the ""Almond"" Brothers and our relationship was established.  I give her special thanks for the origin, and for most of the inspiration, I added the perspiration.

I have personally built a fleet of homemade retorts by diverting oil drums from the landfill, and have been producing daily for 8 months.  These retorts are unable to keep up with the demand and I need a commercial retort.  With a retort mounted on a trailer I can take it to waste locations and further reduce the carbon footprint coming from the development of Austin.

This campaign is designed to be a value driven crowd sourcing where you believe enough in me and my products to pre-purchase, to then be fulfilled at a later date.  I will be working with a fulfillment company that will ship charcoal to fans across the nation.
There is too much organic waste going into the landfills, and I need your help to finance a commercial retort to offset as much as I can.  This cannot be accomplished without your help.

My lump is a premium hardwood charcoal that lights faster and burns hotter and cleaner for a premium grilling experience.  You don't need any chemicals to start it, and it burns at a much higher temperature to better sear your meats to maintain the moisture.

My biochar is a premium hardwood charcoal that has numerous gardening benefits including moisture and nutrient retention and a habitat for beneficial bacteria.  One gram of biochar has the surface area of a tennis court, and helps plants grow bigger and healthier.
I need a larger retort to produce more charcoal.
A commercial retort mounted on a trailer costs $20,000.  This retort would be able to produce hundreds of pounds of charcoal daily and divert over 2 tons of waste per week.
Rewards: (all will receive the shout out)
1 pound of carbon stored in your name and donated to the non-profit Urban Patchwork to use in elementary school gardens. - $2
3 pounds of carbon stored in your name and donated to the non-profit Urban Patchwork to use in elementary school gardens. - $5
Bag of lump charcoal and Locoal sticker - $10 + shipping
Custom Locoal reusable tote bag, bag of Lump and sticker - $25 +shipping
Tshirt and bag of lump and sticker - $50 +shipping

Tour of the grounds with stories of failures and success.  Petey the Tour guide will share his property and show off Melissa, the native Pecan Tree where it all began.  Will include appetizers over Locoal, paired beverages and desserts - $200/pp
Commercial Retort to your property and loaded up with a full batch of materials, (4) Locoal shirts, and a cubic yard of biochar delivered to you or donated to Urban Patchwork - $1000

I have already offset thousands of pounds of organic waste from the landfill, and have developed relationships to provide a solution for dozens of dumpsters of organic materials to be diverted each week.
Each bag of Lump charcoal diverts 4 pounds of waste from the landfill.
Each Cubic yard of biochar diverts nearly a half ton of organic waste from the landfill.
Biochar stores carbon in the soil for decades.   In addition to the benefits to the plants and water ways, carbon in a physical form will not be released into the air as a greenhouse gas.
The Locoal mission:  Waste diversion, methane elimination and carbon sequestering while producing premium products.

I was laid off last fall and I have put my blood, heart, sweat and savings into this business.  Developing a brand, filing a trademark, networking sales and waste channels all while crafting a premium product has reinforced my beliefs, but I need your help to make my dreams come true.

For the past 8 months I have been waking up with the drive of diverting waste.  Starting my morning chopping wood, eliminating greenhouse gases and producing charcoal, each ax swing inches closer to my goals of waste reduction and education of alternate waste solutions.  I believe in my charcoal so much I have been brushing my teeth with it.
I have sold over 100 units without any negative feedback and great grilling results.  However, scaling to more markets will require larger production.
A commercial retort can process 2 cubic yards of waste per day and create hundreds of units of lump charcoal, or equivalent of dozens of cubic feet of biochar.
Locoal products will be sold across Central Texas and provide a superior solution for grilling, gardening and greening our communities.

The “Quick Story”

Papelyco by Lifepack was formed to offer an alternative, sustainable solution to using disposable plates made from non-biodegradable foams and plastics that wind up in landfills, streams and oceans after use
column2:
these products are harmful to wildlife and the environment as they may never bio-degrade.

We offer an alternative that converts users of paper products into responsible consumers.

Hailing from Colombia and brought to St. Louis via Arch Grants by co-founders Claudia Isabel Barona (CMO) and Andres Benavides (CEO), Lifepack sells “packaging that generates life”.

Our sustainable, disposable, biodegradable paper products are made from pineapple crowns and corn husks—agricultural waste by-products—that reduce both the pollution from polymer plate use and greenhouse emissions. But our product is not just recyclable: Since the product is embedded with seeds, consumers can actually plant the packaging after use. This means a plate will find a second life as a plant or flower, providing the planet with more oxygen and, ultimately, more life. Or, if you wish not to plant it, you can simply discard it with your regular garbage where it will bio-degrade in the landfill in a matter of weeks.
column4:
>

Here is a quick summary of our campaign before we tell you more.

We are making these wonderfully biodegradable plates in Colombia which you need in the US. To get US going, we need US-based production. Help us get to our  goal so that we can bring our product to you. Read more about our story, our passion and our goals.

Our full time line and description of how we plan to use the money are detailed at the end of this page. We have plans that can utilize much beyond our target of.
column6:
'>Our Story:

The idea for the startup was based on some shocking statistics: In 2010, Colombia generated 27,500 tons of waste each day
column7:
the USA clocked in at 600,000 tons—with just 35% of the waste being recycled. In Colombia specifically, 4% of that came from disposable plates and cups, as well as plastic and styrofoam packaging. Meanwhile, packaging in the US comprises 30 percent of solid waste and takes between 500 and 1,000 years to decompose. The effects of all this waste on the environment, needless to say, are huge.

In 2010, our daughter was born and as we thought of her future and those of other children we decided to produce and introduce a new product that would contribute to sustaining the health of our planet and our children.
column8:
>

Our mission is to become a global producer of products that are 100% plantable, compostable and biodegradable. We want to empower consumers to make decisions that help protect and preserve our planet today and tomorrow by promoting a sense of social responsibility.

How it works?
column10:
showinfo=0"">

 

STEP 1 - Use the plate.

STEP 2 - Remove the biodegradable film covering the plate which is made from corn. This will allow the seeds to germinate more quickly from the plate.

STEP 3 - Plant the plate: Take your plantable paper and cover the soil in the prepared pot or in a garden with the paper. It's okay if the paper overlaps. Spread a 1/8 inch layer of soil over the plantable paper pieces and tamp down gently.

STEP 4 - Water during germination: After planting the paper, give it a good soak. You want the paper and the soil to be nicely damp but not swimming in water. During the first 10 days, keep the paper moist at all times. The water is necessary for germination.

STEP 5 - Care after germination:  Once sprouts appear, continue to keep the paper moist but be careful not to overwater. Once sturdy plants appear, water as needed.

STEP 6 - Enjoy the flowers: Once the flowers (or herbs or vegetables) start to blossom, enjoy them.

STEP 7 - The plate decomposes and a beautiful plant is created.

Our current products and accomplishments
column13:
>

Each plate you use means that:  

0.02% fewer trees are cut.

2.7 liters less wáter will be used in manufacturing.

500 grams of less solid waste would go to landfills.

4.8 Kwh will be saved in production

How do we do it?
column14:
>

1. We collect agricultural wastes such as corn husks or pineapple crowns depending on what is most commonly available in the region from local farmers. We never cut trees to produce our product.

2. We transform these natural fibers into an environmentally safe paper product that we then use to produce our final product. Our production process is clean and free of any chemical ingredients that can harm the environment. 

3. We produce the final product by employing heads of households that are single-women with children seeking a means of employment and providing them with an income opportunity. We also engage incarcerated women providing them with manufacturing experience and skills that are translatable to non-institutional work settings.

4. Our product is ready and available. Flowers are presently germinating from our plantable plates. In the near future we plan to develop and transfer this technology to industrial packaging applications in the food and beverage, pharmaceutical and consumer products industries.

Social Sustainability
column15:
>

Our social sustainability consists of:

• creating awareness and teaching consumers to be more environmentally conscious and responsible
column16: • providing work to people that need it in order to improve their own quality of life and their families
column18: • Working with farmers to reduce waste management costs
column19: and regional farmers to create our products
column20:
• By engaging our suppliers, employees and consumers we are helping their families as well.

Overall, the leadership team’s vision—and passion—values “sustainability of the natural environment
column21: of being responsible stewards of that environment
column22:
and of promoting social justice, equity and life skills training through entrepreneurship”.

Looking Forward

So far, Lifepack's vision of social and environmental impact has come to fruition: We have provided skills training to more than 190 women, created 20 direct jobs, trained 35 female inmates, brought revenue to more than 10 pineapple farmers and generated an average of $3,000 in additional income to single-mother households—a number that goes a long way in Colombia.

What are we going to do? 

With your help Indiegogo friends:

Papelyco wants to establish its production facility in St. Louis, Missouri and use corn husk and local seeds in its products. The Papelyco team also wants to reduce million tons of waste generated from manufacturing in the United States.

Papelyco also want to increase our production and sales, to introduce the plantable paper to use in a diverse packaging applications like food, beverages, health care, personal care, and much more industrial package applications. 

Papelyco will generate employment. 

Papelyco plans to launch its production facility in the new Saint Louis manufacturing incubator Brick City Makes (http://brickcitymakes.com) .

Who do we want to reach and help? 

 We want all public schools and communities to plant our products so that the products can transform into beautiful local gardens and that the people who plant our products can have healthy and organic foods in their homes.
column23:
>

The hundreds of thousands of flowers in our products will help in the pollination process of bees and butterflies like the Monarch Butterfly. Our products will help the Monarchs in their yearly migration and therefore will increase their populations. 

We want to create many jobs in the St. Louis area, especially for people with disabilities and for local war veterans.

A Mobile App to Follow the Process of Papelyco Plates!

All the world may know where the plants are that are grown from our products. 

Papelyco by Lifepack, has designed an app for phones that will be free to download. Our clients will be able to track from anywhere in the world where our plates are being planted and how they are growing by putting in their Zip Code. They can take pictures of the plants and interact with other users via social media. Also, experts will be able to track the pollination process of bees and butterflies. 

People Talking About Papelyco
column25:
showinfo=0"">

About Us

Papelyco by Lifepack is based out of Cali - Colombia and St. Louis, MO USA.
column27:
>

 Here you can know more about us:

https://www.stlmag.com/dining/colombian-couple-brings-eco-friendly-enterprise-to-st-louis/#.WIEfXXKpDyo.facebook

Follow us on http://papelyco.com/

Time Line
column32:
>

 

Risks and challenges

We have met a number of risks and challenges with our start-up but we have learned to overcome these by implementing simple yet effective solutions. We believe the greater risk is in having a grand idea that can make a difference in our health and that of the planet but not turning it into a reality. Papelyco is a reality. We have a tangible, proven product that is presently in the market.

Waste is building up in remote indigenous villages in the Brazilian Amazon forest, threatening the health of indigenous people and the environment they depend on. But with your support its possible to help one community transform itself into the first zero-waste village in the Amazon. 

Diferentes resíduos sólidos estão sendo acumulados em aldeias indígenas da Floresta Amazônica brasileira, ameaçando a saúde dos povos indígenas e o meio ambiente. Mas, com o seu apoio, é possível ajudar uma comunidade a se transformar na primeira aldeia lixo zero da Amazônia.

The problem

O problema

How far into the wilderness does garbage reach? Sadly, isolated places in the Brazilian Amazon already have waste problems. In remote areas, where there is no regular garbage pick-up or sewage treatment, many indigenous and local people burn their waste (i.e. plastic, glass, metals, rubber). But burning releases greenhouse gases (GHGs) into the atmosphere and can trigger forest fires during the dry season.

Até onde vai o lixo? Infelizmente, lugares isolados na Amazônia brasileira já têm problemas de lixo. Em áreas remotas, onde não há nenhum tipo de saneamento básico, muitas comunidades indígenas e tradicionais queimam seus resíduos (ex.: plástico, vidro, metais, borracha). Mas a queima desses materiais emite gases de efeito estufa (GEEs) na atmosfera e pode desencadear incêndios florestais durante a estação seca.

Who is affected? 

Quem é afetado?

The Yawanawá people live in the Indigenous Land of Rio Gregório (Gregory River), in the Brazilian state of Acre, Tarauacá Municipality. Around 700 Yawanawá people live in eight communities along the banks of the Gregory River. Contact with Western society 200 years ago completely altered their way of life and widespread deforestation has driven the local environment to its breaking point, also bringing new types of waste. This is threatening their wellbeing, affecting livelihoods and causing health problems. The Mutum community is very open to visitors from all over the world who come to learn about their traditional knowledge and to participate in their healing spiritual rituals. Unfortunately, they also bring with them a lot of waste, contaminating the community’s surroundings.

Os Yawanawá vivem na Terra Indígena do Rio Gregório, no estado do Acre, município de Tarauacá. Cerca de 700 indígenas Yawanawá vivem em oito comunidades ao longo das margens do Rio Gregório. O contato com a sociedade ocidental há 200 anos atrás alterou completamente o modo de vida dos Yawanawá e o desmatamento generalizado levou o ambiente local a seu ponto de ruptura, trazendo novos tipos de lixo. Isso está ameaçando o bem-estar dos Yawanawá, afetando seus meios de subsistência e causando problemas de saúde. A comunidade do Mutum é aberta para visitantes de todo o mundo que querem aprender sobre conhecimentos tradicionais e participar de rituais espirituais de cura. Infelizmente, eles trazem consigo muito lixo, contaminando o ambiente da comunidade.

 

Let’s help the Mutum community get to zero waste!

Vamos ajudar a comunidade do Mutum a se tornar lixo zero!

In February we went to Mutum village to learn more about how they managed their waste. One of the most worrying things we found was the amount of used batteries scattered in the forest and river. Why so many? The Yawanawá rely on hunting for subsistence, and each hunter uses six large batteries every night in their torches. Villagers are generally unaware of how toxic batteries are to both humans and nature. They can cause soil and water pollution and endanger wildlife. When thrown into the rivers they can bio-accumulate in fish, which reduces their numbers and makes them unfit for human consumption. Mutum village will be the pilot project of the community zero waste initiative, and we plan to integrate what we learn into all other Yawanawá villages. Since Mutum is located eight hours by boat from São Vicente village – where the nearest waste disposal facilities are – transportation is key. But first we need to collaborate with the villagers on a waste management plan that everyone can agree to.

Em Fevereiro nós fomos à aldeia do Mutum aprender mais sobre os resíduos. Uma das coisas mais preocupantes que encontramos foi a quantidade de baterias que são descartadas na floresta e no rio. Por que tantas? Os Yawanawá dependem da caça para a subsistência, e cada caçador usa seis baterias grandes por noite em suas lanternas. Os moradores da comunidade não têm conhecimento sobre as toxinas geradas pelas baterias para a saúde e para a natureza. Elas podem causar a poluição do solo e da água e pôr em perigo a vida selvagem. Quando jogadas nos rios podem bio-acumular nos peixes, o que os reduz em quantidade e os torna impróprios para o consumo humano. A aldeia do Mutum será o projeto piloto da iniciativa aldeia lixo zero, mas futuramente planejamos integrar todas as outras comunidades da tribo Yawanawá. Uma vez que a aldeia do Mutum está a oito horas de barco da vila de São Vicente - onde estão as instalações de eliminação de resíduos mais próximas - o transporte é essencial para tornar a aldeia lixo zero. Mas primeiro precisamos colaborar com os moradores da aldeia em um plano de gerenciamento de resíduos que todos possam participar.

Here’s what we will do:

O que vamos fazer:

- Work with families living in Mutum and with leaders from other Yawanawá communities to raise awareness about the dangers of disposing of waste in the forest

- Build local skills in how to reduce, reuse and recycle specific materials and how to compost organic waste

- Organize a community cleanup

- Purchase a motor boat to take solid wastes to São Vicente and fuel for 2 years

- Build a waste station in the Mutum community

- Supply 27 families with solar flashlights and reusable batteries that can be recharged throughout the day

- Give each household a set of containers for different types of waste (compost, recyclable, toxic, etc.) and offer training in how to sort them

- Set up a village composting system

- Put up zero waste signs throughout Mutum to inform visitors

- Build a waste station in the village of São Vicente

- Mediate with state agents of Tarauacá and Cruzeiro do Sul municipalities and the residents of São Vicente to better organize the disposal and recycling of solid waste.

 

- Trabalhar com as famílias que moram no Mutum e com líderes de outras comunidades Yawanawá para aumentar a conscientização sobre os perigos do descarte de resíduos na floresta

- Capacitar os moradores sobre como reduzir, reutilizar e reciclar resíduos sólidos e sobre a compostagem de resíduos orgânicos

- Organizar uma limpeza da aldeia

- Comprar um barco a motor para levar resíduos sólidos para São Vicente e combustível para 2 anos

- Construir uma estação de lixo na aldeia do Mutum

- Fornecer para as 27 famílias do Mutum lanternas solares e baterias reutilizáveis que podem ser recarregados ao longo do dia

- Dar a cada família um conjunto de latas para diferentes tipos de resíduos (composto, reciclável, tóxico, etc.) e prover as informações necessárias sobre como separá-los

- Instalar um sistema de compostagem na aldeia

- Colocar placas informativas de aldeia lixo zero no Mutum para informar os visitantes

- Construir uma estação de resíduos na aldeia de São Vicente

- Mediar com agentes do governo municipal de Tarauacá, os moradores de São Vicente e do governo municipal de Cruzeiro do Sul para melhor organizar a destinação e a reciclagem de resíduos sólidos.

Healing ourselves by healing our environment

Curando a nós mesmos pela cura do meio ambiente

The Yawanawá live in a part of the Amazon forest that is rich in biodiversity and home to myriad healing plants. Generations of living in close harmony with the land has given the Yawanawá an ancestral knowledge of its species. The World Health Organization estimates that 80% of the population of developing countries rely on traditional medicines, mostly plant drugs, for their primary health care needs. We hope you can help the Mutum village become the first zero waste community in the Amazon forest!

Os Yawanawá vivem em uma parte da floresta Amazônica que é rica em biodiversidade e abriga uma miríade de plantas curativas. Por muito tempo gerações viveram em perfeita harmonia com a terra, o que gerou aos Yawanawá um conhecimento ancestral das espécies que se encontram em suas áreas. A Organização Mundial da Saúde estima que 80% da população dos países em desenvolvimento dependem de medicamentos tradicionais, principalmente vegetais, para tratamentos primários de saúde. Esperamos que você possa ajudar a aldeia do Mutum a se tornar um lindo exemplo da iniciativa aldeia lixo zero!

Who we are? 

A equipe

We created Aldeia Lixo Zero because we’ve heard the call of the forest in connection with Nixiwaka Yawanawá - a young leadership in Mutum and a strong voice from the community. Together with Fernanda Gebara – social scientist with ten years of experience with local communities
column3:
and Roberto Herrera – director of photography, the project was born. Julia Yawanawá -  professor in Acre and the leader of the project in Mutum – will coordinate the local actions with Aizan Yawanawá (Guedes) - responsible for water and waste management in the community. This initiative was only possible because of collective intelligence and creative collaboration while Lia kept the call alive.

Criamos Aldeia Lixo Zero porque ouvimos o chamado da floresta em conexão com Nixiwaka Yawanawá - liderança jovem no Mutum e uma voz forte da comunidade. Juntamente com Fernanda Gebara - cientista social com dez anos de experiência com comunidades locais
column4: Lia Salmito - designer gráfico/editora de vídeo
column5:
e Roberto Herrera - diretor de fotografia, o projeto nasceu. Julia Yawanawá - professora no Acre e líder do projeto no Mutum - coordenará as ações locais com Aizan Yawanawá (Guedes) - responsável pela gestão de água e resíduos na aldeia. Esta iniciativa só foi possível devido à inteligência coletiva e à colaboração criativa, enquanto Lia manteve a chama acesa.

","Waste is building up in remote indigenous villages in the Brazilian Amazon forest, threatening the health of indigenous people and the environment they depend on. But with your support its possible to help one community transform itself into the first zero-waste village in the Amazon. Diferentes resíduos sólidos estão sendo acumulados em aldeias indígenas da Floresta Amazônica brasileira, ameaçando a saúde dos povos indígenas e o meio ambiente. Mas, com o seu apoio, é possível ajudar uma comunidade a se transformar na primeira aldeia lixo zero da Amazônia.The problemO problemaHow far into the wilderness does garbage reach? Sadly, isolated places in the Brazilian Amazon already have waste problems. In remote areas, where there is no regular garbage pick-up or sewage treatment, many indigenous and local people burn their waste (i.e. plastic, glass, metals, rubber). But burning releases greenhouse gases (GHGs) into the atmosphere and can trigger forest fires during the dry season.Até onde vai o lixo? Infelizmente, lugares isolados na Amazônia brasileira já têm problemas de lixo. Em áreas remotas, onde não há nenhum tipo de saneamento básico, muitas comunidades indígenas e tradicionais queimam seus resíduos (ex.: plástico, vidro, metais, borracha). Mas a queima desses materiais emite gases de efeito estufa (GEEs) na atmosfera e pode desencadear incêndios florestais durante a estação seca.Who is affected? Quem é afetado?The Yawanawá people live in the Indigenous Land of Rio Gregório (Gregory River), in the Brazilian state of Acre, Tarauacá Municipality. Around 700 Yawanawá people live in eight communities along the banks of the Gregory River. Contact with Western society 200 years ago completely altered their way of life and widespread deforestation has driven the local environment to its breaking point, also bringing new types of waste. This is threatening their wellbeing, affecting livelihoods and causing health problems. The Mutum community is very open to visitors from all over the world who come to learn about their traditional knowledge and to participate in their healing spiritual rituals. Unfortunately, they also bring with them a lot of waste, contaminating the community’s surroundings.Os Yawanawá vivem na Terra Indígena do Rio Gregório, no estado do Acre, município de Tarauacá. Cerca de 700 indígenas Yawanawá vivem em oito comunidades ao longo das margens do Rio Gregório. O contato com a sociedade ocidental há 200 anos atrás alterou completamente o modo de vida dos Yawanawá e o desmatamento generalizado levou o ambiente local a seu ponto de ruptura, trazendo novos tipos de lixo. Isso está ameaçando o bem-estar dos Yawanawá, afetando seus meios de subsistência e causando problemas de saúde. A comunidade do Mutum é aberta para visitantes de todo o mundo que querem aprender sobre conhecimentos tradicionais e participar de rituais espirituais de cura. Infelizmente, eles trazem consigo muito lixo, contaminando o ambiente da comunidade. Let’s help the Mutum community get to zero waste!Vamos ajudar a comunidade do Mutum a se tornar lixo zero!In February we went to Mutum village to learn more about how they managed their waste. One of the most worrying things we found was the amount of used batteries scattered in the forest and river. Why so many? The Yawanawá rely on hunting for subsistence, and each hunter uses six large batteries every night in their torches. Villagers are generally unaware of how toxic batteries are to both humans and nature. They can cause soil and water pollution and endanger wildlife. When thrown into the rivers they can bio-accumulate in fish, which reduces their numbers and makes them unfit for human consumption. Mutum village will be the pilot project of the community zero waste initiative, and we plan to integrate what we learn into all other Yawanawá villages. Since Mutum is located eight hours by boat from São Vicente village – where the nearest waste disposal facilities are – transportation is key. But first we need to collaborate with the villagers on a waste management plan that everyone can agree to.Em Fevereiro nós fomos à aldeia do Mutum aprender mais sobre os resíduos. Uma das coisas mais preocupantes que encontramos foi a quantidade de baterias que são descartadas na floresta e no rio. Por que tantas? Os Yawanawá dependem da caça para a subsistência, e cada caçador usa seis baterias grandes por noite em suas lanternas. Os moradores da comunidade não têm conhecimento sobre as toxinas geradas pelas baterias para a saúde e para a natureza. Elas podem causar a poluição do solo e da água e pôr em perigo a vida selvagem. Quando jogadas nos rios podem bio-acumular nos peixes, o que os reduz em quantidade e os torna impróprios para o consumo humano. A aldeia do Mutum será o projeto piloto da iniciativa aldeia lixo zero, mas futuramente planejamos integrar todas as outras comunidades da tribo Yawanawá. Uma vez que a aldeia do Mutum está a oito horas de barco da vila de São Vicente - onde estão as instalações de eliminação de resíduos mais próximas - o transporte é essencial para tornar a aldeia lixo zero. Mas primeiro precisamos colaborar com os moradores da aldeia em um plano de gerenciamento de resíduos que todos possam participar.Here’s what we will do:O que vamos fazer:- Work with families living This election, make climate action issue #1!

""We need to act as though our house is on fire. Because it is.""

- Greta Thunberg

Artists for Real Climate Action (ARCA) is  non-partisan group of concerned artists who've come together to create dozens of messages that show Canadians how to put pressure on their leaders to make climate action real.  Over 100 Canadian artists have donated their time and resources to create a funny, inspiring, campaign of videos to sound the alarm over our climate crisis. All we need now is your help getting them out there! 

This election is critical
column2:
our next government is in a position to determine the future of our planet. We need to make sure every single Canadian politician knows that in order to win, they need a real plan for climate action. 

Getting the message out isn’t free!

We need to buy media space, so we can preach beyond the choir and speak to people we might not normally have access to. That’s where your donations will go-- to get the message on billboards, movie screens, and social media news feeds across the country.

And while Elections Canada is threatening to make climate change a partisan issue, we’re a third party advertiser, and can say what needs to be said. 

Please help us sound the alarm, and get real action underway. 

PS: We are collaborating with Tree Canada and all donations over $50 dollars will get a tree planted in your name!

P.P.S. To see 3rd Party Advertiser reporting requirements for Elections Canada, please go to: https://www.elections.ca/content.aspx?section=p... 

Follow us on social media:

Instagram

Facebook

Twitter

 

 

--

we need all of you

naya bali veda vastu eco art retreat in bali
thank you so much dear
norbert stitz
for your warm-hearted donation my dream becomes now the necessary drive.
Dream in your heart and leave it up to mother nature, now it becomes an unstoppable flow .
Help us to make it happen!
Let's show that it's possible to live in accordance with the laws of nature,
without polluting our environment or harming any form of life.

Only through positive collective action can we transform our world.
we can make a big difference.
it`s a not-for-profit project
the property will be jointly owned by the community
we will support other green projects with our income.
i`m just the catalyst.
Ask for more information
tunelart@gmail.com
Thank you with all my love

ludwig
Sustainability Project
We live in a time of outrageous change,
creating more awareness about our own lives, all living creatures and the
resources of our planet earth.
naya-bali-eco-art-retreat will be
built on a total scale of 108 by 108 meters (11664) sqm close to ubud in bali, according
to the veda vastu principles of
„working and living in harmony
with the laws of nature“ www.vastu.net,
dl.globalgoodnews.com/pdf/Sthapatya-Veda.pdf
We will host workshops for arts,
retreats to expose the inherent human ressources.
Money, in general is based on
trust and that’s shaken at the moment.
We invite you to be part of our
beautiful permaculture project, and to become an owner of one or more
bungalows,
or support us : spreading our project amongst your friends or donate.
Donor will be carved on a wooden sculpture at naya.
To make it happen, any amount is helpful.
We will be making use of the
latest environmental technology to be self-sustainable
production via wind -
water generators, solarvoltaic cells. groundwater, biological sewage, hot
water production via solar panels, biological regenerated and
ozonized swimming-pool water organic gardening electro - scooters and
cars.
MAP
The land is located on a
wide-open, flat space 300 meters above
sea-level
and measures 108m by 108m
There will be a circular path and
river encircling the complex
which allows one easy access to
each building.
We will establish the following workshop
studios in the technical building: Carpentry, Pottery, Tailoring, music recording.
The 4 corners of the land will be
used primarily for organic gardening.
The hedge-like fence surrounding
the entire project will be constructed
with berry bushes and fruit trees.
Ozonized pool
the self-contained river
will regenerate the pool water, which will then be
ozonized and directed back to the
pool via a 2m high waterfall.
Background
Ludwig Lehner, the
founder of nayaretreats Istanbul has 10 years experience in building and managing
such eco-retreats please visit :
www.tripadvisor.com/naya büyükada until november 2014
www.tripadvisor.com/naya bali tropical hideaway from october 2012
until April 2013
naya comes from
sanskrit and means „the truth“
The Villas
14 Joglo Villas with about 100 sqm
like the one in the picture 50sqm living room,
50 sqm bedroom and bathroom Approximately, 100 sqm garden
with a little atelier, access to the central pool.
6 river side villas price per one 155.000 €

8 pool side villas price per one 169.000 €

all Villas will be
completely furnished.
The villas will be designed
according to their positions in the following colours:
Earth Element in the south/west: earth tones
Fire Element in the east/south
: sunshine yellow and red tones
Water Element in the east/north: blue tones
Air Element in the west/north: pastel tones
The element of space is
represented in the center of the complex
in the form of an island. This island will also
serve as our concert stage.
Each owner of a Villa has the right
to use his villa 1 month per year after arrangement with naya,
whilst for the remaining 11 months
naya will rent them out for their customers and/or retreats.
Once naya has been fully operational
for one year, owners will then be entitled to 20% of the rental income for one year
from
the 2nd year on 30%
and from the 4th year on 40% ongoing.
the interest rate will be between 4 % and 7 % per year on a calculated
utilisation of 50%.
The total time for construction
will be approximately 3 years.
Naya will take care of all
running costs, taxes and maintenance expenses.
Contact me please for more information
Ludwig Lehner
www.nayaretreats.com
tunelart@gmail.com

In June 2012 the High Park Fire outside of Fort Collins, Colorado burned through 87,000 acres and 259 homes. My cabin, that I built in the 1970's, was burned to the ground.  

This project is about restoration and transformation.  Restoring a home and property that was destroyed in a wildfire and transforming it into a space that will have a positive impact on the community for years to come. Turning a disaster into a project that is environmentally and people friendly and demonstrating a new way to approach building in the 21st century.

It took one and a half years after the fire for the land to finally begin to revegetate and for it to not look like a wasteland. But lo and behold, it is beautiful again with more wildflowers than ever before.

Josh and Melissa Rabe who had just started their Loveland Hemp Company approached me with the concept of rebuilding the cabin using the burned timber (most of the trees just had the bark burned) to build a post and beam structure with industrial hemp walls and floor.

We began construction on this proof of concept cabin in April of 2014  with the focus on sustainable building practices and materials, health of the home's occupants, environmental footprint as well as the usage of indigenous materials. By using the trees from the land and industrial hemp our goals are to build a non-toxic, fire resistant, energy efficient, low maintenance cabin.
column9:
>In doing so we hope to showcase Industrial hemp as a viable and sustainable alternative to traditional construction materials. We believe that this experience will help to further develop a market for Industrial Hemp and other Eco-friendly products.

Working in conjunction with Josh and Melissa, this one of a kind 1,500 square foot cabin will be one of only a few in the country and one of the first in Colorado. We hope to complete the cabin in May 2015.  We are excited about hemp's building properties and Eco-friendliness.

Currently the building is 80% complete.  In order to complete the project and move on with the vision for the cabin we need additional funds.  The funds will be used to complete the installation of hempcrete in the walls and floor, install windows, stucco the inside and out, finish the inside walls, and finish grading the site.

column1: Once the cabin is completed we will be holding community workshops including music and songwriting camps and industrial hemp building workshops starting in June, 2015.  The cabin will also be used as an artist retreat as a place to inspire and create music, art, and prose.

I invite you to be part of a historical project that ushers in a new era of building materials and practices that are sustainable, healthy and Eco-friendly.  Thank you for considering being involved in this endeavor.
<span style=""background-color: initial

P.S.   Please view the music video ""Burning Down the Canyon"" that I wrote after one of the worst wildfires in Colorado history.  It tells the story of the fire.  It has images of the former cabin and the burned property before revegetation.  The video will give you a feeling for the emotion of the wildfire and the emotion that is driving this project. It is truly a ""Phoenix"" project.  Rebirth from the ashes.
You will notice that a number of the perks are music related.  Acoustic Ranch Recording Studio (owned and engineered by Larry Lewis) ties in closely with the vision of the Hemp House as an artist retreat.  It is located 25 minutes from the Hemp House and provides the environment and equipment to produce professional recordings. (www.acousticranch.com)

See Mark Benjamin, Structural Engineer, talk about the advantages of building with hemp and about the Hemp House.  
Credits to Josh Rabe for the intro video production and Dave Hill for the background music (Dave Hill website).

column2:
>An Update

I have closed this campaign, clearly I am nowhere near the target but this is not an issue. I would like to thank those that have donated, and thanks for allowing me to keep the donation as help towards my move etc.

Why am I closing the campaign? Because I have been fortunate enough to be offered a long term project of setting up and running a farmstead along similar lines to how I am living now. My animals are included in this amazing opportunity.

So, I'll just close with a thank you for visiting the page, and bid my farewell!

==========================================================

column1: Noras is a small farm on the edge of a forest in deepest, darkest Latvia. I’ve lived here for a little under a year, the deal is, In exchange for rent, I provide on site security and maintenance. At the end of last year the owners approached me to see if I would be interested in buying the place. Of course I said yes. I love it here.

Last week, however, they told me that there is someone else interested and I have until the end of March to find the asking price (10,000 euro - there are some additional costs I need to cover as well, Indiegogo charges, exchange rate, local tax etc. This is why I am having to ask for $15,000). If not, I would have to vacate the property, which, in effect, would make me homeless.

I live a simple, moneyless life, and have done so since 2008. 

I eat what I grow, raise or forage in the surrounding forest, 

I also barter for other things such as coffee and flour.

I use old fashioned farming techniques and use no machinery on the farm, my ‘workers’ are my animals, the goats help with land and forest clearance and the chickens help me clean out the barn.

My plan for this year has been to open my place up to people who want to come and experience the lifestyle, maybe before taking the plunge themselves or simply to take a break from the stresses of city life. 

While visitors are here, I can share a variety of skills and crafts that I have learned since living this ‘alternative’ life.

In keeping with my moneyless existence I won’t be asking for payment from my visitors, instead they can offer as much (or as little) as they want or can afford. Preferably in the form of barter or by helping out around the place.

As with all farms you can’t simply plan for the weeks or months ahead and I want to start planting a variety of crops that will take 3 or more years to become established, in addition there are seven ponds around the farm that need maintenance and the forest needs managing as well.

So, at the moment I am facing something of a crisis.

If I can’t raise the funds to buy the place then I have serious problems. I will be homeless and, with all the animals as well. This is why I am appealing to you to please help with raising the purchase amount. 

My final goal is that when I finally leave this place, either on my passing or if I am too old to continue, I will gift the farm to a person or family that will continue the dream of Noras: 

to learn and share knowledge, 

to have minimal impact on the planet and

to simply enjoy life.

For the first time in a long time I need to have a bank account. The account will be a business account and it will be registered as an agricultural research station, where I compare old fashioned techniques to modern practices. 

And, although the local currency is the Euro I must ask for the donations to be in dollars because of international restrictions imposed by PayPal (one of the methods for receiving funds). Because of this, I will be using Indiegogo to deal with funding payments.

One final thing. This coming year I will be offering various crafts and individual items for sale (all donors will be advised as and when they become available, and by way of a thank you there will be substantial discounts).
If you have any questions or, want to know more about my moneyless life, please feel free to ask, I’m more than happy to answer.

I’ll just end by saying thanks for taking time to read about this project.

Mike

Hi!

About us

We are
a team of dedicated and ambitious young high school students from Slovenia. <span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >We are the first high school team from Slovenia to compete at iGEM and are very excited to face the challenges synthetic biology poses.
column9:
> The team is composed of eight high school students attending seven different secondary educational institutions across Slovenia. 

What is iGEM?

iGEM is a prominent worldwide competition in synthetic biology with long tradition. Students from all over the world work on their projects during the summer and meet at the iGEM giant jamboree in Massachusetts, Boston in the fall to present their projects.

Learn more: http://igem.org/Competition

column1:
The project

Biofuels? Who needs that?
Since the beginning of the industrial revolution we have spent more than 135 billion tons of oil in the last 150
years. What’s more, our demands for oil are still only increasing. Oil is of tremendous
importance in our everyday life, but it is difficult to obtain. The
multinationals that assume the risks and responsibilities associated with that
also gain the ability to monopolize it, making it unequally accessible.
More
importantly, oil is a non-renewable source and some projections say we only
have enough for the next 40 years! Even so, we use it for almost everything:
for transport, energy production, in pharmacy, for building artificial
materials and much more... Life as we know it today is simply not possible
without oil. Therefore it is crucial to find an ecologically friendly,
self-sustainable and globally accessible alternative for obtaining fuels. Here is where our idea comes in!
Why biobutanol?
Because of its chemical structure, butanol is very
similar to conventional fuels and consequently a perfect replacement for them.
It can be used in eternal combustion engines without modifying them. This means
we could use it to fuel our cars with no modifications required!

How can we obtain biobutanol?

Turns out we can
produce it from organic waste! In anaerobic conditions we can transform organic
waste to biogas (to be used as energy source on its own) and butanoic acid. We
can then take the butanoic acid and transform it into biobutanol with the use of
microorganisms. The method is completely safe to people and to the environment as
the microorganisms are contained and carefully controlled. <b style=""background-color: initial
polluting the Earth we produce a useful, easy and accessible method of
obtaining biofuel from garbage!

How can you help us?

We need you to help us turn our dream of making the world better into a reality! We will use the donations to fund our research and present the project at the MIT giant jamboree in September. Each and every donation is appreciated. Thank you.

Check out our new Kickstarter campaign
Follow Ben and his team on their world-record swimming attempt from Tokyo to San Francisco to better understand and protect our oceans.
A swim from Tokyo to San Francisco to better understand and protect our oceans
This is Ben’s challenge: swimming 8 hours a day for 6 months to cross the 5,500 miles from Tokyo to San Francisco.

Ben has always swum for a reason, it’s his way of expression. In 1998 he became the first man to swim across the Atlantic Ocean without a kickboard, as a tribute to his father and to support cancer research.

This time Ben will jump in the water in the name of science and protecting our oceans. The Longest Swim will be the first citizen science expedition of its kind, as Ben and his crew will collect valuable data on the ocean and human body for 8 research projects directed by 13 scientific institutions, including NASA and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.

PATT Foundation is planting trees in Thailand’s biggest and
oldest national park Khao Yai already for 10 years. But this year is special -
it is the first time that the local Sap Tai community is experiencing water
scarcity. There is not enough water even to sufficiently water the
essential food crops.
This shows that
climate is changing in Khao Yai, but we won’t just watch it happen. We would
like to help the local community and plant 100 native trees with
them on the Zero Emissions Day to raise awareness for climate change and
ensure sufficient water supply for the next year. We will also hire local Thai
staff to provide 2-3 years of aftercare for the planted trees to ensure their
successful growth.
Sap Tai will:
<ul>
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
wild elephants living in the area
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
watershed and prevent water scarcity
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
income for the Sap Tai community
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
and mitigate climate change
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
Local Sap Tai
community doesn’t have enough resources to finance their watershed protection project
that is why we ask for your help. Help us protect the water sources of
the Sap Tai community with this sustainable forest restoration, and at the same
time you’ll also offset your carbon footprint.
<h3><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
Trees are mitigating drought
Not only are trees an
effective means for absorbing and storing the carbon you emit, trees also help
us to adapt to a changing climate and combat drought by:
<ul>
<li>
<b style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
rainfall patterns
and maintain rain cycle, their leaves act as interceptors, catching falling
rain, which then evaporates causing rain precipitation - a process known as
evapo-transpiration. Trees can evapo-transpirate twice as much as agricultural
crops and about twice as much as water body surfaces.
<li>
<b style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
river flows
seasons and high rainfall events, thereby minimizing risks related to water
scarcity and floods.
<li>
<b style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
water evaporation
shading the ground
<li>
<b style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
water saturation into groundwater
column5: >thus reducing water runoff. Tree roots and leaf litter create

column1: soil conditions that promote the infiltration of rainwater into the soil. This
helps to replenish the groundwater supply and maintain streamflow during dry
periods.
<li>
<b style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
underground water reserves
- strategic planting of trees can increase level of groundwater as numerous
studies have already shown.
Furthermore, only native tree species will be used in Sap Tai community as
they have low rate of transpiration and high rate of groundwater recharge in this environment.
<blockquote>“As the climate
changes, severe droughts are likely to become more common, and we shouldn’t
miss the opportunities to influence the hydrologic cycle in a beneficial way
using trees” says David Ellison   from the Institute for World Economics.
100 trees for Zero
Emissions Day – what is ZeDay?
ZeDay takes place
every year on the 21<sup>st</sup> September and it is a global 24 hour moratorium
on the use of fossil fuels. ZeDay guidelines are simple:
<ul>
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
gas or coal.
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
eliminate) your use of electricity generated by fossil fuels.
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
harm’s way: All essential and emergency services operate normally.
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
fun, enjoy the day – make a small green change in someone’s life!
The majority of
greenhouse gases come from burning fossil fuels to produce energy. This means
that the use of fossil fuels is the prime driver of climate change. So let’s
stop their use for a day as reducing our emissions is a vital part of
combating climate change!
But we still want or
need to use at least some modern commodities in our lives - these emissions we can
simply offset with TREES!
Trees are green
machines that act as natural
filters of our air. Through the process of photosynthesis they absorb carbon
dioxide (a key contributor to global warming) from the atmosphere and store it
in their trunk, branches, leaves, roots, soil and foliage, while releasing
oxygen back out.
<b>As each tree can store
around 800 kilograms of carbon dioxide over 40 years of its life, a person
needs to plant on average only 10 trees per year to offset his or her carbon
footprint.
trees with this project and at the same time also help Sap Tai community fight
their drought?
<div>
What will we do with the funding?
Sap Tai
Sap Tai community lays
on the very edge of the Khao Yai National park, which is Thailand’s oldest
(since 1962) and largest national park (2,168 km<sup>2</sup>). The park is a
UNESCO world heritage site and is an important tropical forest ecosystem. It
provides home for over 3000 species of plants, 250 birds and 67 mammals – some
of them critically endangered. But the mountainous Khao Yai also has a dark
side – it has a history of poaching, land encroachment, illegal logging and
unsustainable agricultural practices. All this had a detrimental effect on primary
forest, which also led to soil erosion, landslides, flooding and droughts.
There is an urgent need for forest restoration, conservation and education to reverse
the current trend of habitat degradation.
Local people in Sap
Tai community are experiencing the effects of this degradation (especially
drought), and therefore decided to make a change and protect the existing
forests while also create new ones. This will not only provide them with
sustainable livelihoods, but will also present a healthy habitat for the wild
elephants and other wildlife living in this area. But in order to achieve this,
they need your help.
<h4><b>Tree planting
methodology
PATT Foundation will
help the Sap Tai community to create a healthy forest ecosystem. We will <b>restore
the forest, not just reforest! This means that we will re-establish the
entire forest ecosystems as similar as possible to the original forest
ecosystem which was present before the deforestation occurred.
PATT
Foundation works closely with the Forestry Research &amp
FORRU, which has undertaken ground-breaking research on the best methods to
restore native forests in Thailand. As such we follow their framework species
method of forest restoration - this involves the planting of 20-30 indigenous
tree species specially selected for their ability to rapidly shade out weeds
and attract seed-dispersing wildlife. Birds and mammals, attracted to the
plots, bring with them the seeds of many other forest trees and thus help to
re-establish a species-rich forest tree community similar to that of the
original forest.
PATT
will provide tree seedlings from our own tree nursery in Khao Yai, which serves
as an environmental education facility and also provides employment to Sap Tai people - it hires 3 full
time and up to 20 casual local Thai staff to undertake various aspects of our
reforestation work. Beside tree planting and nursery activities they will also do
the aftercare of the newly planted trees in this project for another 2-3 years
to assure their successful growth.
Rewards
Meeting our goal and
planting 100 trees will ensure sufficient water supply for the Sap Tai
community in the years to come! We need <b>£5 to plant one tree and to provide 2-3
years of aftercare. So in order to plant a forest of 100 trees that will impact
groundwater levels, we need your help to reach a goal of £500.
In return for your
generous support we prepared a really nice green rewards on the right:
<ul>
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
you’ll receive an electronic certificate and a photo of your tree with your name
card next to it.
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >For 10 planted trees you will receive, in addition to the above perks, a digital download of the Climb for Climate Action documentary as a thank you for your efforts to tackle climate change and offset your carbon footprint this year.

column1: <li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
take the local Sap Tai school on a one day environmental educational workshop
to ensure green future for the community. As a thank you for your generous
support you’ll receive all the photos from that environmental day, with many
including your name card.
<div>
Why PATT Foundation?
PATT Foundation i
charity and a Thailand Foundation operating throughout the Southeast Asia
region already since 2005. We initiate, develop and manage large-scale reforestation projects
countering deforestation and climate change. We strive to save the planet by
planting trees, educating communities on sustainable forestry and children on
the environment.
We are hoping to
reach our goal of planting 1 million trees by our 10-year anniversary in
November 2015. Our current total stands at 893,995!
<h3>Risks &amp
If
we don’t hit the £500 target by September 21, we will still plant as many trees
as our campaign will raise donations. Even just one planted tree in Sap Tai
community will help protect water sources, although this might not prevent the
drought next year.
PATT Foundation has already 10 years of experience in forest restoration projects
around Thailand, so we feel confident enough to successfully help Sap Tai
community. We aim to restore forests, not just reforest them, which results in
high success rate of our projects. We pick only native tree species already
present in the area and grow them in our own nursery in Khao Yai which gives
employment to the local community. As we also provide aftercare for the planted
trees our trees really grow unlike in many other projects, where baby trees die
in the field due to neglect and poor conditions within months after planting. Collaboration with the local community also ensures that the trees will be valued
for many more years to come.
Other Ways You Can Help
Can you help us get the word out about the 100 TREES FOR 0

EMISSIONS DAY campaign? 

Visit www.pattfoundation.org to find out more
