The Golden Dorado
Dorado (Salminus brasiliensis) is
an iconic and charismatic fish species in neotropical rivers of Brazil,
Paraguay, Uruguay, Bolivia, and northern Argentina. Both sport and commercial
fishers value Dorado for their sustenance, vigor, beauty, and challenge. ­­Dorado
provides economic support for communities in northern Argentina and throughout South
America. Currently the species is facing severe pressure and declining
populations due to overharvest harvest, habitat degradation, and poorly understood ecology, including movement patterns.
Little is known about Dorado movements and
response to disturbance (Agostinho
et al. 2008, Hahn et al 2011). The Salta region of Argentina is
limited in management resources and faces high social and economic stakes under
poor management of this species. A well-managed Dorado fishery could
potentially provide long-term income to the region. We will investigate the impacts of catch-and-release (C&amp
column2: R) by measuring blood physiology and post-release activity patterns. This work will add to the development of best practices for the C&amp

column1: of Dorado, plus provide insights into their movement ecology.
Our objective is to assess the impacts of recreational fishing, local
stakeholder practices, and habitat conditions on Dorado. Catch-and-release impacts (fight time, air exposure, angling
method) will be assessed for correlation with physiological biomarkers (blood
lactate, blood glucose, blood pH). Additionally, after tagging fish with radio
tags and subsequent mobile tracking, we will quantify immediate post-release
behavior along with longer-term habitat selection, movement patterns, and home
ranges. Data obtained from this study will be used to develop proactive conservation
and management strategies for Dorado populations in the region. In addition the
project will build capacity in the region for local guide and stakeholder
involvement in continuing research.
The research being conducted is guided by a team from the University of Massachusetts Amherst Department of Environmental Conservation.
A team of ecologists will be working in the field, on the Rio Juramento to complete of the objectives you've seen listed.
As the first study of its kind the iconic Golden Dorado the findings and work here stands to be key info that ensures the Dorado will be thriving for years to come.
What we need and what you'll get in exchange.
Conservation fieldwork and research face significant funding challenges, especially in remote and rural regions under significant environmental pressure of risk and loss.
Funds are needed to cover expenses for: research equipment, travel costs, local guides and assistance, housing, fuel, boats, permitting, and vehicles.

We are building partnerships with local and international partners: companies, universities, and organizations to garner sustainable funding. But with the exploratory and unknown nature of this work your start-up funds are what get this project off the ground.
Local guides have been incredibly supportive with their guidance and assistance to develop the research goals and initiatives.

Any funding that exceeds the need of research expenses is being endowed to the Fundacion Rio Juramento,  a non-profit organization devoted to protecting the Rio Juramento and surrounding watersheds that act as habitat for the Golden Dorado.
Specific objectives and tasks
1) Effects of catch and release on Dorado.
We will use a rapid assessment approach to quantify
the physical and physiological impacts of catch and release recreational
angling specific to Dorado (<i>importance of
species specific practices see: Cooke and Suski 2005).  We will measure hooking injury, physiological
stress response, reflex impairment, and short-term mortality related to
commonly used capture and handling methods for Dorado in the Salta region.  This type of information does not currently
exist for Dorado. Information obtained though this research will
lead to development of best practices that can be adopted by anglers, guides,
and local management to increase post-release survivorship and provide valuable
resources for managers and anglers in the development of management plans
(Arlinghaus et al. 2007).
2) Post-release behavior and movements of Dorado
We
will use <span>radio telemetry to measure the
behavioral response and short-term movement patters of Dorado following
catch-and-release angling.<span>  Gentle and
aggressive handling treatments will be established based on the outcome of the
rapid assessment, and fish from these treatments will be manually tracked
post-release.  Correlative relationships
will be possible between handling treatments and factors such as rates of
movement, habitat selection, and dispersal from site of capture and
release.  Measures of flow
regulation, habitat conditions, riparian area loss, sedimentation, and
irrigation diversion will also be classified and relationships will be noted.
This element of our project will fill information gaps on post-release delayed
mortality, and spatial ecology of Dorado in a region that is coming under
greater pressures for development.
3) Socio-ecological survey development and deployment
We
will conduct <span>surveys of local
stakeholders, including farmers, anglers, guides, and visiting
tourists/fishers to classify conflict and perceptions related to Dorado and the
Rio Juramento.  Closed and
semi-structured interviews along with surveys will be used to identify issues
constraining stewardship and management such as commercial harvest, recreational
fisheries, and land-use. This element of the study will help put the outcomes
of the first two projects into a broader perspective as they relate to
conservation and management options for Dorado in the Salta region.  Addressing the social/fisheries conflicts
will be critical for pro-active anticipatory rather than reactionary
management.
Risks and challenges

Rivers, the fish the live in them, and the watersheds that feed in to them are incredibly dynamic systems that have supported communities for millennia. River protection and health is important to everyone that depends on them. Yet society is always facing additional pressure from social inequality and economic needs. We hope that the findings from our work will be key information in environmental decision making around Golden Dorado that is considerate of all challenges facing the communities supported by these fish and the rivers they inhabit.
--

So what comes out of this work?

- When you fund any project you want to know
column2:
what is your money doing? And what greater impact will have?
So lets be clear about what comes out of this work...

1. Greater knowledge of the Dorado and the community it supports which better informs sustainable management and conservation

2. A chance to perform a rapid assessment of a poorly understood fish facing growing angling pressure in an emerging region. Which will provide lessons and guidelines to be applied to other fish facing similar pressures in remote and striking regions around the world in fast growing emerging regions.

3. Research for peer-reviewed scientific publications that will be published and shared with colleagues and the public that can better inform their own management, research, and conservation initiatives of catch-and-release fisheries in similar and varying locales.

4. A presentation will be developed for an international fisheries management symposium on the tools, lessons learned, and objectives achieved in this project. World leaders in recreational angling will be able to learn from, and provide comment on the initiative you supported. 

5. Social media, photo, video, and audio coverage of the efforts will be continuously shared during and after the project. This will be an opportunity to share the stories of local guides and community members with you, the interested and engaged angling community. Blog posts, instagram photos, and videos will be published on angling websites, organization website, and with company partners: Costa Sunglasses, Patagonia Fly Fishing, The Drake, and The Cleanest Line.
--

column1: Other ways you can support?
While any funds you can provide are appreciated immensely and used wisely, your support is valued just as much.
- Please raise awareness with your family, friends, and community about the value of Dorado fishery and conservation research.
- Communicate with local decision makers about the importance of developing comprehensive and adaptive management action around recreational fisheries
- Share your photos, videos, and other media about your responsible and conservation minded recreational fishing.

Which will provide lessons and guidelines to be applied to other fish facing similar pressures in remote and striking regions around the world in fast growing emerging regions.3. Research for peer-reviewed scientific publications that will be published and shared with colleagues and the public that can better inform their own management, research, and conservation initiatives of catch-and-release fisheries in similar and varying locales. 4. A presentation will be developed for an international fisheries management symposium on the tools, lessons learned, and objectives achieved in this project. World leaders in recreational angling will be able to learn from, and provide comment on the initiative you supported.  5. Social media, photo, video, and audio coverage of the efforts will be continuously shared during and after the project. This will be an opportunity to share the stories of local guides and community members with you, the interested and engaged angling community. Blog posts, instagram photos, and videos will be published on angling websites, organization website, and with company partners: Costa Sunglasses, Patagonia Fly Fishing, The Drake, and The Cleanest Line. --

column1: Other ways you can support?
While any funds you can provide are appreciated immensely and used wisely, your support is valued just as much.
- Please raise awareness with your family, friends, and community about the value of Dorado fishery and conservation research.
- Communicate with local decision makers about the importance of developing comprehensive and adaptive management action around recreational fisheries
- Share your photos, videos, and other media about your responsible and conservation minded recreational fishing.

<h3 style=""text-align: center
Sandra, Ana, Adrian and Alberto are the Co-Founders of Creando Redes, a group of entrepreneur scientist working on
the <b>dissemination, promotion and implementation of Ecological
Restoration.
<blockquote style=""text-align: center
Ecological Restoration assists the recovery of
ecosystems that have been degraded, destroyed or transformed by human activities or natural events. Applying this
scientific knowledge, we can regenerate landscapes and ecosystem services such
as water purification, soil carbon sequestration, soil fertility or
biodiversity.
Ecological restoration integrates society as a fundamental part of
the recovery process.  Ecological Restoration <b>involves local
people in the development of the project and delivers direct
benefits for local communities such as better environmental
conditions, new economic resources and social
engagement with the territory.
<h3 style=""text-align: center
We want to bring Ecological Restoration to society, and provide new approaches and tools for decision
making in environmental aspects.
We are aware that education is the most
efficient tool to enhance the development of societies and to promote more
sustainable models which allow us to combine our lifestyles with the
maintenance of natural resources.
With this in mind, we organize Ecological Restoration training courses, and we create participation and experience
exchange fora, as the Foro de Restauración Ecológica: Creando Redes.

collaborate with the most reputed experts in ecological restoration in the
world, who participate in the elaboration of our courses and in our fora
offering their knowledge and experience.

","(For English version, see below)
¿Quienes somos?
Creando Redes somos Sandra, Ana, Adrián y Alberto, un grupo de científicos emprendedores que hemos trabajamos en la difusión y el fomento de la aplicación de la Restauración Ecológica.
Equipo de Creando Redes

La Restauración Ecológica recupera los ecosistemas que han sido degradados o destruidos por las actividades humanas  o eventos naturales extremos, aplicando el conocimiento científico y que tiene como objetivo regenerar paisajes y servicios ecosistémicos tales como la depuración de agua, el almacén de carbono, la fertilidad del suelo o la biodiversidad.

La Restauración ecológica integra a la sociedad como una parte fundamental del proceso: incorpora la visión de todos los individuos en el diseño de las soluciones para los espacios que se desean restaurar, implica a la población local en el desarrollo de proyectos y orienta los beneficios a las comunidades locales, desarrollando la economía y la cohesión social de la zona.
¿Qué hacemos?
El propósito es simple: queremos hacer llegar la Restauraión Ecológica a la sociedad, y aportar nuevos criterios y herramientas para la toma de decisiones en materia de medioambiente.
En Creando Redes somos conscientes de que la
educación es el arma más eficiente para favorecer el desarrollo de las
sociedades y promover modelos más sostenibles, que permitan compatibilizar
nuestros modos de vida con el mantenimiento de los recursos naturales.
Por ello organizamos cursos de Restauración Ecológica en modo presencial y online y creamos entornos de  participación e intercambio de experiencias
entre todos los agentes sociales como el Foro de Restauración Ecológica: Creando Redes.
Nuestras áreas de actividad
¿Cómo lo hacemos?
Generar un cambio global sólo es posible si trabajamos en RED. Por eso, en Creando Redes, colaboramos con los mejores
expertos en Restauración Ecológica del mundo,  que participan en el desarrollo de nuestros
cursos y en el foro aportando todo su conocimiento, que nosotros haremos
llegar  a aquél que más lo necesita!!
Red internacional de colaboradores
¿Qué
necesitamos?
Cambiar el mundo comunicando persona a persona no es una tarea fácil, así que para impulsar
que la Restauración Ecológica llegue a todo el mundo, necesitamos una plataforma web donde poder colgar y dar difusión a
nuestros cursos, y lanzar el primero de ellos que haremos que llegue al otro lado del charco!!
En la campaña necesitamos 12.400 € que emplearemos en:
Plataforma online
Diseño de plataforma web y dominios
Total: 3.600 €
Desarrollo del curso online
Desarrollo de contenidos por expertos en Restauración Ecológica
Grabar y editar los vídeos específicos de los temas (será 100% interactivo).
Total: 6.200€
Marketing y comunicación, que implica:
Publicidad en redes sociales para dar mayor difusión a nuestro proyecto.
Microeventos de promoción
Total: 2.600€
Programa curso online
¿Qué
obtienes?
Si nos ayudas, harás

posible el lanzamiento de nuestro primer curso online y habrás participado en el desarrollo de la primera empresa de Restauración Ecológica en España. Ya es mucho, ¿no crees? Aun así, queremos obsequiarte con estos packs de regalos, según la cantidad que aportes al proyecto:
Colaborador (a partir de 5 €):
Carta manuscrita de agradecimiento + mención en la web en una pestaña de colaboradores.
Colaborador premium (a partir de 10 €):
Carta manuscrita de agradecimiento + mención en la web en una pestaña de colaboradores + link a tu web/blog personal durante un año.
Nos conocemos? (a partir de 20 €):

Recibirás todas las recompensas del colaborador premium, y además, tendrás acceso a una píldora formativa online de una hora de duración en la que te contaremos el proyecto Creando Redes y una breve introducción a la Restauración Ecológica!
Colaborador 2.0 (a partir de 40 €):
Recibirás todas las recompensas del colaborador premium, y además, te envíamos a casa un USB (4 gB) para que lleves el proyecto Creando Redes allá donde vayas!
Quiero aprender! (a partir de 150 €):

Recibirás todas las recompensas del colaborador premium, y además, tendrás acceso gratuito al primer curso online de restauración ecológica! (El curso tendrá un coste de inscripción de 400€, pero es la recompensa por ayudarnos a hacerlo posible). Si tienes alguna duda sobre esta recompensa, no dudes en planteárnosla en info@creandoredes.es

¡Pero no todo acaba aquí! ¡Puedes hacer mucho por Creando Redes si compartes la campaña! Ayúdanos a difundir el proyecto en Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Linkedin, ¡en el bar tomando unas cañas! Te estaremos enormemente agradecidos si nos ayudas a difundir la campaña y el proyecto. Y por supuesto, esperamos que te unas a la comunidad. Para nosotros, eres lo más valioso. ¡Súmate al cambio!
Si conseguimos el reto, te esperamos en la inauguración de la web en Noviembre de 2015. ¡Ayúdanos a hacerlo posible!
Siguenos en:
Facebook    Twitter    Instagram    Youtube    Web

Creando Redes team
Ecological Restoration assists the recovery of
ecosystems that have been degraded, destroyed or transformed by human activities or natural events. Applying this
scientific knowledge, we can regenerate landscapes and ecosystem services such

WHO WE ARE
Paris Lavidis, Gabriello Lewis, Amelia Krinke, and Boubacar Diallo
are the four members of <b>Quartet: This
Side Up.  We are four students
dedicated to performing new music, and premiering works by living composers.
WHAT WE WANT TO DO
We have been invited by Climate Central, an organization of
leading scientists and journalists researching and reporting the facts about
our changing climate and its impact on the American public, to perform as part
of the activities connected to the <b>2015
United Nations Climate Change Conference, in Paris, France in early
December 2015.
will perform a piece by composer
Rolnick,
column2: > which we premiered on June 22, 2015 in New York City at the

column1: Tribeca New Music Festival, called
amplified string quartet, live electronics, and video by R.Luke Dubois,
the cumulative effects of carbon emissions as the jumping off point for a
compelling two-movement musical work that lasts approximately 15 minutes.
Climate Central has arranged for two performances of Oceans
Eat Cities, both at La Maison des Océans, which is operated by the Prince Albert Foundation.
December 4th - A Friday night performance will be open
to the public, and may include additional string quartet repertoire, along with
talks given by Climate Central’s <b>Dr
Benjamin Strauss and by Dr Anny
Cazenave, a pre-eminent French scientist, sea level expert and member of
the <i>Intergovernmental Panel on Climate
Change.
December 6th - A Sunday afternoon performance will be
by invitation only, mostly to scientists and delegates of the U.N. conference,

and will form part of a larger talk on the subject of climate change.

WE HAVE ADDED TWO MORE PERFORMANCES to our schedule

December 3rd - We have been invited to perform for both students and their parents at an international school in Paris.

December 7th - a house concert at
RAISE
Please contribute to our travel
costs to perform Oceans Eat Cities in Paris.
Costs included airfares,
accommodation, and living expenses for the 4 members of the quartet, our
composer and our music director as well as audio equipment rental for the
performances in Paris.
Neil Rolnick
What can I
say about something as concrete and complex as climate change? This is the
question I started with when I sat down to compose Oceans Eat Cities. My
first step in finding an answer was to approach Dr Benjamin Strauss at Climate Central to see if his research
group might be able to help me understand something about the topic that might
lend itself to a musical manifestation.
Ben gave me
a series of data spreadsheets that projected the impact of rising sea level on
cities worldwide, both in terms of numbers of people living on threatened land and
the percentages of total city populations that they represent.  There were different projections for each
coastal city, based on our effectiveness at limiting carbon emissions.  The various greenhouse gas concentration
trajectories are expressed in terms of Representative Concentration Pathways
(RCP).  On this scale, RCP 8.5 represents
a scenario in which we just keep doing what we are doing now.  That is, we don’t do very much to limit
pollution.  In this case, we lock in
dramatically higher sea levels between now and the year 2100 with a trajectory
that increases into the future.  An RCP
2.6 scenario represents the result of maximum aggressive efforts to control
greenhouse gas emissions, starting now and continuing into the future.  In this scenario, there’s a certain amount of
“locked in” damage, but by the middle of the 21st Century, things level out and
we stop locking in additional sea level rise.
There is still some damage but it is limited.
Since what I
wanted to represent was the relative way that the heart of a city would be
displaced by rising seas I took a musical theme and repeated it, while
subtracting the percentage of notes that was the equivalent to the percentage
of the population of the city on land that would be affected by sea level rise.
The first movement uses data from the
RCP 8.5 scenario from Shanghai (China), Mumbai (India), Bangkok (Thailand) and
Osaka (Japan).  The second movement uses
data from the RCP 2.6 scenario from Sidarjo (Malaysia), Tianjin (China) and
Miami (USA).
The
video track for Oceans Eat Cities is by video artist R. Luke DuBois, using the same data sets and applying them to map
imageswith overlays provided by the Climate
Central from their Surging Seas research.
(www.sealevel.climatecentral.org)
QUARTET
Quartet: This Side Up (Q:TSU) is one of the most dynamic and creative
young string quartets in New York City, comprised of four very talented young
people with a passionate commitment to the music of their own time. Ranging in
age from 11 to 15, they have already performed over two dozen world premieres, and
have twice appeared with the <b>Kronos
Quartet in concert.
Quartet: This Side Up is part of Kaufman Center’s Face the Music, NYC’s
cutting edge new music ensemble for teens.
The quartet is mentored by the <b>Kronos
Quartet and is coached by Ari
Streisfeld from the JACK Quartet.
This is a wonderful
opportunity for the Quartet to break new ground by bringing new voices to a
current issue. It will also be the group’s first occasion for significant
exposure on an international level.
Please help us get to Paris
and contribute to the dialogue about climate change.
FURTHER
INFORMATION ABOUT THE TEAM
Our composer: www.neilrolnick.com
Our video artist: www.lukedubois.com
Our music school: www.kaufmanmusiccenter.org
Our climate experts:
www.climatecentral.org
Location for our public concert in Paris: http://www.institut-ocean.org
","WHO WE ARE
Paris Lavidis, Gabriello Lewis, Amelia Krinke, and Boubacar Diallo
are the four members of Quartet: This
Side Up.  We are four students
dedicated to performing new music, and premiering works by living composers.
WHAT WE WANT TO DO
We have been invited by Climate Central, an organization of
leading scientists and journalists researching and reporting the facts about
our changing climate and its impact on the American public, to perform as part
of the activities connected to the 2015
United Nations Climate Change Conference, in Paris, France in early
December 2015.Our Quartet
will perform a piece by composer Neil
Rolnick, which we premiered on June 22, 2015 in New York City at the
Tribeca New Music Festival, called Oceans Eat Cities. Combining
amplified string quartet, live electronics, and video by R.Luke Dubois, Oceans Eat Cities uses data about
the cumulative effects of carbon emissions as the jumping off point for a
compelling two-movement musical work that lasts approximately 15 minutes.
Climate Central has arranged for two performances of Oceans
Eat Cities, both at La Maison des Océans, which is operated by the Prince Albert Foundation.
December 4th - A Friday night performance will be open
to the public, and may include additional string quartet repertoire, along with
talks given by Climate Central’s Dr
Benjamin Strauss and by Dr Anny
Cazenave, a pre-eminent French scientist, sea level expert and member of
the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate
Change.
December 6th - A Sunday afternoon performance will be
by invitation only, mostly to scientists and delegates of the U.N. conference,

and will form part of a larger talk on the subject of climate change. WE HAVE ADDED TWO MORE PERFORMANCES to our scheduleDecember 3rd - We have been invited to perform for both students and their parents at an international school in Paris.December 7th - a house concert at Atelier de la Main d'OrHOW MUCH WE NEED TO
RAISE
Please contribute to our travel
costs to perform Oceans Eat Cities in Paris.
Costs included airfares,
accommodation, and living expenses for the 4 members of the quartet, our
composer and our music director as well as audio equipment rental for the
performances in Paris.ABOUT OCEANS EAT CITIES – from the composer
Neil Rolnick
What can I
say about something as concrete and complex as climate change? This is the
question I started with when I sat down to compose Oceans Eat Cities. My
first step in finding an answer was to approach Dr Benjamin Strauss at Climate Central to see if his research
group might be able to help me understand something about the topic that might
lend itself to a musical manifestation.
Ben gave me
a series of data spreadsheets that projected the impact of rising sea level on
cities worldwide, both in terms of numbers of people living on threatened land and
the percentages of total city populations that they represent.  There were different projections for each
coastal city, based on our effectiveness at limiting carbon emissions.  The various greenhouse gas concentration
trajectories are expressed in terms of Representative Concentration Pathways
(RCP).  On this scale, RCP 8.5 represents
a scenario in which we just keep doing what we are doing now.  That is, we don’t do very much to limit
pollution.  In this case, we lock in
dramatically higher sea levels between now and the year 2100 with a trajectory
that increases into the future.  An RCP
2.6 scenario represents the result of maximum aggressive efforts to control
greenhouse gas emissions, starting now and continuing into the future.  In this scenario, there’s a certain amount of
“locked in” damage, but by the middle of the 21st Century, things level out and
we stop locking in additional sea level rise.
There is still some damage but it is limited.
Since what I
wanted to represent was the relative way that the heart of a city would be
displaced by rising seas I took a musical theme and repeated it, while
subtracting the percentage of notes that was the equivalent to the percentage
of the population of the city on land that would be affected by sea level rise.
The first movement uses data from the
RCP 8.5 scenario from Shanghai (China), Mumbai (India), Bangkok (Thailand) and
Osaka (Japan).  The second movement uses
data from the RCP 2.6 scenario from Sidarjo (Malaysia), Tianjin (China) and
Miami (USA).
The
video track for Oceans Eat Cities is by video artist R. Luke DuBois, using the same data sets and applying them to map
imageswith overlays provided by the Climate
Central from their Surging Seas research.
(www.sealevel.climatecentral.org)MORE ABOUT OUR
QUARTET
Quartet: This Side Up (Q:TSU) is one of the most dynamic and creative
young string quartets in New York City, comprised of four very talented young
people with a passionate commitment to the music of their own time. Ranging in
age from 11 to 15, they have already performed over two dozen world premieres, and
have twice appeared with the Kronos
Quartet in concert.
Quartet: This Side Up is part of Kaufman Center’s Face the Music, NYC’s
cutting edge new music ensemble for teens.
The quartet is mentored by the Kronos
Quartet and is coached by Ari
Streisfeld from the JACK Quartet.
This is a wonderful
opportunity for the Quartet to break new ground by bringing new voices to a
current issue. It will also be the group’s first occasion for significant
exposure on an international level.
Please help us get to Paris
and contribute to the dialogue about climate change.
FURTHER
INFORMATION ABOUT THE TEAM
Our composer: www.neilrolnick.com
Our video artist: www.lukedubois.com
Our music school: www.kaufmanmusiccenter.org
Our climate experts:
www.climatecentral.org
Location for our public concert in Paris: http://www.institut-ocean.org",3.0,0,"1 Campaign

For a Greener Tomorrow, Together!
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >What would happen if a multitude of voices, voices like yours, started to demand a greener tomorrow? Sure, the popular voice is pro-environment. But are corporate leaders and policy makers really paying attention or doing enough? There is a ton you can do in your daily life and community. But we need change on a global level. We need a multitude of voices rising together to be heard. We need all of our individual opinions and goals to be joined together to create a real force. We need you. Join the movement to make this app a reality. Every euro counts.

column1: Altogether GREEN!
Why we want your help?

GreenAdvisor is seeking funds and support to contribute to the development and the testing of the platform. With each additional $3,000 we will be able to pilot the platform in additional cities. Presently the team is investigating the following 5 cities for the testing phase: New York, San Francisco, London, Berlin or Budapest.
With GreenAdvisor, users will be able to:
<ul>
• Find and patronize businesses and organizations which act in an environmentally responsible way.
• Instantly locate any business or organization that has already been rated, either good or bad.
• Rate the green performance of businesses and organizations to pressure and incentivize them to act greener.
• Hold businesses and organizations accountable if they fail to live up to their green potential.

By mobilizing large numbers of people to “vote with their feet and wallets”, GreenAdvisor will reshape the way consumers can influence businesses to act greener. GreenAdvisor seeks to democratize the green movement in much the same way that TripAdvisor has democratized the travel industry. Hence the name.
GreenAdvisor will position consumers to rate businesses according to the following types of indicators:
Other ways you can help GreenAdvisor
If you can't donate you can still contribute to get GreenAdvisor out there. Help us spread the voice of this revolutionary app and join the team that wants to save the planet.
You can share the campaign via Twitter, Facebook, GooglePlus, or any other network, and tell your friends about it.
About us
GreenAdvisor is being built by GREENWILL — a non-profit, environmental initiative with presence in more than 100 countries.
Michele Orzan
Michele Orzan is a former Italian entrepreneur with an eclectic past that blended business, political science &
column2: economics. His love for sustainability led him to found GREENWILL, the worldwide nonprofit movement for a green globe. He is the president of EuCham - European Chamber and the head of the Advisory Board of JEUNE - Young Entrepreneurs Organization of the European Union, besides being involved in the NGO, nonprofit and social business world. Realizing that individuals were not having enough power in rewarding or sanctioning organizations, with his eco-social mindset Michele designed GreenAdvisor, envisioning critical competition between eco-friendly companies :)

column1: Tom Norring

Tom Nørring is the Danish Ambassador to Hungary. Prior, he served as the Danish Ambassador to Greece, where he initiated the Green Embassy movement which was adopted by embassies of Denmark worldwide. He is a passionate supporter of environmental causes, sits on the GREENWILL Board, and helps GreenAdvisor with its knowledge of environmental impact strategy of nordic countries in general and especially with his country's known green approach, acknowledged worldwide: creating a green and sustainable society is one of the key goals for Denmark.
Kenty Richardson

Kenty Richardson is the Director for International Relations and Strategic Development at the Regional Environmental Center - www.rec.org - an international organization established in 1990 by the United States, the European Commission and Hungary, now with the governments of 30 countries as members. Prior, he led the Department in charge of the environment within the Catalan Government for more than 15 years. He was founder and chair of Natura Foundation (now AccioNatura) working in the field of biodiversity and corporate social responsibility. He is on the GREENWILL Board and serves as an environmental advisor to GreenAdvisor.
Tiberius Soltesz

Tiberius Soltesz grew up in Sweden where he studied Political Science and has a Master’s degree in Economics. After working as a trade commissioner for The Swedish Trade Council he joined Kinnarps, Europe's biggest supplier of office furniture. He helped start 3 foreign subsidiaries of Kinnarps and is now the country manager of Kinnarps Austria, Hungary, Slovenia and Croatia. Tiberius, a key member of the GREENWILL Board, is strongly committed to develop green sustainable practices in the business world.
Scott Abrams

Scott is an American writer, consultant and entrepreneur. He is an expert in strategic planning, communications and business development. Scott currently works as a consultant to international organizations, is a published author and director of GREENWILL.
An international team
More information
1. We can rate what we see, but how do we know what’s happening behind the scenes?

There is almost always something that can be reviewed (e.g. the use of LED lights, climate control, recycling facilities, the presence of a Green Policy, etc.). Sometimes consumers will be armed with a lot of ‘evidence’, and other times less so. Employees can also anonymously report back using the platform with an insider’s perspective.
2. Can any business or organization be rated?

Yes. Regardless of whether it wants to be rated or not. We also hope that more and more responsible businesses will suggest that their clients rate them, showing their commitment for a healthier world.
3. Will GreenAdvisor be free?
Absolutely. 100% free, nonprofit and socially-driven.
4. Can users upload attachments / pictures to support their review?
Of course.
5. Let's say I have a company and I want to be more competitive in my sector, couldn’t I just give my competition bad reviews all day long?
No. To prevent cases like this, we will introduce algorithms and safety measures preventing abuses and reducing malicious activities.
6. ...but let’s say I once rated a specific business negatively, however, they recently made a lot of changes and are now much greener. Will I be able to rate them a second time?
Yes, this is possible. Our system will only prevent mass reviews.
7. Will GreenAdvisor be connected to other social media sites?
Sure, users will have the option to instantly share their reviews via Facebook, Twitter and other online platforms.
8. Can I use the application offline?
You will be able to use most features of the application even when you are offline. However, the reviews or any other modification you make will go online when you are connected to the internet.
9. Will users be able to interact, e.g. ask questions, provide comments and suggestions, with the location owners/management?
Yes.
10. I am a business owner, can I introduce my own business to be rated?
Yes. You can create a profile for your company, but you will not be able to review your own enterprise.
11. I just went to my favourite business. I would like to help them to be greener. Will I be able to share some tips with them on GreenAdvisor so that they can improve themselves?
Definitely! In fact, this is one of the best features: businesses will be able to see your suggestions and use them.

OUR PRIMARY CAMPAIGN MISSION:  HELP US REPLENISH OUR BEES ON AUSTIN AREA ORGANIC FARMS!


@SPRINGDALE FARM
Help Austin Honey
Company fully recover from recent flooding events at Bernhardt Farm in Elgin, TX, as well as, unexplained large winter losses the last several months on all of our bee farm locations.
We have lost a total of 28 beehives during three separate flood events

during 2015 in May, June, and October.  Additionally, our apiaries have been decimated over this winter by an unknown calamity--we suspect colony collapse disorder.  We have lost an additional 33 hives over the winter--an unsustainable loss.  This is a total of 61 hives lost.  As a small artisan company,
this is a combined devastating loss since May of 2015.  We need to rebuild our apiaries and purchase
high-quality and gentle nucleus colonies of bees now for 2016.
You can help
us by adopting a beehive, thus providing a direct economic contribution to our
operation now.  This direct contribution will go to purchasing new colonies
of bees now and helping us offset the high costs of getting bees built up to
pollinate crops.  Our bees reside on
local organic farms that are doing an outstanding job of producing wholesome
food for our local community in the Austin, TX area, as well as, contributing
to greater ecological diversity and a healthier environment.
Our bees
reside year-round on the following farms:

column3: '>2.  Green Gate Farms (east Austin and Utley location)

column1: Farm (east Austin)

column3: '>4.  Tecolote Farm (east Austin and Utley location)
'>Our bees perform a vital pollination service thus helping our local

column1: producers have higher yields more consistently.  WE DO NOT CHARGE FOR THIS ORGANIC FOOD POLLINATION SERVICE, and it is a WIN-WIN-WIN for the farms, us, and YOU.  Our bees
thrive on the local farms and produce an excellent crop of raw wildflower honey
and beeswax, which we offer to the Austin area community through farmer's

markets and local stores.  You can also support our farmer partners through their various CSA (community supported agriculture programs) and directly at some area farmer's markets as well where they sell their fruits, produce, herbs, and cut flowers.

column3: '>OUR SECONDARY CAMPAIGN MISSION:  PLACE AND MANAGE BEES THAT YOU OWN ON YOUR PROPERTY TO POLLINATE AND MAKE HONEY!

column1: Born out of YOUR demand to have us place bees on your property to pollinate your garden and landscape and also add to the health of the surrounding ecological environment, we are now offering this new service.  You will find in the ""perk"" detail a 2 and 6 hive option for 2016.  YOU INDEFINITELY OWN THE BEES and we manage them through 2016 and you get ALL THE HONEY AND BEESWAX harvested.  We will also teach you using all of our equipment through 2016.  This is another WIN-WIN-WIN, for you and your family, for your property, and for the overall environment around your property.  You may even qualify for an agricultural tax exemption for your property
column2: check with your county tax office, as well as, your tax adviser, as this interpretation of state law routinely varies by county.

column1: Our version of the ""complete hive"" that we are offering to place on your property is exactly what we use and it is the following Langstroth version of beehive, all brand new equipment.  We can paint it standard flat white to keep the bees cool or you can paint it however you would like.
1.  A screened bottom board for pest control and ventilation enhancement
2.  2 ""Deep"" hive bodies for the bees to pack with brood, their honey, and pollen.
3.  A seasonally affixed ""anti-robbing"" and ""anti-rodent"" front hive entrance guard (to be used from October to March).

4.  A 1 gallon frame feeder to feed the bees sugar water as necessary throughout the year when there is no natural nectar coming into the hive and they are almost out of their stored honey (typically about 100 lbs. storage maximum).
5.  A queen excluder to ensure your healthy gentle-strain queen from Northern California stays in her bottom two boxes laying up to 3,000 eggs per day and not in your honey harvest boxes up top.

column3: '>6.  2 ""Illinois"" medium honey ""super"" boxes to store up to 60 lbs. of honey that we help you harvest once full.
'>7.  A ventilated inner and ""telescoping"" outer cover to protect the bees from the elements.
'>8.  A large paver brick to place on top of the outer cover to keep the cover from flying away during a thunderstorm.
'>9.  A custom designed and made hive stand to keep 2 hives properly elevated and ventilated and minimize pests.

'>10.  We deliver the aforementioned equipment with a full strength colony of honeybees ready to make honey with a strong gentle-strain queen from Northern California in May of 2016.  We use queens from the fertile central valley of Northern California because ALL queens that we have worked with in the past from Texas are aggressive or slightly aggressive and either Africanized or Hybrid-Africanized and constantly swarm out and abscond and do not make much honey.  They also take all the fun out of working with/owning/enjoying honey bees because they are ALWAYS focused on attacking you and then you have to almost burn them with too much smoke to try and calm them down!  We have learned better after now 6 years of having bees in Texas and trying it all.  As manager of your bees, at all times we will ensure the bees remain full strength all year through 2016 despite the climate and in a gentle ""ready-to-pollinate and make-honey"" state.
'>11.  YOU get to work with us as detailed in the ""perks"" section and we teach you one-on-one as you are our student and we individualize the instruction for you at a mutually beneficial time.

'>12.  We harvest all the honey and beeswax as often as possible during the summer INSIDE YOUR HOME WITH YOU, AND YOU KEEP ALL HONEY AND BEESWAX.  We provide you with a bottling bucket with special bottling spigot and as many 5 gallon buckets as necessary to store your harvested honey and beeswax.  We will schedule your honey harvest with you several weeks in advance.  You can make it a honey harvesting party!

column1: We are open to traveling outside of a 45 mile radius from Austin, TX.  Please contact us via email for a custom quote, austinhoneyco@gmail.com.  Thank you!

column7: '>.  Thank you for your support!

thrive on the local farms and produce an excellent crop of raw wildflower honey
and beeswax, which we offer to the Austin area community through farmer's

markets and local stores.  You can also support our farmer partners through their various CSA (community supported agriculture programs) and directly at some area farmer's markets as well where they sell their fruits, produce, herbs, and cut flowers.

Hello my name is Gerard and I'm an urban beekeeper.  


About seven years ago I was living in the Niles neighborhood in Fremont.  I decided to raise bees with the intention of improving the viability of my vegetable garden as well as increase the yield of an avocado tree on the property that wasn't doing to well.  

That year was fabulous.  The avocado tree bore lots of fruit.  The heirloom tomatoes, squash, melons, cucumbers, rainbow chard.everything in the entire garden was exploding with abundance.  I couldn't believe that such a small plot could produce so much food.  The yields were so high that I resorted to knocking on doors around the neighborhood giving food away.

That one hive became two, then three,  I was unabashedly splitting hives, and mixing them up, putting bees from one hive into another, and another.  Soon I had installed numerous colonies between the cities of Fremont, Oakland, Alameda, Richmond, and the Sierra foothills.  I even taught the scary looking old timers that belonged to a ""motorcycle club"" how to raise bees.  Those bees eventually made it as far as Seattle Washington.  

My approach was also an organic one.  In contrast to my methods,  The commercial beekeeping industry were losing colonies to collapse.  In an effort to protect their livelihood they used interventions that I considered desperate measures.  There were was an insecticide for controlling Varroa mites, antibiotics for a fungus called nosema, terramycin for foulbrood, and paradich-lorobenzene, a known carcinogen for wax moths,  They were even putting things in the hive called oxalic acid. if you look on the labels of many of these things they will say toxic to humans!  Some members of the local beekeeping club began to eventually use these methods.  I was as if the pharmaceutical companies were coming around to sell you the latest antibiotic.

I ignored all these suggestions and carried on with my organic methods  and continued to split my hives, experimenting and moving bees from one city to another, and across county lines.  While colonies were collapsing all around me.  I found that I had almost a 100% survival rate.  Why?  Hybrid vigor.  The genetic diversity of my bees became a key to their survival.  I was splitting hives, and mixing them up across county lines.  My colonies could be in Fremont one month, and in Alameda the next. This also gives a mating queen the opportunity to mate with multiple drones, inevitably increasing the diversity and strength of the Hive.  Recently researchers have found that queens that have mated at least seven times are almost three times more likely to survive.  

These tough bees had developed resistance.  The same resistance that they have had for thousands of years before humans came along.  I have found by accident  why my hives don't collapse.  I used a strictly organic method coupled with a limited amount of meddling, and a rationed approach to honey harvest.  I leave the majority of the honey for the bees so that they can make it through the winter.  Only then in the spring when the nectar flows begin will I take honey from the previous year.  

https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/06/1...

We've had a great winter here in California and the wildflower blooms are going to be spectacular.  I predict that the nectar flows will also be amazing.  If theres any year in the history of California that will be conducive to the to the honeybee ecology.  2016 would be it.  

Bees are dying from a number of factors,  but what we can do we should do.  and this includes raising genetically tough bees.

I would love to raise genetically tough bees and install these hives throughout every corner of the bay area, but I need your help to do it.  

Each hive costs about $400 to set up.  I would be happy to take care of them, and teach others how to take care of them also.  Its fun, and it helps save the bees.  the plan is to build as many hives as we can fund, and space them throughout the bay area.  Ive set the funding goal to $8,000 so that we can add 20 hives to the area.  Every $400 we go over, Ill install another hive.  The more money raised, the more hives we install thus improving the genetic diversity of the bay area bee.

WHAT WE DO

We believe education is the key to creating a clean energy future. At the Midwest Renewable Energy Association (MREA), we promote renewable energy, energy efficiency, and sustainable living through education and demonstration. In particular, we have initiatives focused on the development of robust markets for renewables and a history of success in public engagement and inspiring positive energy and climate action.

Together with partners around the Midwest, we work to expand renewable energy adoption through innovative programs, renewable energy training, and educational events. We are currently achieving our mission through six initiatives:

1. The Energy Fair
2. Midwest Grow Solar Partnership
3. ReNew the Earth Institute (REI)
4. Professional Training
5. MREA Site Assessment Certificate
6. Solar University Network (SUN)
Right now we have an opportunity to expand our efforts by joining the nationwide push for electric transportation and advanced energy storage: All powered by clean energy.
Your support will help us install a solar carport on our newly-constructed, advanced electric vehicle charging demonstration!
The site features a 480V electric service powering an ABB Terra 53 DC fast charger and a fleet of ClipperCreek workplace chargers with advanced monitoring and load balancing software
column2: representing the state of the art in electric vehicle charging. It will allow us to expand our training programs and host the largest gathering of electric vehicles in the Midwest during our annual event, The Energy Fair.

column1: WHAT WE NEED

We are seeking $45,000 to construct a 20kW solar canopy for our newly built electric vehicle charging demonstration and training lab. We have the infrastructure to demonstrate the potential of electric transportation. Now, we need to power it with solar.

The new 3-phase solar canopy would expand our on-site training labs, allowing us to provide hands-on experience with commercial solar equipment. It would provide a beautiful structure that inspires the thousands of visitors who come to our campus each year. And, it would demonstrate the potential of marrying these two promising technologies.

This project has already brought us new partners interested in an advanced, resilient distributed and clean electric grid. We are incredibly grateful to everyone who has already helped drive this project forward, including:
<ul>
• Alliant Energy
• Clippercreek, Inc.
• Dairyland Power Cooperative / Touchstone Energy Cooperatives
• Fronius USA, LLC
• North Wind Renewable Energy Cooperative
• Photovoltaic Systems, LLC
• SolarEdge
• TurningPoint - Energy
• Unlimited Renewable Energies
• Werner Electric Minnesota
• Zef Energy and ABB, Inc.
PROJECT UPDATE

Thank you to our generous campaign supporters for helping us surpass our goal of generating $7500 on Indiegogo by July 11 to meet a matching donation from Photovoltaic Systems, LLC who has graciously offered to donate ALL of the needed solar modules to install a 20kW solar canopy over MREA's newly built electric vehicle demonstration and training lab.

We are incredibly grateful to everyone for helping us achieve this first milestone of securing solar modules. Moving forward, our next step is to secure funding to cover racking expenses. We still have a ways to go, but we are getting closer every day!

We would also like to thank our many supporters who donated to our campaign during The 28th annual Energy Fair, helping us raise over $6,500 in cash donations that are not reflected on this campaign page.
Thank you!
STRETCH GOALS

If we can exceed this initial goal of $45,000, we will purchase a new electric vehicle to conduct our outreach and training efforts throughout the Midwest. And, we will fund an outreach position to expand our Solar Power Hour program and bring our message to the masses.
Stretch Goal 1:  Three-year lease on an electric vehicle = $12,600
Stretch Goal 2:  50% funding for MREA Outreach Coordinator = $30,000
IMPACT

Your support will help us inspire Midwest communities to take leadership in clean energy development. In 1990 we hosted our first Energy Fair in Central Wisconsin and interest and investment in renewable energy has grown each year since. We are now seeing the widespread adoption of solar and wind energy by homes, businesses, cities, and electric utilities. We need to sustain this momentum and build a clean energy economy of the future.
We have the tools to end the fossil fuel age. We need the people and the investment.

We recently held our 28th annual Energy Fair, June 16-18, 2017 in Custer. We were honored to host keynote speaker, JB Straubel, CTO and Co-Founder of Tesla and enjoyed welcoming the largest gathering of electric vehicles in the Midwest. We see the potential to make positive changes. We see the growing interest in clean technologies. We feel the energy behind this movement.
Please join us!
WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION MEANS

Support MREA's Driving on Sunshine campaign to help us lead by example and educate the public on the benefits of going solar. Help us marry the technologies of solar energy and electric vehicles and invest in a bright future.
Together we can create a clean energy future: one with clean air, clean water, and access to clean energy for all!
JOIN US

Driving on Sunshine is about providing clean, local power to our communities! Together with our member and donor support we are training the clean tech workforce and expanding our reach far and wide.

Please support our campaign and help us drive the development of clean energy forward!
column4:
>Read more about our work on our website: midwestrenew.org
Learn about The Energy Fair and everything it has to offer: TheEnergyFair.org
For more stories about our programs' impact, view our Annual Report.
column6:
>All donations are tax deductible.

The Race to Save the World is a feature documentary film that follows the inspiring stories of everyday people who are devoting their lives to fighting climate change.  This film follows the passion, determination and unwavering commitment of people who aren't putting their heads in the sand, they aren't waiting for someone else to do something, they’re in the trenches doing anything and everything they can to make an impact.

The news about climate change is overwhelming and frightening and many think that there is little that one person can do, so they tune out this message. The Race To Save The World will motivate rather than frighten viewers, as we show people who are doing all they can to inspire the world to act while there’s still time to lessen the damage on future generations.

We were nearly done shooting and already editing The Race To Save The World when the election happened.  With all the climate deniers and the fossil fuel extractors in this administration, we were so shocked and saddened that we decided we needed to film for another 4-6 months into the new administration to show how people will continue to fight to protect life on this planet.
In order to finish principal photography, we need to raise $40,000.  If we raise more, we will put it towards the editing, as well as the sound mix and the music.
THE NEXT SIX MONTHS ARE KEY!

We have been filming for over two years, and it’s clear that there is a powerful movement building. While millions of people are still tuning out climate change and going about their lives hoping that someone else will solve this crisis, there are more and more people who are deeply engaged in the fight to preserve our planet for future generations.

The Race to Save the World follows our subjects from a very personal perspective.  By humanizing our subjects and revealing personal story arcs, viewers are drawn into the issue of global warming from a place of inspiration, rather than fear, and their stories will inspire audiences to join this fight.  Our goal in making The Race To Save The World is to help bring a new population of people into this movement, to make their voices heard and to take action for a livable future.
Why We're Fighting

Public policy changes when enough Americans voice their desires to see change, and it moves faster when the populace speaks loudly and forcefully to make sure that politicians pay attention. As Mark Hertsgaard, environmental correspondent for The Nation points out in our film, “The Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act, the Endangered Species Act, why did they happen? They happened because 20 million Americans got into the street. And that is what it's going to take.” By showing the stories of these unstoppable, tireless and resolute partisans in the fight for our collective future, we hope to shift the focus away from fear, and towards an uplifting spirit of unity and collective action.
Where Will Your Money Go?

All funds from this Indiegogo campaign will be allocated to cover essential production-related expenses. This money will come at a critical time as we are finishing up the filming.  Funds will be used to cover crew costs, travel and logistics and will ensure that we don't miss important moments needed to finalize the story arcs of our subjects.
What if we raise more than our goal?

If we reach $90,000 we will be able to finish the filming AND the offline editing.  And if we receive $150,000, we will be able to do the color correction, sound mix and music and completely finish the film!!  If we can rally support and raise all of these funds now, it will ensure that The Race To Save The World will be finished by the end of 2017, so that we can use this film to get people to join this war against catastrophic climate change before it’s too late.
Why us?

Joe Gantz is known for work that examines personal stories with honesty, humor, and depth. With his brother, Joe produced and directed Taxicab Confessions, the Emmy award-winning HBO documentary series featuring real-life interactions between cab drivers and their passengers that has been broadcast for fifteen years. Through their work, they’ve honed a documentary style they call, “life in progress” that allows them to make their subjects so comfortable that they quickly go about their daily life, as if there was no one filming. The subjects are not performing
column2: they are guiding this story, and the camera transports you into their lives, making for very authentic stories.

column1: Producer/Director Joe Gantz
Our Last Film
Through the making of our last documentary, American Winter, we saw how a film can contribute significantly to a much bigger movement.

American Winter is about families struggling in the wake of the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. The film follows personal stories that reveal the impact of rising poverty and income inequality and a shrinking middle class in the U.S., and was nominated for an Emmy Award and a Ridenhour Prize (a prize for acts of truth-telling that protect the public interest). Since American Winter was broadcast on HBO, we had successful screenings with non-profit partners in over 100 cities to bring attention to the issues of poverty, homelessness, food insecurity and the need for social services.  And we are very proud that this film had a significant part in the movement to raise the minimum wage.
<div><div style=""text-align: center

Four subjects from American Winter were invited to testify at a Senate hearing entitled, “The State of the American Dream – Economic Policy and the Future of the Middle Class”, moderated by Senators Elizabeth Warren and Jeff Merkley.  For The Race to Save the World, we will use a similar personal approach to emotionally-engage viewers in this urgent fight against catastrophic climate change.
JOIN OUR TEAM!

This crowd-funding campaign will not only help us make a powerful film.  It will also help us connect with a growing community of activists, organizations, leaders, policymakers and citizens who are passionately engaged in the climate change fight and who can use this film as a tool to support their efforts.
We want to inspire those on the sidelines to get involved.  Whether you are already in this fight or if this is your first step, donating to this campaign is an opportunity to act.
Make a donation, help spread the word through social media, and THANK YOU for joining us on this journey to complete The Race to Save The World!

Hello...my name is Milton ""Tony"" Taboada, I am passionate about the environment and earth. 
I created an animated character called Globearth, with the mission to inform and educate children about ways to protect our planet.
The purpose of this campaign is to produce educational videos (via internet for free) for children informing them about pollution, deforestation, recycling, conservation and animals rights.
We need your help to make this dream a reality!

Hola ... mi nombre es Milton ""Tony"" Taboada, un apasionado del medio ambiente y del planeta tierra. He creado el personaje animado de nombre GLOBEARTH con la mision de informar y educar a los jovenes de la gran importancia de protejer nuestro planeta tierra.

El proposito de este proyecto es recaudar fondos para producir videos educativos para los mas jovenes con informacion sobre la contaminacion ambiental, deforestacion, reciclaje, conservacion y proteccion de los animales
column2: los cuales seran distribuidos por internet en forma ""gratuita""  para poder llegar a todos los rincones del planeta.

column1: Estudios han demostrado que el  uso apropiado de un personaje animado ayuda a los jovenes a aprender .
Se acuerdan ustedes cual fue su personaje animado favorito?
Si gusta contribuir, puede elejir una de las dos opciones.
A - 'Click' en  ""BACK IT""  (respaldar) luego hacer 'click' en ""DONATION AMOUNT""  (monto a donar) luego continuar con la transaccion.
B - Ir a '""PERKS'"" (paquete) luego elejir el monto con el cual  usted desea contribuir. 'Click' en ""GET THIS PERK""  (elejir paquete)  luego continuar con la transaccion.
Cualquier monto que usted generosamente contribuya, nos ayudara a lograr el objetivo.
Gracias!
Visite: www.HelpGlobearth.com  o si tiene alguna pregunta escribanos a mtz82009@hotmail.com
Con su generoso apoyo lograremos la meta trazada!
Por favor, ayudenos a difundir este mensaje con sus familiares y amigos.
Siganos en Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube  - HELP GLOBEARTH
Gracias.
<h3>What We Need &amp
We need your help and contribution to create educational videos (e.g., 30 minutes) about pollution, deforestation, recycling, conservation and animal rights.
Kids can learn to make this planet a cleaner, safer and friendlier place to live.
We need to fund $15,000.00 USD
Your contribution will help us to pay for production costs that involves filming, editing, etc.
It also includes paying for a director, script writer, actors and extras, a voice over personality, studio locations, music (licenses) and permits.
If the incoming funds exceeds our goal, we would include animated sequences in the educational video(s) of Globearth in either 2D or 3D.

We are planning to film one episode on the beach (Santa Monica or Laguna Beach), two episodes in a production studio and the last episode with live animals at Planet Rehab. These specified locations require permits and licenses to film.
A portion of campaign funds will go to Indiegogo and will be used for transaction fees, the manufacturing of T-shirts, plush toys, posters, postcards, postage (shipping &

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will film shorter segments and post them on the internet. Also we will be investing in Globearth shirts, posters and plush toys to be donated at schools, hospitals and/or churches. If you have any suggestions on the organizations to donate to, please let us know.
Disclaimer: For international supporters that decide not to pay for the shipping and handling, depending on the perk package we will donate it to the organization of your choice in the U.S.
The future of our planet is in the hands of the new generation, please support us by making this project happen!
The Impact

As studies have shown, children are willing to explore and learn more when a program has an animated or a cartoon character leading the educational message or discussion. Globearth has the ability to have a huge impact on children that will help lead them into debates and discussions about the different environmental topics. Globearth's presence and live interaction in the educational videos will help children remember the important environmental issues for years to come!
What is or was your favorite animated or mascot character(s) when growing up?
Did that character(s) present a message that taught you valuable lessons in life?
Do you remember how influential that character was to you when you were growing up?
Please support this campaign and let's make Globearth part of the new generation! Your contribution is very valuable for this project!  Together we can make a difference!
Let me share a story

One sunny Saturday, March of 2015, Globearth (mascot costume) made its first appearance at the Santa Monica Pier in California. It was one the most beautiful experiences I have ever witnessed in my life! The general public was welcoming and excited to meet Globearth, families interacted and took pictures all day. The connection between Globearth and the children was so unreal that it encouraged me to dedicate myself to this new passion project.
Since then, Globearth has appeared and participated voluntarily in different cities and events: Earth Day CVWD in Rancho Cucamonga
column2: All Kids Expo in Rancho Cucamonga
column3: Founders Day Community Parade in Rancho Cucamonga
column4: Planet Rehab's Beach Clean Up Day at Laguna Beach and Huntington Beach
column5: Earth and Environmental Day in Claremont, Diamond Bar, Chino, San Dimas
column6: and the Central American Parade in Los Angeles.

column1: Other Ways You Can Help
Please contact us through indiegogo or www.helpglobearth.com giving us your insight, opinions and suggestions that are valuable to us to succeed in this campaign.
If you wish to contact me directly you can at mtz82009@hotmail.com
Please share this campaign to your family and friends, don't forget to follow us on social media outlets (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube) ""Help Globearth""
Thanks again.

We need your help to make this dream a reality!

The purposes of this research project are:
<ul>
• tour the United States for four (4) months in a camper van connecting with people across the U.S. who are engaged in Earth-based food, medicine, and spiritual practices
• learn how and why the people I interview engage in these practices
• understand multiple ways these practices can be defined
• design and execute research using creative methods and social media while maintaining my research integrity
This research is important because it will:
<ul>
• record stories of individuals engaged in Earth-based practices
• document diverse experiences of people in the U.S.--how they value the Earth and why
• generate many narratives
• promote findings through public and non-traditional means
Project Deliverables
<ul>
• social media posts
• blog posts
• podcast episodes
• videos
• magazine and journal articles
• mixed media art
• poetry
• book
How will I conduct this research?

Interviewees will be chosen via a method called snowball sampling. This means that I will choose one person who is known publicly for engaging in these practices and then that person will refer me to the next person and each subsequent person will select other interview prospects.
I am supporting myself with my own Earth-based lifestyle business:
<ul>
• plant-based food popup meals,
• plant-based cooking classes and webinars,
• spiritual healing sessions, and
• classes, talks, and webinars about Earth-based narratives.
I NEED YOUR HELP!
<ul>
• Share this crowd fund site
<li>Visit and share my websites<ul>
• www.rosehiproadtrip.com
• www.freeyahmind.com
<li>Visit and interact with my social media platforms<ul>
<li>Facebook: Rose Hip Road Trip &amp
<li>Instagram: @rosehiproadtrip &amp
• Read my blog and listen to my podcast (on websites listed above)
• Suggest locations for, host and/or attend Hilary's House Dining Club events (learn more on Hilary's House Dining Club Facebook Page)
• Invite me to give a talk to your organization
• Subscribe to my mailing list
• Book a reading or psycho-spiritual healing session
• Share your experiences about attending an event or one-on-one session
• Attend a webinar or online class
With your financial support, I will:
<ul>
• purchase a vehicle from which I can live over the course of the research project
• revamp the vehicle I purchase to make it suitable for my business and research needs
• insure my vehicle
• obtain roadside assistance
<li>maintain a social/multi-media presence with necessary equipment &amp

A line by line breakdown of my budget is available upon request. If you have a vehicle or run a company that makes and/or sells travel/camping gear, plant-based foods, cooking equipment, or mechanical parts, you can also support me by offering discounted and/or complementary products. If your product is something that I need and use, I will be happy to offer mentions and product placement on my social media platforms in exchange.
Research Philosophy

My research corresponds with theories asserting that individuals and human collectives find healing and wholeness by owning multiple versions of difficult and complex histories and dreaming into being new realities for futures. I am a combination of many things—things that are considered contradictory in systems that don’t honor the complexity of what it means to be whole. The complexity of my own identity informs my desire to research the complexity of collective identities. Because I have researched and own the complexity within myself, I can research complexity outside of myself effectively.

My research is imbued with a science and a politics of hope, with a theory of compassion. It centers healing, consciousness, and liberation/salvation. I choose to focus my work on healing, consciousness, and liberation not to ignore problems, but because doing so allows the problem to emerge as part of the discussion without it being the whole discussion. Authentic discussions of healing require mentioning from what and through what one is being healed. Authentic discussions of liberation require mentioning from what one is being liberated. Narratives of healing and liberation inspire, encourage, and empower.
Thank you for your support. Thank you for your partnership. I look forward to bringing you along for the ride!
If you have questions, don't hesitate to reach out via social media or email HilaryB@rosehiproadtrip.com

EN: whatis the Djebli Club?
Djebli The club is a social cultural artistic platform. This
is a non lucatif profit project that
promotes humanity. respect for nature
and shared as values of living
together, that has for mission to:
·
Provide a space for creativity
and inspiration for artists around the world and of all kinds.
·
Facilitate the access to art
for the locals of the Mokrisset Chefchaouen region, and allow them to get in
touch with artists around the world.
·
Offer to the inn’s guests a
pleasant stay and offer them a variety of cultural and artistic activities.
·
Encourage eco-tourism in
Morocco.
·
Encourage the sustainable
development of the Mokrisset Chefchaouen region by involving the local
community in the creation, the implementation and the advancement of the project.
·
Promote green actions to
preserve the natural resources and the environment, notably through a
particular mode of ecological building.
FR: Qu'est ce que le Djebli Club?
Le Djebli
club est une plateforme artistique culturelle sociale.
C’est un projet à but non lucatif qui prône l'humanité. le
respect de la nature et le partage comme valeurs
essentielles du vivre ensemble, qui a pour missions:
·
Offrir un
espace pour la créativité et l'inspiration pour des artistes du monde
entier et de tout genre.
·
Faciliter l’accès à
l'art aux habitants de la région de Mokrisset chefchaouen (Maroc) et leur
permettre de rentrer en contact avec des artistes du monde entier.
·
Offrir un
séjour agréable aux invités de l'auberge et leur offrir une variété d'activités
culturelles et artistiques.
·
encourager
le tourisme écolo.
·
Promouvoir
des actions green pour la préservation des richesses naturelles et
l'environnement à travers notamment un mode de constructions écologique.
EN: IMPACT
The Djebli Club is part of a sustainable development and conscience
prospect. its approach will enable an attentive development of the
environment for the region and to the local community.
The youth of the region will also have the opportunity to receive training
and workshops by artists and cultural professionals visiting the Djebli Club.
These artists will have access to an exceptional framework suitable for
inspiration and artistic equipment. They have the possibility to substitute the
payment for their accommodation with courses for the young people in the
region.
<div><span style=""background-color: initial
<div><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
FR: L'impact
Le Djebli
Club s'inscrit dans une perspective de développement durable et conscient. il
permettra un développement soucieux de l'environnement et de la communauté
locale.
la jeunesse
de la région aura également l'opportunité de recevoir des formation et des
ateliers par des artistes et des professionnels de culture visitant le Djebli
Club.
ces artistes
auront accès à un cadre exceptionnel propice à l'inspirations et à du matériel
artistique avec la possibilité de substituer le paiement de leur hébergement
par des cours au profit des jeunes de la région.
EN: Construction
The Djebli Club will adopt a
green building method of construction favoring recycling and the use of natural
materials. It will follow the “hobbit house” model of construction. With this
model, the inn will fit in perfectly with the landscape without creating a
discord with the local space. The buildings will be built with the same
techniques used by the local houses (Terracotta, wood…), only they would also
have the peculiarity of being in complete harmony with the landscape.The Djebli
Club furnishings would also be in the same spirit. The furniture will be built
by volunteers using recycled materials.
FR: Construction
Le Djebli
Club adoptera un mode de construction écologique en privilégiant le recyclage
et l'utilisation de matériaux naturels. il suivra le modèle de construction
Hobbit house. avec ce modèle, l'auberge se mariera parfaitement au paysage sans
créer de discordance avec l'espace local. Les bâtiments seront construits avec
les mêmes techniques utilisées pour les habitations locales (terre, cuite,
bois,...) mais auront également cette particularité d'être en harmonie totale
avec le paysage.
L'ameublement du Djebli Club sera également dans le
même esprit. les meubles seront construits par les volontaires en utilisant des
matériaux recyclés.

·

project.
·
you can also participate in
the work of construction. (if you are in Morocco)
