<div><div class=""campaignStoryVideoWrapper""><iframe src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/3voDZHf7FIY?autohide=1&amp
Summary

About Us: Launched in 2015, the key purpose of the International Resilience Network (IRN) is supporting the growth of locally based innovations aimed at healing our inter-generational and inter-species connections. At the Heart of our work is the resurgence of Indigenous knowledge for human and planetary well-being, Elders and  youth have important roles to play at our helm.

Those who have either founded or are friends of IRN are passionate about the revitalization of Indigenous and interconnected ways of being as a response to the individualism and consumerism that is wiping away life.

Relationships play an important part in our community-building and there's a lot of growing enthusiasm on the ground about our hubs!  Our 7 communities include people who attended our 2015 Summit- they are already part of our network. Some of us have been working and growing together for over a decade or more - for example the Radical Human Ecology and Dialogues across Canada
Our Team: We have a small team of directors.

As a member of the Ngai Te Rangi tribe, Aotearoa who has both who has settler and Indigenous origins, Lewis Williams, http://www.kalewiswilliams.com the Founding Director of IRN, knows first hand the richness of moving back to deeply  interconnected ways of being. It is possible, and necessary for all of us.

Our Youth Director Fergus Walker,  Isle of Skye, Scotland, is one of the Founding Directors of Common Good Food, http://www.commongoodfood.org  a not for profit focused on food sovereignty through combining modern technology with traditional, Indigenous knowledge. To hear from fergus see his short video on http://www.internationalresiliencenetwork.com
Our third Co-director Nick Claxton https://www.uvic.ca/education/future/indigenous...  is from the Tsawout Band &
column2: WSÁNEĆ Nation, Vancouver Island. An Assistant Teaching Professor in Indigenous Education with the University of Victoria, Dr Claxton is playing a leading role in revitalizing the traditional ReefNet fishing methods of the WSANEC Peoples.

column1: About Our Campaign: Our campaign to heal inter-generational and inter-species connections is in response to the profound Disconnect Condition of our times. For example, this is evident in the interconnected problems of climate-change and species depletion, Indigenous youth suicide or the high poverty rates of older people. If our inter-generational and inter-species connections continue to unravel so do we!

As a means of strengthening our connections and passing on traditional knowledge we are continuing to re-establish the rich Indigenous, inter-generational, and  intercultural connections begun at our 2015 Summit on Tsawout traditional territory. To do this we aim to establish 7 inter-generational resilience hubs in Canada, Scotland, Aotearoa and Australia.

The aim of each hub is to strengthen practices of intergenerational resilience - the strength that comes from shared knowledge and connections between Elders and youth.  Whether through land-based learning, arts informed ways of being or deep fireside talks, each hub will bring Elders and youth together for inter-generational learning around practical tasks of sustainability. Each hub or sustainability innovation will be evaluated and learnings shared through our global virtual exchange program.

Your contributions will be vital in enabling Elders and young people to attend each hub, supporting the costs of food, venue, learning materials, coordination and program evaluation. Through connecting and supporting today's knowledge keepers and tomorrow's leaders your contributions play a vital role in ensuring we sustain the web of life! Just like a well-tended garden, if given the support and nourishment, each hub will seed new hubs, spinning the web of resilience wide and far.
<h3>What We Need &amp
Seeding Inter-generational Resilience for Sustainable Futures is aiming to raise a Total of $55,000.
Inter-generational Resilience Hubs
<ul>
• $5,000 / hub ($35,000 total) which will be matched locally either in cash or in kind resourcing.
• $200 will support one Elder or young Thought Leader's attendance at an Inter-generational resilience hub over 2-3 days. This includes travel, cost of material, food and accommodation.
Global Exchange
<ul>

• $20,000 to coordinate results emerging from each hub, establish our inter-generational and intercultural global exchange through a digital platform, and seed our next international face to face summit in Aotearoa.
• $12, 000 will fund a coordinator, $3,000 for our digital platform, and $5,000 towards seeding the next summit (travel and time costs).

Our Short Term Fundraising goal for our First Inter-generational Resilience Hub Launch, August 3rd. is $10,000 - $5,000 to see our next hub and $5,000 to assist Tsawout to continue with their inter-generational resilience and ReefNet Fishing hub.
If we don't reach our entire goal of $55,000, our first priority is to seed each  of the 7 Inter-generational resilience hubs.
The Impact
This work has potential to:
<ul>
<li>Restore the importance of Indigenous and traditional knowledge
• Re-centre inter-generational connections and relationships between Elders and Youth,
<li>Further grow the strength and talents of our youth, unleashing the capacities of our communities
• Perhaps most significant, generate understandings across Indigenous and settler communities of how we can work together for sustainable futures.
To see our track record of growing inter-generational resilience go to: www.internationalresiliencenetwork.com
Other Ways You Can Help
There are many ways besides financial contributions to help:
<ul>
• Getting the word out about our campaign is a biggie.
• Hitting the 'Indiegogo' share tools will help heaps
• Or you might know of people or organizations who can provide perks to help our campaign along!
Come and be part of our journey!
","Summary

About Us: Launched in 2015, the key purpose of the International Resilience Network (IRN) is supporting the growth of locally based innovations aimed at healing our inter-generational and inter-species connections. At the Heart of our work is the resurgence of Indigenous knowledge for human and planetary well-being, Elders and  youth have important roles to play at our helm.

Those who have either founded or are friends of IRN are passionate about the revitalization of Indigenous and interconnected ways of being as a response to the individualism and consumerism that is wiping away life.

Relationships play an important part in our community-building and there's a lot of growing enthusiasm on the ground about our hubs!  Our 7 communities include people who attended our 2015 Summit- they are already part of our network. Some of us have been working and growing together for over a decade or more - for example the Radical Human Ecology and Dialogues across Canada
Our Team: We have a small team of directors.

As a member of the Ngai Te Rangi tribe, Aotearoa who has both who has settler and Indigenous origins, Lewis Williams, http://www.kalewiswilliams.com the Founding Director of IRN, knows first hand the richness of moving back to deeply  interconnected ways of being. It is possible, and necessary for all of us.

Our Youth Director Fergus Walker,  Isle of Skye, Scotland, is one of the Founding Directors of Common Good Food, http://www.commongoodfood.org  a not for profit focused on food sovereignty through combining modern technology with traditional, Indigenous knowledge. To hear from fergus see his short video on http://www.internationalresiliencenetwork.com

Our third Co-director Nick Claxton https://www.uvic.ca/education/future/indigenous...  is from the Tsawout Band & WSÁNEĆ Nation, Vancouver Island. An Assistant Teaching Professor in Indigenous Education with the University of Victoria, Dr Claxton is playing a leading role in revitalizing the traditional ReefNet fishing methods of the WSANEC Peoples.

The Background

We have already lost so many iconic giants, species that inspired awe and curiosity. Without these species, our world is emptier and the role these species played in regulating ecosystems is gone forever. These giants included the Yangtze river dolphin, the Steller’s sea cow and the Tasmanian tiger. All wiped out through greed, ignorance and apathy. Right now, a small team of biologists, anglers and their supporters are fighting hard, with little to no resources, to prevent the extinction of another giant, the critically endangered flapper skate – the largest of its kind on planet earth.

The flagship species

These 200lb relatives of sharks and rays are the apex predator (they eat smallsharks!) in coastal North West Europe, can live to a hundred years, tend to remain in the same place and reproduce very slowly. They even communicate with each other through electrical impulses. They will be the first commercially fished species driven to extinction unless we act now. Our project will carry out vital research on the basic ecology, physiology and behaviour of these species as well as test the efficacy of translocation (think Star Trek and the Whales, then tone it down as we will be flying their eggs over and hatching them).

The problem

Unfortunately, the cards are stacked against us – in the current political climate conservation funding is at a low ebb and the political will to be creative and make a positive difference is completely lacking. Throw in a pinch of climate change and a dash of ocean acidification and its a pretty grim stew. But SkatePark is a battle we can win, Skatepark is realistic, feasible and with your donations we will do it!
column3: >We are proposing a damper Yellowstone Wolf project: using the Strangford Lough Marine Protected Area in Northern Ireland as a test site for SkatePark, the world first elasmobranch reserve. The Lough was once home to plenty of skate and other smaller cousins, but they disappeared (they didn't go on holiday, if you know what I mean). The lough has also lost another vital component of its ecosystem, the mussel
column5: > of biodiversity (again, they didn't exactly walk out of the reef). In short, the Lough has become degraded, missing vital members from both the top (skate) and bottom (mussels) parts of its ecosystem. In the absence of higher predators, the recovery
column6: > of the reef is being suppressed by crabs (who without skates and rays are in seventh heaven). We believe
column7: > that a recovery in the predator
column8: > population will suppress crab foraging enough too
column10: > the mussel reef (and the associated biodiversity) to recover. Luckily, the Lough and the Skate now  enjoy robust
column11: > legal protection. The site is practically
column12: > enclosed and we have local support, this can work!
column13: >SkatePark is a demonstration project, if we can demonstrate the efficacy
column14: > of transloacting apex predators here, we can use this to help justify similar active
column15:
> conservation actions elsewhere. This is a paradigm shifter. 

Where you can help

All donations will go directly towards supporting research by postgraduate students that is all directly relevant to the foundation and realisation of SkatePark. Mostly, we require funding to pay for boat time to support research projects. We have students, basic equipment but no boat support, which is a bit important for carrying out most marine biological projects. Please check out Alexandra's video to find out what she will spend your hard earned dough on.

Who We Are 
Our research team is led by Dr Patrick Collins at Queen’s University in Belfast in Northern Ireland and Alexandra McInturf at University of California, Davis in the good ol' US of A. The video footage was taken by our buddies at Puffin Media (subsea footage) and by N&
column16:
L productions (above sea footage). You might think it odd that some Californians are supporting a project based in the North East Atlantic, but maybe they believe this can work too!

","The BackgroundWe have already lost so many iconic giants, species that inspired awe and curiosity. Without these species, our world is emptier and the role these species played in regulating ecosystems is gone forever. These giants included the Yangtze river dolphin, the Steller’s sea cow and the Tasmanian tiger. All wiped out through greed, ignorance and apathy. Right now, a small team of biologists, anglers and their supporters are fighting hard, with little to no resources, to prevent the extinction of another giant, the critically endangered flapper skate – the largest of its kind on planet earth.The flagship speciesThese 200lb relatives of sharks and rays are the apex predator (they eat smallsharks!) in coastal North West Europe, can live to a hundred years, tend to remain in the same place and reproduce very slowly. They even communicate with each other through electrical impulses. They will be the first commercially fished species driven to extinction unless we act now. Our project will carry out vital research on the basic ecology, physiology and behaviour of these species as well as test the efficacy of translocation (think Star Trek and the Whales, then tone it down as we will be flying their eggs over and hatching them).The problemUnfortunately, the cards are stacked against us – in the current political climate conservation funding is at a low ebb and the political will to be creative and make a positive difference is completely lacking. Throw in a pinch of climate change and a dash of ocean acidification and its a pretty grim stew. But SkatePark is a battle we can win, Skatepark is realistic, feasible and with your donations we will do it!The SolutionWe are proposing a damper Yellowstone Wolf project: using the Strangford Lough Marine Protected Area in Northern Ireland as a test site for SkatePark, the world first elasmobranch reserve. The Lough was once home to plenty of skate and other smaller cousins, but they disappeared (they didn't go on holiday, if you know what I mean). The lough has also lost another vital component of its ecosystem, the mussel reefs, which supported squillions of biodiversity (again, they didn't exactly walk out of the reef). In short, the Lough has become degraded, missing vital members from both the top (skate) and bottom (mussels) parts of its ecosystem. In the absence of higher predators, the recovery of the reef is being suppressed by crabs (who without skates and rays are in seventh heaven). We believe that a recovery in the predator population will suppress crab foraging enough too allow the mussel reef (and the associated biodiversity) to recover. Luckily, the Lough and the Skate now  enjoy robust legal protection. The site is practically enclosed and we have local support, this can work!SkatePark is a demonstration project, if we can demonstrate the efficacy of transloacting apex predators here, we can use this to help justify similar active conservation actions elsewhere. This is a paradigm shifter. Where you can helpAll donations will go directly towards supporting research by postgraduate students that is all directly relevant to the foundation and realisation of SkatePark. Mostly, we require funding to pay for boat time to support research projects. We have students, basic equipment but no boat support, which is a bit important for carrying out most marine biological projects. Please check out Alexandra's video to find out what she will spend your hard earned dough on.Who We Are Our research team is led by Dr Patrick Collins at Queen’s University in Belfast in Northern Ireland and Alexandra McInturf at University of California, Davis in the good ol' US of A. The video footage was taken by our buddies at Puffin Media (subsea footage) and by N&L productions (above sea footage). You might think it odd that some Californians are supporting a project based in the North East Atlantic, but maybe they believe this can work too!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

The Climate Change and Extreme Weather Story
Who?

We are Michal, Vlado, Danka, Anton and Peter and we are part of the team working on this crowdfunding campaign. But Rain for Climate is actually much more – we are a consortium of renowned scientist and experts from 13 countries, backed up by academic and privately held institutions and we keep growing. We have been researching climate change and hydrology from various perspectives since 1980’s, came to a dramatic conclusion and have very important massage for humanity to deliver.
What?
Climate Change, Extreme Weather and Water

Our research shows that the presence of water in a territory is absolutely essential for thermoregulation to function on planet Earth. Mismanagement of rainwater is gradually leading to permanent water scarcity on continents with devastating consequences.

People annually seal vast areas by development activities and further boost the negative impact of such actions by industrialized agriculture, managed forestry and deforestation. This spins off a growing spiral of destruction: lack of water causes individual territories to overheat and soil to lose its ability to absorb water – the temperatures hit extremes, since there is not enough water to act as a thermoregulation medium - the ‘heat island’ effect deforms local weather conditions causing turbulent events and shifts in precipitation patterns – this results in droughts or extreme rainfall from dense clouds – the floods and erosion take away soil, and we channel it to the seas – and the loop closes, only more extensively.
Pic.: heat island effect deforming local weather
Desertification

Temperature and precipitation extremes, lack of soil and flashfloods – these are characteristics of deserts. To make things worse, we put ourselves into the boiling frog’s situation - people are causing the biggest desertification ever, causing the complete destabilization of Earth’s thermoregulation without realizing it.
Pic.: temperature extremes caused by lack of water on territory
Solution

Our research indicates that to stabilize the climate globally, we will need to return approx. 700 km3 (168 mi3) of water back to continents. To put it into perspective, let’s take Mt. Everest as the highest mountain on Earth. The goal is 35x the volume of Mt. Everest.

How does one return water to a territory? The answer is called rainwater retention measures. You can think of it as construction work and by specific remodeling of your property you can achieve zero rainwater runoff. Correctly using the retained water will minimize the negative impact on the local climate.
It is easier said than done because the property owner usually wants to keep the function of the property in its current form (e.g., factory, golf course, agricultural land, etc.)

Pic.: solution samples in urban environment, argicultural land and forest

 

How?
The good news is that to work with water is very actionable, unlike CO2 reduction. It is mainly a matter of being consciously aware of what is required and understanding several basic concepts.

You can implement rainwater retention measures on a small property yourself. It is part of our mission to empower people with proper knowledge. Please refer to the DIY section of our website for more details.

It does get more complicated when one is working on a complex property or is addressing a climate change specific issue. For example, a flood prevention measure must be well designed to save lives and avert damage
column2: equally drought prevention need to be designed systematically taking local conditions into account to work at all.

column1: We have designed a specific technology – collecting data by a customized drone, we can measure and assess the impact of the territory on local climate and we can custom design specific rainwater measures virtually anywhere in the world. The prototypes are work-in-progress but to achieve the big goal

The other aspect is crowdsourcing  - it takes a territory, human power, capital and know-how to materialize a rainwater retention project. This is why we want to provide basic how-to to everybody and turn our website into a global rehydration portal, where people based on their geography, offer their resources and projects that are accessible to everyone for rapid knowledge transfer.

Having previous experience with politics and to make the movement sustainable for the long-term, we decided to drive this movement from bottom up. Our mission is to share the knowledge and work with people making our way towards the policymakers.
Pic.: Top-notch technologies and scientific approach marry disruptive model and grass root movement
Other Benefits
A rainwater retention program, when approached systematically and designed carefully, yields besides local climate moderation, other very interesting benefits:
<ul>
<li>
Flood, water erosion and mudslides prevention – we slow down, retain and use rainwater before it can cause damage. See with your very own eyes our multiple proof-of-concept locations worldwide.
<li>

Drought and wildfire prevention – soil and landscape abundant in water is a prerequisite for wildfire prevention. Retained rainwater further mitigates periods drought. We have done it in the desert in Saudi Arabia and Portugal.
<li>
Enhanced water sources – sufficient volume of rainwater retention measures create new potable water sources in times of water scarcity. Check out our projects in India for further details.
<li>
Increase in biodiversity – enough water for the local ecosystems enables nature to thrive, for example in Australia.
• Increase in biomass and food production – thriving ecosystems produce more biomass and ultimately more food than before.
<li>
Carbon sequestration – increased biomass production effectively sequestrates carbon from the air in the most traditional, yet most natural fashion, no geoengineering required.
<li>

Job creation and local economies support – local companies implementing rainwater retention measures mean we create local jobs. In combination with secured food it helps to achieve local political stabilization - once again we have achieved it in Slovakia.
• When applied systematically, it is possible to return regular precipitation patterns even to arid and long-term drought stricken areas.
<li>

Impact on sea level rise – did you know that all the rainwater we channel from continents to the oceans and which never comes back due to the heat island phenomena is responsible for sea level rise by 2.1 mm (0.08 in) annually ? Once we retain rainwater on the continents, we leave it up to you to formulate the conclusion.
Other Ways you can Help
Climate change is everybody’s business, regardless of you supporting the crowdfunding campaign. There are additional ways you can help:
<ul>
• Please share our campaign and the campaign updates on your social media – it is important to share this knowledge
<li>
Talk to your family &
column2: friends about a solution to mitigate climate change and weather extremes – it is important to empower them

column1: <li>
Point to www.RainForClimate.com for information and to sign up for our newsletter – this is how we stay in touch with you, as there will be more possibilities to get involved coming up shortly
Finances

Our endeavor is going to take several steps as such a challenge takes a long-term campaign. This crowdfunding campaign is the first round that will help to roll-out the solution globally and  to unlock the following campaign. The more funds we will be able to crowdfund, the more efficiently we will be able to move things forward.
What are we crowdfunding now?
Empowering people and providing knowledge requires a proper vehicle.
<ul>

• We are digitizing part of the rainwater retention measures catalog to provide you information and detailed step-by-step instructions on how to build your own. You will be able to find this information in the DIY section of our website.

• A global re-hydration portal is going to unlock the crowdsourcing aspect of the movement. It will allow anybody in the world to bring in to the table what they have available - be it a territory, human capital or finances to materialize rainwater retention projects out of thin air. This way we can all truly collaborate globally, observe the geographical areas of our interest and transparently measure against the great goals we have ahead of us
Risks &
<ul>

• The existing sociological systems are resistant to change. This means that there will be objections against Rain for Climate, against the explanation of weather extremes and how it relates to global climate change.
    This is the reason why we are starting bottom up – dedicated individuals building rainwater retention measures in their gardens will achieve more than political debates. Worst comes to worst – it still would be worth building rainwater retention measures because of the other benefits mentioned above. These are proven, no questions asked.

• We may experience issues with the monitoring system due to the complexity of the monitored environments.
    We have the best experts with us onboard, and this gives us the confidence to say that the issues will get resolved.
References
Our team has been working on climate change for 30 years.
Here are some of our achievements:
<ul>
• We formed a scientific theory about climate change and extreme weather mechanism
• The theory is supported by a number of published scientific articles
• Multiple locations worldwide have implemented the rainwater retention measures with great success
• Members of our team designed and executed a rainwater retention program at country level
• Our work was officially recognized by - United Nations, Goldman Environmental Prize (also known as Green Nobel) and many others

For more detailed information please visit our website www.RainForClimate.com. We sincerely hope that our message and the crowdfunding campaign will resonate with you and together we will restore the global climate.

Let us conclude with Gandhi's words:

First they ignore you,
then they laugh at you,
then they fight you,
then you win.
Information About the Perks

Our perks revolve around the knowledge associated with the New Water Paradigm. The perks ultimately serve the purpose of our mission – to raise awareness and empower people as much as possible and to act as quickly as possible. Ultimately, we hope to get the attention of two specific types of people – influencers who can help us to push the solution deployment exponentially and people who would like to get involved – and act either as the Rain for Climate ambassadors spreading the knowledge and networking or actually manage and implement projects.

The more funds we will be able to crowdfund, the more efficiently we will be able to move things forward.
What are we crowdfunding now?
Empowering people and providing knowledge requires a proper vehicle.

We are digitizing part of the rainwater retention measures catalog to provide you information and detailed step-by-step instructions on how to build your own. You will be able to find this information in the DIY section of our website.

A global re-hydration portal is going to unlock the crowdsourcing aspect of the movement. It will allow anybody in the world to bring in to the table what they have available - be it a territory, human capital or finances to materialize rainwater retention projects out of thin air. This way we can all truly collaborate globally, observe the geographical areas of our interest and transparently measure against the great goals we have ahead of us
Risks & Challenges

The existing sociological systems are resistant to change. This means that there will be objections against Rain for Climate, against the explanation of weather extremes and how it relates to global climate change.This is the reason why we are starting bottom up – dedicated individuals building rainwater retention measures in their gardens will achieve more than political debates. Worst comes to worst – it still would be worth building rainwater retention measures because of the other benefits mentioned above. These are proven, no questions asked.

We may experience issues with the monitoring system due to the complexity of the monitored environments.We have the best experts with us onboard, and this gives us the confidence to say that the issues will get resolved.
References
Our team has been working on climate change for 30 years.
Here are some of our achievements:
We formed a scientific theory about climate change and extreme weather mechanism
The theory is supported by a number of published scientific articles
Multiple locations worldwide have implemented the rainwater retention measures with great success
Members of our team designed and executed a rainwater retention program at country level
Our work was officially recognized by - United Nations, Goldman Environmental Prize (also known as Green Nobel) and many others

For more detailed information please visit our website www.RainForClimate.com. We sincerely hope that our message and the crowdfunding campaign will resonate with you and together we will restore the global climate.Let us conclude with Gandhi's words:
First they ignore you,then they laugh at you,then they fight you,then you win.
Information About the Perks

Our perks revolve around the knowledge associated with the New Water Paradigm. The perks ultimately serve the purpose of our mission – to raise awareness and empower people as much as possible and to act as quickly as possible. Ultimately, we hope to get the attention of two specific types of people – influencers who can help us to push the solution deployment exponentially and people who would like to get involved – and act either as the Rain for Climate ambassadors spreading the knowledge and networking or actually manage and implement projects.",4.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Velke Zaluzie, Slovakia",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/restore-global-climate-with-rain-for-climate/pica

Short Summary
Hi! My name is Peter Danforth. I am the Director of Operations for
Project SERV Inc. a 501(c)(3) not -for-profit organization dedicated the
restoration of shellfish in our marine environments. I have always had a keen
interest in saving our environment through restoration efforts and I started
working on technologies that could do so with shellfish about 5 years ago. My
partners and I have have developed methods to restore shellfish to their marine
environments through a patent pending procedure referred to as Shellfish Set Trap Systems SSTS.
Through our
fundraising efforts we hope to restore shellfish and marine organisms and
their natural habitats, provide education and public outreach, provide jobs and
promote economic development.
Our current specific
fundraising objective is to support the development of our Shellfish Set Trap
System (SSTS). The SSTS is an invention designed to restore oyster reefs
worldwide.
The Benefits of the
SSTS
•Carbon
Sequestration</u>– Buffer acidification of ocean rates through increased
Calcium carbonate levels.
•Habitat
Restoration</u> - More shellfish means more biodiversity through living
reef systems leading to…
•Cleaner Waters –
A single oyster alone can filter about 50 gallons of water a day.
•Increased
Shellfish Landings
•Coastal Erosion
Mitigation </u>– Oyster Reefs are now part of New York States 2100
Commission Report effort to prevent storm surge damage from storms like
Superstorm Sandy!
•Home Ownership
Values</u>– Clean waters, protected shorelines adds value to home owners with
shore front property.
What We Need &
Our goal for April
2016 is to raise $250,000
minimum budget to effectively run Project SERV Inc. and its current projects.
Please note! There are
Bronze, Silver and Gold Memberships:
•4 Project SERV
T-Shirts (small, medium, large and extra large available)
•Link for your
business on our website throughout 2017
•2 Project SERV
T-Shirts (small, medium, large and extra large available)
•Link for your
business on our website throughout 2017
•1 Project SERV
T-Shirt (small, medium, large and extra large available)
•Link to your
business on our website throughout 2017
Your contribution is
an investment in the future of our oceans and a the survival of shellfish like
oysters whose habitats have been decimated by disease, over fishing, and
pollution.
Coastal wetland loss
is a major environmental problem affecting coastlines worldwide.  The
causes are complex, ranging from global warming, to working coasts supporting critical
infrastructure such as highways, ports, pipelines and navigational waterways of
economic significance. <b>Without coastal restoration, people and businesses will
be forced to retreat from coastal areas which results in severe economic
consequences to various areas.
Coastal erosion refers
to land receding along the coastline due to erosion of soil. As humans we have
built habitations along the coastline, flooding of these areas present a
serious danger to human safety and to property. Coastal erosion results from
storms, such as hurricanes, and human activities, such as building on the
wetlands and destroying this ecosystem. Global warming has led to rising sea levels,
which results in disappearing shorelines
The founders of
Project SERV have created a method by which
shellfish larvae are grown in large numbers and released in a natural setting,
beginning earlier in the season than is typically done. This can take the form
of enclosed reef structures
column2: i.e. oyster reefs or clam and scallop swarms where

column1: suitable substrate exists. This system mimics and boosts natural systems.
The spawning of
shellfish has occurred for 4000 plus years and the methods have not varied much
until now.
Our patented
technology produces more shellfish numbers at twice the rate then
current methods and  and focuses on the bio-remediation of reefs and
ecosystem restoration as opposed to hatchery food production.
Shellfish have
supported civilizations for millenniums from Romans to railroad workers in
California in the 1800s. It is theorized that oyster and tuber diet lead to the
survival of the human race some 193,000 years ago during along glacial stage known
as Marine Isotope Stage 6 (MIS6) where only a few thousand breeding individuals
still existed in South Africa. This and the fact that <b>shellfish shells
throughout the millenniums have trapped enough atmospheric carbon to allow life
as we know it, shows a positive correlation between our survival and shellfish
survival.
In 1864 alone, 700
million European flat oysters (Ostrea edulis) were consumed in London,
employing up to 120,000 men in Britain to dredge oysters.
Shell piles in the
southwest of France contain over 1 trillion shells apiece, underscoring both
the productivity of the native species and the scale of harvest.
In the 1870s,
inter-tidal reefs of the eastern oyster (Crassostrea virginica) extended
for miles along the main axis of the James River in Chesapeake Bay but had
largely disappeared by the 1940s.
Native bivalve
shellfish provide a variety of ecologically and economically valuable services.
As “ecosystem engineers” shellfish influence the environment around them in
ways that benefit other species – and therefore benefit people and our economy.
In many places, walls
and jetties are built to defend coastlines from erosion
revitalized reefs could provide this protection and offer many additional
services as well.
Project SERV Inc, with
our patented technology, can provide an environmentally sustainable solution
for coastal mitigation issues that are occurring on a world-wide basis!
Risks &
Our greatest risk and
challenge is not being able to receive the support we need in order to work
properly. Without financial support we can not:
<ol>
• Hire personnel and contractors
<li>Order equipment and supplies for the Shellfish
Set Trap Systems,
<li>Pay for insurance, advertising, pay rent and
provide maintenance for our facilities.
We are a dedicated
group however! We have worked for 5 years on a shoestring budget and have
managed to have an office, done two successful proof of concept studies and are
currently working with SUNY Southampton to provide Shellfish Set Trap Systems
in order to restore oyster reefs on the south shore of Long Island in
Other Ways You Can Help
Please also visit us at
www.projectserv.org
If you are in Long
Island this spring and summer and would like to volunteer we can be reached
through Indigogo or our web site!

Short Summary

Hello my name is Paul, but generally known as Grizzly. This name has stuck with me  since I began traveling off the ""beaten track"". Investing in  a small piece of land in Gambia changed my life. The chance of living &
column2: working in Africa became a reality.

column1:
Were do I begin ! I started traveling when I was 16 and my obsession has continued in between getting married , having 3 children, getting divorced and visualizing a dream of building an Eco Mud Brick Guest House in Gambia West Africa. When completed the five guest rooms can accommodate twelve persons in comfort. 

Neighbors in local village 


Background

My lifestyle has always being unorthodox with my ex wife stating I spend too much time and money on traveling holidays. Just ask my kids about some of the adventures they experienced and I think it was all worthwhile ! Working in various professions I gravitated towards Community Education gaining a BA Informal Education.  Involvement in helping disenchanted youth and wider communities in the UK and Gambia enabled me to develop a variety of projects.Youth Exchanges to Amsterdam Holland &
column2:
Harlem USA enabled young people to experience life outside the ""ghetto"". Witnessing the impact of poverty and lack of employment in Gambia I explored the possibility of developing a sustainable project.The idea of creating small scale Eco Tourism in Kitti village situated near the border with Southern Senegal had begun !

Many people questioned why I decided to get involved in such a project and especially in Africa ! Images of corruption, poverty, unstable government and the' 'fear factor' of doing something different.Considering potential obstacles I felt more determined  to complete a worthwhile project,with the intention of creating employment,developing a sustainable business and contributing to the community through Eco tourism. The idea was born and the rest is history!

The name Mellow Yellow conjures up happiness , peace and community and aptly named after a coffee shop I visited in Amsterdam.Hence the name ""Mellow Yellow Mud Brick Retreat"" offering future guests a genuine African cultural experience. 

Impact on the local Community

Living in rural villages without employment and electricity is common place in Gambia with many people leaving to earn an income. Sourcing skilled local workers I was able to employ well diggers, mud brick makers, concrete specialists, masons and steel workers.""News traveled ""about our development project, encouraging local business stakeholders to develop their small micro businesses in a positive fashion. In a variety of ways  this new project contributed to the local economy.Orders ranged from 50kg cement bags,trucks of sand,stone,steel and food bought from local shop keepers.Transport deliveries,taxi drivers and local farmers all benefited, with increasing activity on the building site. Other entrepreneurs turned up on pay day to sell clothes, fresh fish and numerous other goodies.Based upon these experiences our long term aims are to provide further employment for tour guides, dancing &
column3:
drumming teachers ,taxi excursions on completion of the Mellow Yellow Mud Brick Retreat.

Local shop keeper

Further Information

I can honestly say I'm not a builder or architect but have overcome these obstructions by 'learning on the job'. I orchestrated good planning, help from professionals and advance planning visits. On earlier trips to Gambia I worked as a volunteer developing agricultural projects and fresh water wells. These expeditions  enabled me to develop good contacts offering an opportunity to buy land. More importantly I located sources for building materials, transportation, and skilled workers. 

As with many African nations the security of the country is manned by either police or army road blocks which is something you get used too. Transporting materials tests your patience, diplomacy and offers entertainment with expectations of pay offs if anything happens to be out of place. I am now back in the UK to raise additional capital to complete the building including the roofing, interior, fixtures &
column4:
fittings and solar energy needs. (please see list)                  

Target Audience for visitors

International Women Groups- Cultural Expeditions

Independent travelers -off the beaten track

Artists &
column5:
Writers in collaboration with local musicians and artists

Bird Watchers-Gambia offers a great location for ornithologists

International Youth Groups

Fisherman -The river Gambia offers both sea and fresh water fishing

Pensioners - Who enjoy a hot climate

And anybody else who wants an adventure !

Construction begins

I always believe that opportunities which appear difficult are always achievable. No water sources, no building ! The first major step was the construction of a fresh water well. Built with concrete and steel with a depth of 13 meters to avoid any problems with tape worms in the water. Many local wells are just dug out of the ground without any supportive walls, as village people can't afford the concrete and steel needed for construction.

column1:
It's a long way down here !

It's a fantastic feeling knowing you have your own clean, and earthy water supply straight from an underground water table.The water is cool, fresh with a lovely taste !  I find it incredibly difficult now  to drink water from the tap when I'm back in London England.The building has a strong concrete foundation taking two months to finish and completed without the use of machinery. Initially a huge hole was dug measuring 225 square meters filled with ""hand made"" concrete blocks.Then carefully covered with a concrete flooring with a slight amber shape.Using large 15 foot wooden planks enabled the foundation to stand above floor level, vital to avoid flooding and damp damage.Luckily I managed to obtain a petrol engined concrete mixer from a building firm in the UK who generously offered one as a donation, so concrete no longer had to mixed by hand. If you ever had experience of mixing concrete in the hot sun you'll understand  the toil and sweat involved.!
column3:
/>

Concrete foundation beginning to take shape !

Foundation completed

Finally after numerous long days the concrete foundation is completed and  the guys  have done such a great job. Now the 'real work' of making and laying the mud bricks into the shape of a five bed room guest house started in earnest. Eight thousand mud bricks were made by hand as seen in the campaign card photograph.

column1: Reasons for using mud bricks  :
1. Emphasizing the traditional practice and skill of mud brick making.
2. Creating a beautiful building encompassing of orangery brown mud bricks which are both strong and pretty.
3. Utilizing local skilled workers earning money to feed their families.
4. Offering future guests a comfortable stay and a good nights sleep due to the coolness a mud brick building offers

Mud bricks enjoying the warmth of sunshine

The completed mud bricks are placed out in the sun on the hard concrete foundation and given at least four/ five weeks or longer to dry out. The longer they are left the harder they become, and here is the first batch of mud bricks. Every morning the bricks are sprayed lightly with water which gives them some moisture. Mud brick makers are extremely skilled, handling them carefully using an antiquated tool which offers a consistent size and quality.

As you might be aware constructing a building is no easy task , but with help from array of skilled workers the outer walls of the building are progressing without mishaps. The village Chief offered considerable support to the project and welcomed the development of  Eco tourism in Kitti village. Many Gambians rely on the tourist industry which is a major earner for the  economy.Learning new skills I am now able to mix concrete accurately, make mud bricks, whilst managing numerous workers on site. All the building materials are bought locally including stone from the quarry, sand , mud brick mixture and 50 kg cement bags transported by lorry onto the work site. A local villager supplied the cement bags enabling him to develop his small scale micro business, due to the amount of orders I placed.That was great news ! 

            

Guest rooms beginning to take shape

Proudly observing the work achieved so far ""Alieu"" welcomes break time with a big smile and an opportunity to reflect on the work achieved so far ! The next stage of the building process is  completing the four concrete corner pillars and bands around the whole building.Strong concrete support will provide the building with increased  strength, longevity and comfortably hold the weight of the roof. Unable to afford an architect fees I designed the building myself which not only saved money, but offered me another challenge to overcome ! The ongoing project has employed local people, highlighting the needs of countryside dwellers.Proud to be part of this development has encouraged some villagers to consider the idea of a mud brick business to meet local demands.
column3:
/>

Great job Captain coming along nicely !

Omar nicknamed ""Captain""  one of the master builders is putting finishing touches to the corner pillars. The ply- boards used are removed within 48 hours allowing the concrete bands and pylons to dry thoroughly. Using this technique proved useful in containing the shape and concrete mixture for the concrete bands. The combination of steel pylons and concrete gives added strength to the building. As a joint project the villagers are able to earn wages and be involved in the long term process of developing a sustainable business.

This Eco friendly building takes into consideration the local environment, utilizing local materials and the practical use of solar energy. Once the roof has being constructed solar panels can be installed, providing all the energy needs for the building. Gambia guarantees constant sunshine during both the dry and wet season ranging from 6 - 10 hours daily. 

Wow !

The building is beginning to take shape presenting a strong structure, based upon a solid foundation and accurately built walls. The next stage will be the supported triangles which will give further shape to the building, and offer support for the wooden roof structure.

This architectural drawing shows the outline of the roof structure built with red wood otherwise known as 'Iron Wood' which is resistant to wood eating insects. The idea is to create a building with a long 'shelf life', avoiding major additional maintenance costs, using the best quality wood.Transported from over the border in neighboring Southern Senegal I am able to obtain the best quality wood at excellent prices. Kitti village is located only 7 miles from the border with cross border business encouraged to help both local economies.The same tribal groups are located in both countries with many people visiting family and friends.

Please excuse me for the scribble on the drawing !
I hope you are getting a 'feel' for the work involved so far, which has come along way from the early planning stages.There is still an immense amount of work to be completed, but the team is looking forward to continuing the project shortly. Baboucarr a structural engineer worked out the dimensions and calculations  needed for the roof construction. I was really indebted for the invaluable help he provided and felt confident that the strength of the building could hold the roof comfortably without any mishaps !      


This pie chart demonstrates a breakdown of costs involved



Budget costs spent so far :

Cost of land

Shipping costs of imported materials &
column5:
materials

Mud brick machinery rental costs

Truck loads of stone, sand, &
column6:
mud brick mortar

Bags of cement

Transportation cost of raw materials

Storage costs &
column7:
security

General tools on building site -

Plywood boards &
column8: large wooden planks for foundation construction/ concrete bollards &amp
column10:
other accessories

Food for workers

Electrical wiring - sockets- lightning accessories 

Thick Green corrugated roofing

Doors &
column12:
unskilled labor costs

Costs = £20000

I am realistic about the remaining  budget needed. Please see the following outcomes :

Laboring  costs of Skilled workers &

column1:
Indoor furniture  -Locally made

Kitchen construction &
Slate tiling &
column2:
accessories 

Fresh water well connection - piping and solar pump

Roofing materials / nails / screws / &
column4:
plaster

Costs of saw mill

250 pieces of wood assorted shapes and sizes - Red wood

Solar panels, batteries, fuse box  &
column8:
doors 

Bags of cement

Truck loads of stone &
column9:
sand

Transportation costs 

Food for workers

Remaining budget costs  = £ 18000

column1:
Concluding statement

I'm sure you have enjoyed reading our experiences of building a mud brick retreat in a poor &
column2:
undeveloped village ! Considerable work needs to be completed on the building, but with your support the Mellow Yellow Mud Brick Retreat will be a success.
If you are unable to offer any financial support please help by spreading the word about our Eco development.   ` 
 


Finally Boat trip &
column3:
fresh fish for dinner if you donate  £500 +

In the future Kitti Village looks forward to offering adventurous guests a chance to explore a wonderful cultural experience.

Many local wells are just dug out of the ground without any supportive walls, as village people can't afford the concrete and steel needed for construction.

It's a long way down here !It's a fantastic feeling knowing you have your own clean, and earthy water supply straight from an underground water table.The water is cool, fresh with a lovely taste !  I find it incredibly difficult now  to drink water from the tap when I'm back in London England.The building has a strong concrete foundation taking two months to finish and completed without the use of machinery. Initially a huge hole was dug measuring 225 square meters filled with ""hand made"" concrete blocks.Then carefully covered with a concrete flooring with a slight amber shape.Using large 15 foot wooden planks enabled the foundation to stand above floor level, vital to avoid flooding and damp damage.Luckily I managed to obtain a petrol engined concrete mixer from a building firm in the UK who generously offered one as a donation, so concrete no longer had to mixed by hand. If you ever had experience of mixing concrete in the hot sun you'll understand  the toil and sweat involved.!Concrete foundation beginning to take shape !Foundation completedFinally after numerous long days the concrete foundation is completed and  the guys  have done such a great job. Now the 'real work' of making and laying the mud bricks into the shape of a five bed room guest house started in earnest. Eight thousand mud bricks were made by hand as seen in the campaign card photograph.
Reasons for using mud bricks  :
1. Emphasizing the traditional practice and skill of mud brick making.
2. Creating a beautiful building encompassing of orangery brown mud bricks which are both strong and pretty.
3. Utilizing local skilled workers earning money to feed their families.
4. Offering future guests a comfortable stay and a good nights sleep due to the coolness a mud brick building offers

Mud bricks enjoying the warmth of sunshineThe completed mud bricks are placed out in the sun on the hard concrete foundation and given at least four/ five weeks or longer to dry out. The longer they are left the harder they become, and here is the first batch of mud bricks. Every morning the bricks are sprayed lightly with water which gives them some moisture. Mud brick makers are extremely skilled, handling them carefully using an antiquated tool which offers a consistent size and quality. As you might be aware constructing a building is no easy task , but with help from array of skilled workers the outer walls of the building are progressing without mishaps. The village Chief offered considerable support to the project and welcomed the development of  Eco tourism in Kitti village. Many Gambians rely on the tourist industry which is a major earner for the  economy.Learning new skills I am now able to mix concrete accurately, make mud bricks, whilst managing numerous workers on site. All the building materials are bought locally including stone from the quarry, sand , mud brick mixture and 50 kg cement bags transported by lorry onto the work site. A local villager supplied the cement bags enabling him to develop his small scale micro business, due to the amount of orders I placed.That was great news !               Guest rooms beginning to take shape Proudly observing the work achieved so far ""Alieu"" welcomes break time with a big smile and an opportunity to reflect on the work achieved so far ! The next stage of the building process is  completing the four concrete corner pillars and bands around the whole building.Strong concrete support will provide the building with increased  strength, longevity and comfortably hold the weight of the roof. Unable to afford an architect fees I designed the building myself which not only saved money, but offered me another challenge to overcome ! The ongoing project has employed local people, highlighting the needs of countryside dwellers.Proud to be part of this development has encouraged some villagers to consider the idea of a mud brick business to meet local demands.    Great job Captain coming along nicely !Omar nicknamed ""Captain""  one of the master builders is putting finishing touches to the corner pillars. The ply- boards used are removed within 48 hours allowing the concrete bands and pylons to dry thoroughly. Using this technique proved useful in containing the shape and concrete mixture for the concrete bands. The combination of steel pylons and concrete gives added strength to the building. As a joint project the villagers are able to earn wages and be involved in the long term process of developing a sustainable business. This Eco friendly building takes into consideration the local environment, utilizing local materials and the practical use of solar energy. Once the roof has being constructed solar panels can be installed, providing all the energy needs for the building. Gambia guarantees constant sunshine during both the dry and wet season ranging from 6 - 10 hours daily.  Wow ! The building is beginning to take shape presenting a strong structure, based upon a solid foundation and accurately built walls. The next stage will be the supported triangles which will give further shape to the building, and offer support for the wooden roof structure. This architectural drawing shows the outline of the roof structure built with red wood otherwise known as 'Iron Wood' which is resistant to wood eating insects. The idea is to create a building with a long 'shelf life', avoiding major additional maintenance costs, using the best quality wood.Transported from over the border in neighboring Southern Senegal I am able to obtain the best quality wood at excellent prices. Kitti village is located only 7 miles from the border with cross border business encouraged to help both local economies.The same tribal groups are located in both countries with many people visiting family and friends.Please excuse me for the scribble on the drawing !I hope you are getting a 'feel' for the work involved so far, which has come along way from the early planning stages.There is still an immense amount of work to be completed, but the team is looking forward to continuing the project shortly. Baboucarr a structural engineer worked out the dimensions and calculations  needed for the roof construction. I was really indebted for the invaluable help he provided and felt confident that the strength of the building could hold the roof comfortably without any mishaps !       This pie chart demonstrates a breakdown of costs involvedBudget costs spent so far :Cost of land Shipping costs of imported materials & household items Cost of digging well & materialsMud brick machinery rental costsTruck loads of stone, sand, & mud brick mortarBags of cement Transportation cost of raw materials Storage costs & security General tools on building site - Plywood boards & large wooden planks for foundation construction/ concrete bollards & bands  Steel & other accessories Food for workersElectrical wiring - sockets- lightning accessories  Thick Green corrugated roofingDoors & locks Skilled workers & unskilled labor costs Costs = £20000 I am realistic about the remaining  budget needed. Please see the following outcomes :Laboring  costs of Skilled workers & laborers
Indoor furniture  -Locally made Kitchen construction & breakfast barBathrooms- including showers & toilet facilities

Slate tiling & accessories  Fresh water well connection - piping and solar pumpRoofing materials / nails / screws / & accessoriesIndustrial pump and pipingPlastering tools & plasterCosts of saw mill 250 pieces of wood assorted shapes and sizes - Red woodSolar panels, batteries, fuse box  & installationCompletion of sewage system & piping Pluming of household & connections Wooden door frames , windows & doors Bags of cementTruck loads of stone & sandTransportation costs Food for workers Remaining budget costs  = £ 18000

Concluding statement I'm sure you have enjoyed reading our experiences of building a mud brick retreat in a poor & undeveloped village ! Considerable work needs to be completed on the building, but with your support the Mellow Yellow Mud Brick Retreat will be a success.If you are unable to offer any financial support please help by spreading the word about our Eco development.   `   Finally Boat trip & fresh fish for dinner if you donate  £500 +In the future Kitti Village looks forward to offering adventurous guests a chance to explore a wonderful cultural experience.",14.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Kitti Village, Gambia",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/lets-build-the-mellow-yellow-mud-brick-retreat/pica

I have always been fascinated with Antarctica. When I was little I dreamed of visiting all 7 continents, but Antarctica seemed unreachable unless I was a scientist for superhero (one in the same, wouldn't you agree?). Then, in 1997, I read ""The Back Door Guide to Short-Term Job Adventures,"" by Michael Landes. A very short passage explained how non-scientists/non-superheroes were able to find work on the Ice Continent and it was settled: this little island girl from Guam was going to Antarctica... someday!

Shortly after becoming open water SCUBA certified, I learned I could actually dive in Antarctica. I also learned more about the plight of our seas. I decided it was time to finally make my Antarctica dream a reality, before it was too late. But I needed to do more than just be a very cold tourist. I wanted my trip to mean something, to bring some good into this world.

Over the last few months, I have devoted every spare moment to training for Antarctic diving and learning more about our fragile blue home. In February, I will embark on a trip that will take me to Korea, the UK, Iceland, Chile, Antarctica, Hawaii, and then back home to Guam.

David Ramsay, from Magmadive.is will train me in Iceland and then join me as my Antarctica dive buddy, where we will take the most amazing underwater photography of the Antarctic Peninsula and the Weddell Sea.

We will use the funds raised through this campaign towards creating photo books DVDs, and other media, to document the journey and celebrate underwater realms all over the globe. Also, 30% of every donation will go towards saving our marine habitats. 

Support our project today, and be one of the firsts to see our breathtaking underwater imagery from all corners of the planet, while contributing to important ocean protection initiatives. Blue = Green! Oceans = Oxygen! Antarctica 2015!

Dear Friends,
In 2015, the World Economic Forum ranked
water as the Top Global Risk for the first time.
ACTION IS NEEDED NOW!
After completing a PhD in Water Engineering in France,
I relocated to Toronto and created Ecoloodi (ecoloodi.org), a bilingual non-profit
organization dedicated to educating children about water issues.
Ecoloodi has delivered water-related educational
programs to children in Canada, France and Benin. By educating children today,

we can help create the leadership needed for tomorrow.

“Human history becomes more and more a race between education and catastrophe”, H.G. Wells.
You can make a difference in people’s lives by helping us expand our
water themed educational activities.
The $50,000 raised from this campaign will fund educational materials
(videos, books, posters, teaching guides) for children in grades 1 to 6 in
Canada, France and Benin.
Ecoloodi is going back to Benin in January 2016. Half the population
there are children in need, and our partnership providing new educational
materials to teachers will make a big difference.
See the excerpt from a video we created for last year’s visit to Benin

here. 

H2O: The story of a
little drop
<b>Educational tools for children
in Canada, France and Benin.
Budget and Timeline
<div>

Best wishes from Benin


Help us turn water education into action.
Every drop counts!
Ecoloodi started with a seed of an idea. You can help it grow. All
donors will receive up-to-date information about water issues in Ecoloodi’s
monthly Newsletter and recognition on our website (unless choosing to be

anonymous).

""We would appreciate you sharing this campaign
with anyone who can help make a difference and thank
you in advance for your support"", Ludiwine Clouzot, Founder of Ecoloodi
For those in Toronto:
Join us for a very special event on Tuesday, June 16th, from
6 to 9PM, at the Centre for Social Innovation (720 Bathurst St.). The Water4All
event will feature a panel of water experts, live music, dance, food, a
silent auction and The Water Brothers. This will be a fun evening to meet and mingle with members of
the water community.

Scientists predict that by 2050 - in 33 years, there will be more plastic in the ocean than fish. What can you do about it? Support the Save the Albatross Coalition and help reduce this plastic plauge.

Why the Albatross?

Just as the canary in the coal mine forewarns of danger, the Laysan Albatross provides a way to measure the impact of plastics in the ocean. Known as the sailor's companion, this once ubiquitous bird is threatened with extinction because of the unintended consequences of our plastic discards. Floating bottle caps look and smell like food. This plastic is then eaten by adult birds and regurgitated for their young whose bellies fill with plastic causing them to starve. The Laysan Albatross is a poster child for this problem – but 80% of all seabird species across the globe are impacted.

Want to help?

Step 1. Donate to our campaign. We will use your contribution to support our grassroots and global efforts. 

What to do more?

Step 2. Sign the Change.org Petition, Tell Coke and Pepsi to leash their lids.

Step 3. Write to California legislators and tell them to support Assembly Bill 319. FindYourRep.legislature.ca.gov. AB 319 Sample Letter of Support

Step 4. Tell your friends about the campaign and share this link on social media.  https://igg.me/at/savethealbatross

By helping to fund the Save the Albatross Coalition you will be supporting education and public outreach as well as specific legislation to require beverage producers and distributors to leash the lids to bottles to avoid further danger to all ocean creatures.

California Assemblyman Mark Stone (D, 29th Assembly District – Monterrey, Santa Cruz and Santa Clara Counties) introduced Assembly Bill 319, which would prohibit retailers, by 2020, from selling beverages in bottles with a cap that is not tethered to the container. This California law can help make changes worldwide.

Bottle caps are one of the most frequent items found at annual beach and watershed clean-ups, threatening wildlife that mistakes the bottle caps for food and costing local communities millions of dollars to address the plastic debris. 

There is a precedence for this. In the 1970s, the beverage industry proactively replaced pull-tabs on cans with today’s stay-on tabs, eradicating small metal pieces that polluted streets and beaches. 

With your support, we will make meaningful change to the status quo and help the plight of the albatross and the rest of our ocean eco-system.

About me and the research:

I'm a post graduate and I'm trying to get an scholarship to become a researcher. While I get the scholarship I'm starting to work on my thesis project at the National Museum of Natural Sciences in Madrid (Spain).

My project it's going to be about bird speciation in islands, using the chaffinch (Fringilla coelebs) as model species. Islands are perfect ecosystems to study adaptive radiations (rapid speciation processes, a good example are Darwin's finches). To achieve the goal of the study I need to take samples in different islands to compare them with samples from the continent. I already have some samples from the Canary Islands and Spain, but I also need samples from the island of Guadalupe (México) and the continental part.
I need about 1500 USD to pay the cover the flights to and within México and the expenses for food for a month.
To thank you, I am very happy to offer perks, which are beautiful  photographs taken during the trip, of the birds captured (They don't suffer any harm, of course) and the beautiful landscapes.
Any help will be welcome, so if I don't reach my entire goal I hope I can collect the rest in other ways, Difussion is always a nice way to help too!
The Impact
This project can help in many ways, for instance, many morphs of the chaffinch catalogued today as subspecies could become different new species!
Moreover this research would help to a better understanding of the process of speciation and the genomic base underneath.
Of course, when the field work and the analysis are done I hope to publish all the amazing results in science magazines and in my thesis.
Thank you in advance!

OBRIST C-Transformer

Need further details? Check out our OCT webpage with further information, explanations and videos from supporters, scientists and up to 100 answered questions:
www.obrist-c-transformer.com

What happens when a tree-hugger, a technical mathematician, an expert in emission avoidance and some scientists from the US and Austria are working together? Something good for Mother Nature and humankind.

The world's most burning problem today is climate change. How we deal with it will determine if we have a future or if we will join the dinosaurs. We've noticed that everyone is telling us what we shouldn't do, but nobody is telling us what we can do. We want to change that.

Throwing all our knowledge together in one pot and observing nature gave us the idea for the OBRIST C-Transformer. A machine that will combine many different technologies and navigate through our forests. A machine inspired by nature and created for nature to overcome what our planet cannot manage by itself anymore, and ultimately, what caused climate change: CO2 produced by humans. 

We have the concept and scientific proof.
Now we need you to help us make it a reality and to transform our planet together.

 

Why this is important

Through various forms of transportation and industries we have caused an extremely high amount of CO2 emissions. We have destroyed the natural balance and nature cannot cope anymore.

The OBRIST C-Transformer will use natural resources to possibly not only stop climate change, but also to create a chance to turn it around. It will utilize the natural process of the trees to pull CO2 from the air. The technologies needed will be optimized for the OBRIST C-Transformer to ensure the ability to act as quickly as possible. 

Why it works

Carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is necessary for plants and trees to grow. Forests play a specific and important role in the global carbon cycle by absorbing carbon dioxide during photosynthesis, storing carbon above and below the ground, and producing oxygen as a by-product of photosynthesis (US Department of Agriculture Forest Service)

However, without the OBRIST C-Transformer our forests are close to CO2 neutral. This means they bind and release almost similar amouts of carbon during their life span. With the help of the OBRIST C-Transformer, our forests will be revitalized and able to reduce CO2 from the atmosphere for the long term.

How? Before a tree dies and releases its carbon, which has been stored in its wood during its life span back into the atmosphere, the OBRIST C-Transformer will turn its trunk into biochar and introduce it into the forest's ground. In this manner, the carbon improves soil fertility and the release of carbon back into our atmosphere is prevented.

Even more, the OBRIST C-Transformer will not only address the problem of too much CO2 in our atmosphere, but simultaneously it will help revitalize our forests by planting new trees and seedlings, leading to a greater biodiversity and creating healthy, self-sustaining and thriving ecosystems. In this manner, it could be optimally used to transform areas of monoculture into lively permaculture.
Results
<div>

The OBRIST C-Transformer will be a long-term solution for our environment. After having reached the point of worldwide carbon neutrality, the OBRIST C-Transformer can continue to actually reverse climate change and keep converting our forest areas into forests full of healthy biodiversity. This will make them self-sustaining, just like forests used to be before we humans destroyed the balance.

Another key factor is the economic stimulation of areas which are usually economically low by providing an opportunity to generate revenue from these forests without destroying the natural biodiversity. The OBRIST C-Transformer will impulse the reforestation of harvested areas and the afforestation of degraded monoculture areas.
 
The OBRIST C-Transformer
Creating fertile soil. Planting new trees. Renewing our forests. And providing a solution to not only stop climate change, but also to create a chance to turn it around.

 

The story behind

Who we are: Nickole Lewis, Chris Meusburger, Frank Obrist and a bunch of other people, all working together at OBRIST Technologies Inc. (Whittier, California) and OBRIST Engineering (Lustenau, Austria). Our companies have been focused on emission avoidance and reduction technologies for 20 years.  During the past two decades the OBRIST group emerged as the technology leader in mobile applications based on the natural refrigerant R744. With the implementation of OBRIST compressor technologies, the first eco-friendly air conditioning was implemented in the Mercedes S-Class mass production.

The idea

The idea of the OBRIST C-Transformer was born by Frank Obrist, founder of the OBRIST group together with Robert Schlögl, the director at the Fritz Haber institute of the Max Planck society. Discussing the possibility to use biomass as fuel, Frank had the flash of wit to support forests in reducing carbon and to provide a solution that can fix a problem generated over many generations - climate change.

Nickole Lewis from the US, working as an international project manager at OBRIST Technologies and calling herself a tree-hugger and pro-earth, was intrigued by the possibility of creating a machine that will give something back to Mother Nature instead of exploiting her while simultaneously doing something against climate change. She instantly joined the development and sided with Chris Meusburger, a technical mathematician in his early twenties. Chris likes down-to-earth solutions and is focused on using approved technologies to implement the OBRIST C-Transformer
column2:
a machine that will use already existing solutions and create a chance that nobody thought was possible.

 

Crowdfunding and why we need it

Worldwide solutions need worldwide actions. Climate change concerns us all and we believe that saving our planet should be a top priority for all nations worldwide. If everything remains as is our children's future will be bleak. We need fast and efficient action. Nevertheless, the development of the OBRIST C-Transformer requires money. It can only be put into reality if we all stick together.

Our plans

Our first phase will be to examine core processes of the OBRIST C-Transformer like pyrolysis, storage potentials, the scope of the processes and the size of the machine needed. We then plan to link worldwide with scientists and universities for the development phase. Our tentative goal is series production by 2025. All together we are looking at a total investment of one billion dollars. We would like to finance the first part of this amount through crowdfunding while at the same time creating global awareness for our project.

Funding steps: Finances and actions

$500.000,00 and above, within the first year

Evaluation of core-topics such as sizing, pyrolysis process, machine concept, total c-transforming capacity

$1.000.000,00 and above, within the first year

Possibility to raise worldwide awareness and to get in contact with universities, researchers, scientists worldwide. We will be able to fine tune the core-topics.

$2.000.000,00 and above, within the first year

Preparation of a scientific team setup including universities, laboratories, research institutions worldwide

$5.000.000,00 and above, within the first year

Diving deeper in the process, first simulation possible, full theoretical approach, more detailed design studies: How will the OBRIST C-Transformer technology work in detail?

$10.000.000,00 and above, within the next 3 years

Selected, simplified practical pre-tests with the global researching team
Focus on most critical and most risky processes and aspects

$20.000.000,00 and above, within the next 3 years

Evaluation of research results and 2nd loop of critical, practical pre-tests
column3: Evaluation and first contacts to worldwide companies for hardware design &
column4:
supply

$50.000.000,00, within the next 3 years

Beginning of the setup of first hardware prototypes of the single sub-units in decentral approach

$50.000.000,00 and above, within the next 4 to 5 years

Focus on critical aspects and energy processes
column5: Integration of worldwide activists, major companies
column6:
a-sample level of the decentral units

$100.000.000,00 and above, within the next 4 to 5 years

B-Sample level of the decentral units, setup of know-how pool structure
column7:
$500.000.000,00 and above, within the next 6 to 7 years

First movable prototype in reduced scale
column8: Confirmation of efficiency, storing capacity and working principle
column9: development and integration of real hardware units in reduced scale
column10:
pilot prototype unit in reduced scale

$1.000.000.000,00 and above, after 2025

Full implementation of technology including at least 2 full prototypes, global approach including full and high level promotion of the technology
column11:
Mass production design, Proof of concept in 3 selected areas

Implementation phase: Worldwide roll-out

 

Risks and challenges

We have invested tons of effort in order to initiate the concept of the OBRIST C-Transformer, but Murphy is always on the lookout and many unexpected things can happen. 
Money is critical. We need a huge amount to finance scientists, researches, prototypes and lots of other things. The crowdfunding campaign is our chance to raise awareness in order to reach as much independent funding as possible.

What happens if we don't reach our funding goal? We will keep up our work. Every single dollar you're willing to spend will be used to proceed with the development as far as possible.We know that crowdfunding cannot be our sole way of financing the OBRIST C-Transformer. That is why we've also thought about additional ways like climate funds and private equity to bring the OBRIST C-Transformer to life.

 

Perks

We've thought a lot about what kind of perks to offer for your help. We've decided to create perks that fit to our target and mission. You can choose out of different kinds of possibilities and actions to help save our world in addition to your support of the OBRIST C-Transformer.

Didn't find anything you like? Just let us know. We're happy to hear your ideas.

 

What can you do besides funding us

Spread the word and talk to your friends. Share our campaign and help us raise awareness. We have a chance to turn climate change around. Don't miss it.

Become a part of our development

We have given a lot of thought on different topics of our concept. Nonetheless, we are still fine-tuning the process. Do you have some ideas or do you know someone who would be eager to help? Is there anything we haven't thought about? Share your knowledge and your questions. Give us feedback and join the development process.

 

Frequently asked questions

Still curious? Check out our OCT platform with further information, explanations and videos from supporters, scientists and up to 100 answered questions: www.obrist-c-transformer.com/platform
